<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Joseph Stalin</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Leader of the Soviet Union (1924–1953)</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Stalin" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Stalin_(disambiguation)" title="Stalin (disambiguation)">Stalin (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">In this name that follows <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Slavic_naming_customs" title="Eastern Slavic naming customs">Eastern Slavic naming conventions</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Patronymic" title="Patronymic">patronymic</a> is <i> Vissarionovich</i> and the <a href="/wiki/Surname" title="Surname">family name</a> is <i> <a href="/wiki/Stalin_(name)" title="Stalin (name)">Stalin</a></i>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<div class="center"><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leader_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Leader of the Soviet Union">Leader of the Soviet Union</a></b><br/>
<div class="hlist hlist-separated">
<ul><li><span style="font-size: 120%;"><b>←</b></span> <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Georgy_Malenkov" title="Georgy Malenkov">Malenkov</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[f]</a></sup><span style="font-size: 120%;"><b>→</b></span></li></ul>
</div>
</div></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-below" colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px solid right; font-size: 95%"><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Joseph Vissarionovich Stalin</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[g]</a></sup> (born <b>Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili</b>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birth_name_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-birth_name-4">[d]</a></sup> 18 December [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 6 December] 1878<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014742,_note_25_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014742,_note_25-8">[1]</a></sup> – 5 March 1953) was a <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">Georgian</a> revolutionary and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_people" title="Soviet people">Soviet</a> political leader who led the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> from 1924 until his death in 1953. He held power as <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> (1922–1952) and <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Premier of the Soviet Union">Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union</a> (1941–1953). Initially governing the country as part of a <a href="/wiki/Collective_leadership_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Collective leadership in the Soviet Union">collective leadership</a>, he consolidated power to become a dictator by the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[2]</a></sup> Ideologically adhering to the <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninist</a> interpretation of <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a>, he formalised these ideas as <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a>, while his own policies are called <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinism</a>.
</p><p>Born to a poor family in <a href="/wiki/Gori,_Georgia" title="Gori, Georgia">Gori</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>), Stalin attended the <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi_Spiritual_Seminary" title="Tbilisi Spiritual Seminary">Tbilisi Spiritual Seminary</a> before joining the Marxist <a href="/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party</a>. He edited the party's newspaper, <i><a href="/wiki/Pravda" title="Pravda">Pravda</a></i>, and raised funds for <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolshevik" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> faction via robberies, kidnappings and <a href="/wiki/Protection_racket" title="Protection racket">protection rackets</a>. Repeatedly arrested, he underwent several internal exiles to <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a> seized power in the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a> and created a <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a> under the new <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Communist Party</a> in 1917, Stalin joined its governing <a href="/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Politburo</a>. Serving in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> before overseeing <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Creation_of_the_Union_of_Soviet_Socialist_Republics" title="Treaty on the Creation of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics">the Soviet Union's establishment</a> in 1922, Stalin <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Rise of Joseph Stalin">assumed leadership over the country</a> following <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Vladimir_Lenin" title="Death and state funeral of Vladimir Lenin">Lenin's death in 1924</a>. Under Stalin, <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_one_country" title="Socialism in one country">socialism in one country</a> became a central tenet of the <a href="/wiki/Ideology_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Ideology of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">party's ideology</a>. As a result of his <a href="/wiki/Five-year_plans_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Five-year plans of the Soviet Union">Five-Year Plans</a>, the country underwent <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Collectivization in the Soviet Union">agricultural collectivisation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Industrialization in the Soviet Union">rapid industrialisation</a>, creating a centralised <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">command economy</a>. Severe disruptions to food production contributed to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%9333" title="Soviet famine of 1932–33">famine of 1930–33</a> that killed millions. To eradicate accused "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enemies_of_the_working_class" title="Enemies of the working class">enemies of the working class</a>", Stalin instituted the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>, in which over a million were imprisoned and at least 700,000 executed between 1934 and 1939. By 1937, he had absolute control over the party and government. Stalin also further expanded the <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">Gulag</a> system of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forced-labour_camps" title="Forced-labour camps">forced labour camps</a>.
</p><p>Stalin promoted Marxism–Leninism abroad through the <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Communist International</a> and supported European <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-fascist" title="Anti-fascist">anti-fascist</a> movements during the 1930s, particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a>. In 1939, his regime signed a <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">non-aggression pact</a> with <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">Soviet invasion of Poland</a>. Germany ended the pact by <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invading the Soviet Union</a> in 1941. Despite initial catastrophes, the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> repelled the German invasion and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">captured Berlin</a> in 1945, ending <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> in Europe. Amid the war, the Soviets <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">annexed the Baltic states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina" title="Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina">Bessarabia and North Bukovina</a>, subsequently establishing <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Empire" title="Soviet Empire">Soviet-aligned governments</a> throughout Central and Eastern Europe and in parts of East Asia. The Soviet Union and the United States emerged as global superpowers and entered a period of tension, the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. Stalin presided over the Soviet post-war reconstruction and its <a href="/wiki/Soviet_atomic_bomb_project" title="Soviet atomic bomb project">development of an atomic bomb</a> in 1949. During these years, the country experienced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1946%E2%80%9347" title="Soviet famine of 1946–47">another major famine</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Antisemitism in the Soviet Union">antisemitic</a> campaign that culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Doctors%27_plot" title="Doctors' plot">doctors' plot</a>. After <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Death and state funeral of Joseph Stalin">Stalin's death</a> in 1953, he was eventually succeeded by <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>, who subsequently <a href="/wiki/On_the_Cult_of_Personality_and_Its_Consequences" title="On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences">denounced his rule</a> and initiated the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/De-Stalinisation" title="De-Stalinisation">de-Stalinisation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Culture of the Soviet Union">Soviet society</a>.
</p><p>Widely considered to be one of the 20th century's most significant figures, Stalin was the subject of a pervasive <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin%27s_cult_of_personality" title="Joseph Stalin's cult of personality">personality cult</a> within the international Marxist–Leninist movement, which revered him as a champion of the working class and <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991, Stalin has retained popularity in Russia and Georgia as a victorious wartime leader who cemented the Soviet Union's status as a leading world power. Conversely, his regime has been described as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Totalitarian" title="Totalitarian">totalitarian</a>, and has been widely condemned for overseeing <a href="/wiki/Political_repression_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Political repression in the Soviet Union">mass repression</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">wide-scale deportation</a>, hundreds of thousands of executions, and famines <a href="/wiki/Excess_mortality_in_the_Soviet_Union_under_Joseph_Stalin" title="Excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin">that killed millions</a>.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Early_life_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Early life of Joseph Stalin">Early life of Joseph Stalin</a></div>
<h3><span id="1878.E2.80.931899:_Childhood_to_young_adulthood"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1878–1899:_Childhood_to_young_adulthood">1878–1899: Childhood to young adulthood</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:155px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="993" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg/188px-Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg/282px-Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg/376px-Stalin_1893-1.1.1.jpg 2x" width="188"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:118px;max-width:118px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:155px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="816" data-file-width="612" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg/116px-Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg/174px-Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg/232px-Stalin_1893-1.1.2_detail.jpg 2x" width="116"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">1893 class table of Gori Religious School including a photo of Stalin. Some of the photos may be from earlier dates, but it is believed that this photo of Stalin was taken in 1893.</div></div></div></div>
<p>Stalin was born in the Georgian town of <a href="/wiki/Gori,_Georgia" title="Gori, Georgia">Gori</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19912Khlevniuk201511_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19912Khlevniuk201511-10">[3]</a></sup> then part of the <a href="/wiki/Tiflis_Governorate" title="Tiflis Governorate">Tiflis Governorate</a> of the Russian Empire and home to a mix of Georgian, Azerbaijanian, Armenian, Russian, and Jewish communities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200415_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200415-11">[4]</a></sup> He was born on 18 December [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 6 December] 1878<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200414Montefiore200723_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200414Montefiore200723-12">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[h]</a></sup> and baptised on 29 December.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200416_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200416-15">[7]</a></sup> His birth name was Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-birth_name_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-birth_name-4">[d]</a></sup> and he was nicknamed "Soso", a <a href="/wiki/Diminutive" title="Diminutive">diminutive</a> of "Ioseb".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200416Montefiore200723Kotkin201417_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200416Montefiore200723Kotkin201417-16">[8]</a></sup> His parents were <a href="/wiki/Besarion_Jughashvili" title="Besarion Jughashvili">Besarion Jughashvili</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keke_Geladze" title="Keke Geladze">Ekaterine Geladze</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19912Volkogonov19915Service200414Montefiore200719Khlevniuk201511_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19912Volkogonov19915Service200414Montefiore200719Khlevniuk201511-17">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196626Conquest19911Khlevniuk201511_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196626Conquest19911Khlevniuk201511-18">[10]</a></sup> He was their only child to survive past infancy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19915Service200416Montefiore200722Kotkin201417Khlevniuk201511_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19915Service200416Montefiore200722Kotkin201417Khlevniuk201511-19">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Besarion was a shoemaker who was employed in a workshop owned by another man;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19915Service200414Montefiore200722Kotkin201416_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19915Service200414Montefiore200722Kotkin201416-20">[12]</a></sup> it was initially a financial success but later fell into decline,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200416Montefiore200722,_32_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200416Montefiore200722,_32-21">[13]</a></sup> and the family found itself living in poverty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200419_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200419-22">[14]</a></sup> Besarion became an alcoholic<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200417Montefiore200725Kotkin201420Khlevniuk201512_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200417Montefiore200725Kotkin201420Khlevniuk201512-23">[15]</a></sup> and drunkenly beat his wife and son.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199110Volkogonov19915Service200417Montefiore200729Kotkin201424Khlevniuk201512_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199110Volkogonov19915Service200417Montefiore200729Kotkin201424Khlevniuk201512-24">[16]</a></sup> Ekaterine and Stalin left the home by 1883 and began a wandering life, moving through nine different rented rooms over the next decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200730–31Kotkin201420_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200730–31Kotkin201420-25">[17]</a></sup> In 1886, they moved into the house of a family friend, Father Christopher Charkviani.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Montefiore200731Kotkin201420–21_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Montefiore200731Kotkin201420–21-26">[18]</a></sup> Ekaterine worked as a house cleaner and launderer and was determined to send her son to school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200731–32_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200731–32-27">[19]</a></sup> In September 1888, Stalin enrolled at the Orthodox Gori Church School,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[20]</a></sup> a place secured by Charkviani.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200420Montefiore200732–34Kotkin201421_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200420Montefiore200732–34Kotkin201421-29">[21]</a></sup> Although he got into many fights,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200420Montefiore200736_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200420Montefiore200736-30">[22]</a></sup> Stalin excelled academically,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Service200430Montefiore200744Kotkin201426_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Service200430Montefiore200744Kotkin201426-31">[23]</a></sup> displaying talent in painting and drama classes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200743–44_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200743–44-32">[24]</a></sup> writing <a href="/wiki/Stalin%27s_poetry" title="Stalin's poetry">his own poetry</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200744_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200744-33">[25]</a></sup> and singing as a choirboy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199113Service200430Montefiore200743Kotkin201426_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199113Service200430Montefiore200743Kotkin201426-34">[26]</a></sup> Stalin faced several severe health problems: An 1884 <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> infection left him with facial scars;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Volkogonov19915Service200419Montefiore200731Kotkin201420_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Volkogonov19915Service200419Montefiore200731Kotkin201420-35">[27]</a></sup> and at age 12 he was seriously injured when he was hit by a <a href="/wiki/Phaeton_(carriage)" title="Phaeton (carriage)">phaeton</a>, probably the cause of a lifelong disability in his left arm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Service200425Montefiore200735,_46Kotkin201420–21_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199112Service200425Montefiore200735,_46Kotkin201420–21-36">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="510" data-file-width="686" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg/260px-The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg/390px-The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg/520px-The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Orthodox_Theological_Seminary.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1894 Stalin began his studies at the <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi_Spiritual_Seminary" title="Tbilisi Spiritual Seminary">Tiflis Spiritual Seminary</a> (pictured here in the 1870s).</div></div></div>
<p>In August 1894, Stalin enrolled in the Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi_Spiritual_Seminary" title="Tbilisi Spiritual Seminary">Spiritual Seminary</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tiflis</a>, enabled by a scholarship that allowed him to study at a reduced rate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196628Montefiore200751–53Khlevniuk201515_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196628Montefiore200751–53Khlevniuk201515-37">[29]</a></sup> He joined 600 trainee priests who boarded there,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200754–55_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200754–55-38">[30]</a></sup> and he achieved high grades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Service200436Montefiore200756Kotkin201432Khlevniuk201516_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Service200436Montefiore200756Kotkin201432Khlevniuk201516-39">[31]</a></sup> He continued writing poetry; five of his poems, on themes such as nature, land and patriotism, were published under the pseudonym of "Soselo" in <a href="/wiki/Ilia_Chavchavadze" title="Ilia Chavchavadze">Ilia Chavchavadze</a>'s newspaper <i>Iveria</i> (<i>Georgia</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199118Service200438Montefiore200757Kotkin201433_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199118Service200438Montefiore200757Kotkin201433-40">[32]</a></sup> According to Stalin's biographer <a href="/wiki/Simon_Sebag_Montefiore" title="Simon Sebag Montefiore">Simon Sebag Montefiore</a>, they became "minor Georgian classics"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200758_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200758-41">[33]</a></sup> and were included in various anthologies of Georgian poetry over the coming years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200758_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200758-41">[33]</a></sup> As he grew older, Stalin lost interest in priestly studies, his grades dropped,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200769Kotkin201432Khlevniuk201518_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200769Kotkin201432Khlevniuk201518-42">[34]</a></sup> and he was repeatedly confined to a cell for his rebellious behaviour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Montefiore200769Kotkin201436–37Khlevniuk201519_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Montefiore200769Kotkin201436–37Khlevniuk201519-43">[35]</a></sup> The seminary's journal noted that he declared himself an atheist, stalked out of prayers and refused to doff his hat to monks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200770–71_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200770–71-44">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin joined a forbidden book club at the school;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Montefiore200762Kotkin201436,_37Khlevniuk201518_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199119Montefiore200762Kotkin201436,_37Khlevniuk201518-45">[37]</a></sup> he was particularly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Chernyshevsky" title="Nikolay Chernyshevsky">Nikolay Chernyshevsky</a>'s 1863 pro-revolutionary novel <i><a href="/wiki/What_Is_to_Be_Done%3F_(novel)" title="What Is to Be Done? (novel)">What Is To Be Done?</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200763_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200763-46">[38]</a></sup> Another influential text was <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Kazbegi" title="Alexander Kazbegi">Alexander Kazbegi</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Patricide" title="The Patricide">The Patricide</a></i>, with Stalin adopting the nickname "Koba" from that of the book's bandit protagonist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199114Volkogonov19915Service200427–28Montefiore200763Kotkin201423–24Khlevniuk201517_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199114Volkogonov19915Service200427–28Montefiore200763Kotkin201423–24Khlevniuk201517-47">[39]</a></sup> The pseudonym may also have been a tribute to his wealthy benefactor, Yakobi "Koba" Egnatashvili, who paid for his schooling at the Tiflis seminary. ("Koba" is the Georgian diminutive of Yakobi, or Jacob, and Stalin later named <a href="/wiki/Yakov_Dzhugashvili" title="Yakov Dzhugashvili">his first-born son</a> in Egnatashvili's honor.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[41]</a></sup> He also read <i><a href="/wiki/Das_Kapital" title="Das Kapital">Das Kapital</a></i>, the 1867 book by German sociological theorist <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196638Montefiore200764_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196638Montefiore200764-50">[42]</a></sup> Stalin devoted himself to Marx's socio-political theory, <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200769_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200769-51">[43]</a></sup> which was then on the rise in Georgia, one of various forms of <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> opposed to the empire's governing <a href="/wiki/Tsarist_autocracy" title="Tsarist autocracy">tsarist</a> authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200440Kotkin201443_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200440Kotkin201443-52">[44]</a></sup> At night, he attended secret workers' meetings<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200766_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200766-53">[45]</a></sup> and was introduced to <a href="/wiki/Silibistro_Jibladze" title="Silibistro Jibladze">Silibistro "Silva" Jibladze</a>, the Marxist founder of <a href="/wiki/Mesame_Dasi" title="Mesame Dasi">Mesame Dasi</a> ("Third Group"), a Georgian socialist group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200765Kotkin201444_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200765Kotkin201444-54">[46]</a></sup> Stalin left the seminary in April 1899 and never returned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200441Montefiore200771_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200441Montefiore200771-55">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1899.E2.80.931904:_Russian_Social-Democratic_Labour_Party"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1899–1904:_Russian_Social-Democratic_Labour_Party">1899–1904: Russian Social-Democratic Labour Party</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1902-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1908" data-file-width="1140" decoding="async" height="368" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Stalin_1902-1.jpg/220px-Stalin_1902-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Stalin_1902-1.jpg/330px-Stalin_1902-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Stalin_1902-1.jpg/440px-Stalin_1902-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1902-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Police photograph of Stalin, taken in 1902, when he was 23 years old.</div></div></div>
<p>In October 1899, Stalin began work as a meteorologist at the Tiflis observatory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196654Conquest199127Service200443–44Montefiore200776Kotkin201447–48_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196654Conquest199127Service200443–44Montefiore200776Kotkin201447–48-56">[48]</a></sup> He had a light workload and therefore had plenty of time for revolutionary activity. He attracted a group of supporters through his classes in socialist theory<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200779_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200779-57">[49]</a></sup> and co-organised a secret workers' mass meeting for <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">May Day</a> 1900,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196654Conquest199127Montefiore200778_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196654Conquest199127Montefiore200778-58">[50]</a></sup> at which he successfully encouraged many of the men to take strike action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200778_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200778-59">[51]</a></sup> By this point, the empire's secret police, the <a href="/wiki/Okhrana" title="Okhrana">Okhrana</a>, were aware of Stalin's activities in Tiflis' revolutionary milieu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200778_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200778-59">[51]</a></sup> They attempted to arrest him in March 1901, but he escaped and went into hiding,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199127Service200445Montefiore200781–82Kotkin201449_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199127Service200445Montefiore200781–82Kotkin201449-60">[52]</a></sup> living off the donations of friends and sympathisers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200782_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200782-61">[53]</a></sup> Remaining underground, he helped plan a demonstration for May Day 1901, in which 3,000 marchers clashed with the authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199128Montefiore200782Kotkin201450_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199128Montefiore200782Kotkin201450-62">[54]</a></sup> He continued to evade arrest by using aliases and sleeping in different apartments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200787_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200787-63">[55]</a></sup> In November 1901, he was elected to the Tiflis Committee of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">Russian Social Democratic Labour Party</a> (RSDLP), a Marxist party founded in 1898.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196663Rieber200537–38Montefiore200787–88_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196663Rieber200537–38Montefiore200787–88-64">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>That month, Stalin travelled to the port city of <a href="/wiki/Batumi" title="Batumi">Batumi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200452Rieber200539Montefiore2007101Kotkin201451_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200452Rieber200539Montefiore2007101Kotkin201451-65">[57]</a></sup> His militant rhetoric proved divisive among the city's Marxists, some of whom suspected that he might be an <i><a href="/wiki/Agent_provocateur" title="Agent provocateur">agent provocateur</a></i> working for the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200791,_95Kotkin201453_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200791,_95Kotkin201453-66">[58]</a></sup> He found employment at the <a href="/wiki/Rothschild_family" title="Rothschild family">Rothschild</a> refinery storehouse, where he co-organised two workers' strikes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200790–93Kotkin201451Khlevniuk201522–23_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200790–93Kotkin201451Khlevniuk201522–23-67">[59]</a></sup> After several strike leaders were arrested, he co-organised a mass public demonstration which led to the storming of the prison; troops fired upon the demonstrators, 13 of whom were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200449Montefiore200794–95Kotkin201452Khlevniuk201523_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200449Montefiore200794–95Kotkin201452Khlevniuk201523-68">[60]</a></sup> Stalin organised another mass demonstration on the day of their funeral,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200797–98_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200797–98-69">[61]</a></sup> before being arrested in April 1902.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200449Rieber200542Montefiore200798Kotkin201452_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199129Service200449Rieber200542Montefiore200798Kotkin201452-70">[62]</a></sup> Held first in Batumi Prison<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196667Service200452Montefiore2007101_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196667Service200452Montefiore2007101-71">[63]</a></sup> and then Kutaisi Prison,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196667Conquest199129Service200452Montefiore2007105_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196667Conquest199129Service200452Montefiore2007105-72">[64]</a></sup> in mid-1903 he was sentenced to three years of exile in eastern Siberia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196668Conquest199129Montefiore2007107Kotkin201453Khlevniuk201523_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196668Conquest199129Montefiore2007107Kotkin201453Khlevniuk201523-73">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin left Batumi in October, arriving at the small Siberian town of <a href="/wiki/Novaya_Uda,_Irkutsk_Oblast" title="Novaya Uda, Irkutsk Oblast">Novaya Uda</a> in late November 1903.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196675Conquest199129Service200452Montefiore2007108–110_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196675Conquest199129Service200452Montefiore2007108–110-74">[66]</a></sup> There, he lived in a two-room peasant's house, sleeping in the building's larder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007111_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007111-75">[67]</a></sup> He made two escape attempts: On the first, he made it to <a href="/wiki/Balagansk" title="Balagansk">Balagansk</a> before returning due to <a href="/wiki/Frostbite" title="Frostbite">frostbite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200452Montefiore2007114–115_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200452Montefiore2007114–115-76">[68]</a></sup> His second attempt, in January 1904, was successful and he made it to Tiflis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200452Montefiore2007115–116Kotkin201453_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200452Montefiore2007115–116Kotkin201453-77">[69]</a></sup> There, he co-edited a Georgian Marxist newspaper, <i><a href="/wiki/Proletariatis_Brdzola" title="Proletariatis Brdzola">Proletariatis Brdzola</a></i> ("Proletarian Struggle"), with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philip_Makharadze" title="Philip Makharadze">Philip Makharadze</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200457Montefiore2007123_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200457Montefiore2007123-78">[70]</a></sup> He called for the Georgian Marxist movement to split from its Russian counterpart, resulting in several RSDLP members accusing him of holding views contrary to the ethos of <a href="/wiki/Proletarian_internationalism" title="Proletarian internationalism">Marxist internationalism</a> and calling for his expulsion from the party; he soon recanted his opinions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200454Montefiore2007117–118Kotkin201477_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200454Montefiore2007117–118Kotkin201477-79">[71]</a></sup> During his exile, the RSDLP had split between <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Julius_Martov" title="Julius Martov">Julius Martov</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Mensheviks" title="Mensheviks">Mensheviks</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199133–34Service200453Montefiore2007113Kotkin201478–79Khlevniuk201524_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199133–34Service200453Montefiore2007113Kotkin201478–79Khlevniuk201524-80">[72]</a></sup> Stalin detested many of the Mensheviks in Georgia and aligned himself with the Bolsheviks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196676Service200459Kotkin201480Khlevniuk201524_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196676Service200459Kotkin201480Khlevniuk201524-81">[73]</a></sup> Although he established a Bolshevik stronghold in the mining town of <a href="/wiki/Chiatura" title="Chiatura">Chiatura</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007131_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007131-82">[74]</a></sup> Bolshevism remained a minority force in the Menshevik-dominated Georgian revolutionary scene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199138Service200459_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199138Service200459-83">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1905.E2.80.931912:_Revolution_of_1905_and_its_aftermath"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1905–1912:_Revolution_of_1905_and_its_aftermath">1905–1912: Revolution of 1905 and its aftermath</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="732" data-file-width="1016" decoding="async" height="209" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG/290px-Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG/435px-Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG/580px-Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lenin_at_Tampere.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin first met Vladimir Lenin at <a href="/wiki/Tampere_conference_of_1905" title="Tampere conference of 1905">a 1905 conference in Tampere</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland" title="Grand Duchy of Finland">Grand Duchy of Finland</a>. Lenin became "Stalin's indispensable mentor".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin201481_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin201481-84">[76]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In January 1905, government troops <a href="/wiki/Bloody_Sunday_(1905)" title="Bloody Sunday (1905)">massacred protesters</a> in Saint Petersburg. Unrest soon spread across the Russian Empire in what came to be known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revolution_of_1905" title="Revolution of 1905">Revolution of 1905</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196680Service200456Montefiore2007126_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196680Service200456Montefiore2007126-85">[77]</a></sup> Georgia was particularly affected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196684–85Service200456_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196684–85Service200456-86">[78]</a></sup> Stalin was in <a href="/wiki/Baku" title="Baku">Baku</a> in February when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armenian%E2%80%93Tatar_massacres_of_1905%E2%80%9307" title="Armenian–Tatar massacres of 1905–07">ethnic violence</a> broke out between Armenians and Azeris; at least 2,000 were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200458Montefiore2007128–129_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200458Montefiore2007128–129-87">[79]</a></sup> He publicly lambasted the "pogroms against Jews and Armenians" as being part of Tsar <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II</a>'s attempts to "buttress his despicable throne".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007129_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007129-88">[80]</a></sup> Stalin formed a Bolshevik Battle Squad which he used to try to keep Baku's warring ethnic factions apart; he also used the unrest as a cover for stealing printing equipment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007129_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007129-88">[80]</a></sup> Amid the growing violence throughout Georgia he formed further Battle Squads, with the Mensheviks doing the same.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007131–132_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007131–132-89">[81]</a></sup> Stalin's squads disarmed local police and troops,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007132_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007132-90">[82]</a></sup> raided government arsenals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007143_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007143-91">[83]</a></sup> and raised funds through <a href="/wiki/Protection_racket" title="Protection racket">protection rackets</a> on large local businesses and mines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007132–133_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007132–133-92">[84]</a></sup> They launched attacks on the government's <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> troops and pro-Tsarist <a href="/wiki/Black_Hundreds" title="Black Hundreds">Black Hundreds</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196687Montefiore2007135,_144_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196687Montefiore2007135,_144-93">[85]</a></sup> co-ordinating some of their operations with the Menshevik militia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007137_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007137-94">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1905, the Georgian Bolsheviks elected Stalin as one of their delegates to a Bolshevik conference in Saint Petersburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196689–90Service200460Montefiore2007145_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196689–90Service200460Montefiore2007145-95">[87]</a></sup> On arrival, he met Lenin's wife <a href="/wiki/Nadezhda_Krupskaya" title="Nadezhda Krupskaya">Nadezhda Krupskaya</a>, who informed him that the venue had been moved to <a href="/wiki/Tampere" title="Tampere">Tampere</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Finland" title="Grand Duchy of Finland">Grand Duchy of Finland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007145_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007145-96">[88]</a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/Tampere_conference_of_1905" title="Tampere conference of 1905">the conference</a> Stalin met Lenin for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196690Conquest199137Service200460Kotkin201481_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196690Conquest199137Service200460Kotkin201481-97">[89]</a></sup> Although Stalin held Lenin in deep respect, he was vocal in his disagreement with Lenin's view that the Bolsheviks should field candidates for the <a href="/wiki/1906_Russian_legislative_election" title="1906 Russian legislative election">forthcoming election</a> to the <a href="/wiki/State_Duma_(Russian_Empire)" title="State Duma (Russian Empire)">State Duma</a>; Stalin saw the parliamentary process as a waste of time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196692Montefiore2007147Kotkin2014105_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196692Montefiore2007147Kotkin2014105-98">[90]</a></sup> In April 1906, Stalin attended the <a href="/wiki/4th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="4th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">RSDLP Fourth Congress</a> in <a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>; this was his first trip outside the Russian Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196694Conquest199139–40Service200461,_62Montefiore2007156_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196694Conquest199139–40Service200461,_62Montefiore2007156-99">[91]</a></sup> At the conference, the RSDLP — then led by its Menshevik majority — agreed that it would not raise funds using armed robbery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196696Conquest199140Service200462Khlevniuk201526_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196696Conquest199140Service200462Khlevniuk201526-100">[92]</a></sup> Lenin and Stalin disagreed with this decision<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196696Service200462Kotkin2014113_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196696Service200462Kotkin2014113-101">[93]</a></sup> and later privately discussed how they could continue the robberies for the Bolshevik cause.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007168Kotkin2014113_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007168Kotkin2014113-102">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin married <a href="/wiki/Kato_Svanidze" title="Kato Svanidze">Kato Svanidze</a> in an Orthodox church ceremony at <a href="/wiki/Senaki" title="Senaki">Senaki</a> in July 1906.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200464Montefiore2007159Kotkin2014105_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200464Montefiore2007159Kotkin2014105-103">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[96]</a></sup> In March 1907 she bore a son, <a href="/wiki/Yakov_Dzhugashvili" title="Yakov Dzhugashvili">Yakov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200464Montefiore2007167Kotkin2014106Khlevniuk201525_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200464Montefiore2007167Kotkin2014106Khlevniuk201525-105">[97]</a></sup> By that year — according to the historian <a href="/wiki/Robert_Service_(historian)" title="Robert Service (historian)">Robert Service</a> — Stalin had established himself as "Georgia's leading Bolshevik".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200465_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200465-106">[98]</a></sup> He attended the <a href="/wiki/5th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party" title="5th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party">Fifth RSDLP Congress</a>, held at the <a href="/wiki/Brotherhood_Church" title="Brotherhood Church">Brotherhood Church</a> in London in May–June 1907.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199141Service200465Montefiore2007178–180Kotkin2014108_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199141Service200465Montefiore2007178–180Kotkin2014108-107">[99]</a></sup> After returning to Tiflis, Stalin organised the <a href="/wiki/1907_Tiflis_bank_robbery" title="1907 Tiflis bank robbery">robbing of a large delivery of money to the Imperial Bank</a> in June 1907. His gang ambushed the armed convoy in <a href="/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Tbilisi" title="Freedom Square, Tbilisi">Yerevan Square</a> with gunfire and home-made bombs. Around 40 people were killed, but all of his gang escaped alive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199141–42Service200475Kotkin2014113_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199141–42Service200475Kotkin2014113-108">[100]</a></sup> After the heist, Stalin settled in Baku with his wife and son.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher1966100Montefiore2007180Kotkin2014114_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher1966100Montefiore2007180Kotkin2014114-109">[101]</a></sup> There, Mensheviks confronted Stalin about the robbery and voted to expel him from the RSDLP, but he took no notice of them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher1966100Conquest199143–44Service200476Montefiore2007184_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher1966100Conquest199143–44Service200476Montefiore2007184-110">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="4339" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg/220px-Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg/330px-Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg/440px-Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin%27s_Mug_Shot.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A mugshot of Stalin made in 1911 by the <a href="/wiki/Okhrana" title="Okhrana">Tsarist secret police</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In Baku, Stalin secured Bolshevik domination of the local RSDLP branch<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007190_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007190-111">[103]</a></sup> and edited two Bolshevik newspapers, <i>Bakinsky Proletary</i> and <i>Gudok</i> ("Whistle").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007186_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007186-112">[104]</a></sup> In August 1907, he attended the <a href="/wiki/International_Socialist_Congress,_Stuttgart_1907" title="International Socialist Congress, Stuttgart 1907">Seventh Congress</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Second_International" title="Second International">Second International</a> — an international socialist organisation — in <a href="/wiki/Stuttgart" title="Stuttgart">Stuttgart</a>, Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007189_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007189-113">[105]</a></sup> In November 1907, his wife died of <a href="/wiki/Typhus" title="Typhus">typhus</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007191Kotkin2014115_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007191Kotkin2014115-114">[106]</a></sup> and he left his son with her family in Tiflis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199144Service200471Montefiore2007193Kotkin2014116_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199144Service200471Montefiore2007193Kotkin2014116-115">[107]</a></sup> In Baku he had reassembled his gang, the Outfit,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007194_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007194-116">[108]</a></sup> which continued to attack Black Hundreds and raised finances by running protection rackets, counterfeiting currency, and carrying out robberies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200474Montefiore2007196Kotkin2014115_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200474Montefiore2007196Kotkin2014115-117">[109]</a></sup> They also kidnapped the children of several wealthy figures to extract ransom money.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007197–198Kotkin2014115_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007197–198Kotkin2014115-118">[110]</a></sup> In early 1908, he travelled to the Swiss city of <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a> to meet with Lenin and the prominent Russian Marxist <a href="/wiki/Georgi_Plekhanov" title="Georgi Plekhanov">Georgi Plekhanov</a>, although the latter exasperated him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007195_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007195-119">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 1908, Stalin was arrested and interned in Bailov Prison in Baku.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199144Service200468Montefiore2007203Kotkin2014116_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199144Service200468Montefiore2007203Kotkin2014116-120">[112]</a></sup> There he led the imprisoned Bolsheviks, organised discussion groups, and ordered the killing of suspected informants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199145Montefiore2007203–204_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199145Montefiore2007203–204-121">[113]</a></sup> He was eventually sentenced to two years exile in the village of <a href="/wiki/Solvychegodsk" title="Solvychegodsk">Solvychegodsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vologda_Oblast" title="Vologda Oblast">Vologda Province</a>, arriving there in February 1909.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199145Service200468Montefiore2007206,_208Kotkin2014116_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199145Service200468Montefiore2007206,_208Kotkin2014116-122">[114]</a></sup> In June, he escaped the village and made it to <a href="/wiki/Kotlas" title="Kotlas">Kotlas</a> disguised as a woman and from there to Saint Petersburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199146Montefiore2007212Kotkin2014117_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199146Montefiore2007212Kotkin2014117-123">[115]</a></sup> In March 1910, he was arrested again and sent back to Solvychegodsk.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199146Montefiore2007222,_226Kotkin2014121_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199146Montefiore2007222,_226Kotkin2014121-124">[116]</a></sup> There he had affairs with at least two women; his landlady, Maria Kuzakova, later gave birth to his second son, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_Kuzakov" title="Constantine Kuzakov">Konstantin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200479Montefiore2007227,_229,_230–231Kotkin2014121_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200479Montefiore2007227,_229,_230–231Kotkin2014121-125">[117]</a></sup> In June 1911, Stalin was given permission to move to <a href="/wiki/Vologda" title="Vologda">Vologda</a>, where he stayed for two months,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199147Service200480Montefiore2007231,_234Kotkin2014121_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199147Service200480Montefiore2007231,_234Kotkin2014121-126">[118]</a></sup> having a relationship with Pelageya Onufrieva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200479Montefiore2007234Kotkin2014121_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200479Montefiore2007234Kotkin2014121-127">[119]</a></sup> He escaped to Saint Petersburg,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007236Kotkin2014121_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007236Kotkin2014121-128">[120]</a></sup> where he was arrested in September 1911 and sentenced to a further three-year exile in Vologda.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007237Kotkin2014121–22_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007237Kotkin2014121–22-129">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1912.E2.80.931917:_Rise_to_the_Central_Committee_and_editorship_of_Pravda"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1912–1917:_Rise_to_the_Central_Committee_and_editorship_of_Pravda">1912–1917: Rise to the Central Committee and editorship of <i>Pravda</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg/220px-First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg/330px-First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg/440px-First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:First_Issue_of_PRAVDA.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first issue of <i>Pravda</i>, the Bolshevik newspaper of which Stalin was editor</div></div></div>
<p>In January 1912, while Stalin was in exile, the first <a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Bolshevik Central Committee</a> was elected at the <a href="/wiki/Prague_Conference" title="Prague Conference">Prague Conference</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200483Kotkin2014122–123_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200483Kotkin2014122–123-130">[122]</a></sup> Shortly after the conference, Lenin and <a href="/wiki/Grigory_Zinoviev" title="Grigory Zinoviev">Grigory Zinoviev</a> decided to co-opt Stalin to the committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200483Kotkin2014122–123_130-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200483Kotkin2014122–123-130">[122]</a></sup> Still in Vologda, Stalin agreed, remaining a Central Committee member for the rest of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199148Service200483Montefiore2007240Kotkin2014122–123_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199148Service200483Montefiore2007240Kotkin2014122–123-131">[123]</a></sup> Lenin believed that Stalin, as a Georgian, would help secure support for the Bolsheviks from the empire's minority ethnicities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007240_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007240-132">[124]</a></sup> In February 1912, Stalin again escaped to Saint Petersburg,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007241_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007241-133">[125]</a></sup> tasked with converting the Bolshevik weekly newspaper, <i>Zvezda</i> ("Star") into a daily, <i><a href="/wiki/Pravda" title="Pravda">Pravda</a></i> ("Truth").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007243_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007243-134">[126]</a></sup> The new newspaper was launched in April 1912,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007247_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007247-135">[127]</a></sup> although Stalin's role as editor was kept secret.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007247_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200484Montefiore2007247-135">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1912, he was arrested again and imprisoned in the Shpalerhy Prison, before being sentenced to three years exile in Siberia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199151Montefiore2007248_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199151Montefiore2007248-136">[128]</a></sup> In July, he arrived at the Siberian village of <a href="/wiki/Narym" title="Narym">Narym</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007249Kotkin2014133_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007249Kotkin2014133-137">[129]</a></sup> where he shared a room with a fellow Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Yakov_Sverdlov" title="Yakov Sverdlov">Yakov Sverdlov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200486Montefiore2007250Kotkin2014154_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200486Montefiore2007250Kotkin2014154-138">[130]</a></sup> After two months, Stalin and Sverdlov escaped back to Saint Petersburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199151Service200486–87Montefiore2007250–251_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199151Service200486–87Montefiore2007250–251-139">[131]</a></sup>
During a brief period back in Tiflis, Stalin and the Outfit planned the ambush of a mail coach, during which most of the group — although not Stalin — were apprehended by the authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007252–253_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007252–253-140">[132]</a></sup> Stalin returned to Saint Petersburg, where he continued editing and writing articles for <i>Pravda</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007255_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007255-141">[133]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="952" data-file-width="714" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg/170px-Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg/255px-Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg/340px-Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_in_exile_1915.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin in 1915</div></div></div>
<p>After the <a href="/wiki/1912_Russian_legislative_election" title="1912 Russian legislative election">October 1912 Duma elections</a>, where six Bolsheviks and six Mensheviks were elected, Stalin wrote articles calling for reconciliation between the two Marxist factions, for which Lenin criticised him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007256_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007256-142">[134]</a></sup> In late 1912, Stalin twice crossed into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> to visit Lenin in <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199152Service200487–88Montefiore2007256–259Kotkin2014133_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199152Service200487–88Montefiore2007256–259Kotkin2014133-143">[135]</a></sup> eventually bowing to Lenin's opposition to reunification with the Mensheviks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007263_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007263-144">[136]</a></sup> In January 1913, Stalin travelled to <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199154Service200489Montefiore2007263_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199154Service200489Montefiore2007263-145">[137]</a></sup> where he researched the 'national question' of how the Bolsheviks should deal with the Russian Empire's national and ethnic minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200489Montefiore2007264–265_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200489Montefiore2007264–265-146">[138]</a></sup> Lenin, who encouraged Stalin to write an article on the subject,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200459_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200459-147">[139]</a></sup> wanted to attract those groups to the Bolshevik cause by offering them the right of secession from the Russian state, but also hoped they would remain part of a future Bolshevik-governed Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007266_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007266-148">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin's article <i><a href="/wiki/Marxism_and_the_National_Question" title="Marxism and the National Question">Marxism and the National Question</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199153Service200485Montefiore2007266Kotkin2014133_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199153Service200485Montefiore2007266Kotkin2014133-149">[141]</a></sup> was first published in the March, April, and May 1913 issues of the Bolshevik journal <i><a href="/wiki/Prosveshcheniye" title="Prosveshcheniye">Prosveshcheniye</a></i>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014133_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014133-150">[142]</a></sup> Lenin was pleased with it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267-151">[143]</a></sup> According to Montefiore, this was "Stalin's most famous work".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007266_148-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007266-148">[140]</a></sup> The article was published under the pseudonym "K. Stalin",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267-151">[143]</a></sup> a name he had used since 1912.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Volkogonov19917Service200485_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Volkogonov19917Service200485-152">[144]</a></sup> Derived from the Russian word for steel (<i>stal</i>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Service200485_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Service200485-153">[145]</a></sup> this has been translated as "Man of Steel";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Volkogonov19917Montefiore2007268Kotkin2014133_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269Volkogonov19917Montefiore2007268Kotkin2014133-154">[146]</a></sup> Stalin may have intended it to imitate Lenin's pseudonym.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269-155">[147]</a></sup> Stalin retained the name for the rest of his life, possibly because it was used on the article that established his reputation among the Bolsheviks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267–268_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007267–268-156">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 1913, Stalin was arrested while back in Saint Petersburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007268–270Khlevniuk201528_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007268–270Khlevniuk201528-157">[149]</a></sup> He was sentenced to four years exile in <a href="/wiki/Turukhansk" title="Turukhansk">Turukhansk</a>, a remote part of Siberia from which escape was particularly difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199154Service2004102–103Montefiore2007270,_273Khlevniuk201529_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199154Service2004102–103Montefiore2007270,_273Khlevniuk201529-158">[150]</a></sup> In August, he arrived in the village of Monastyrskoe, although after four weeks was relocated to the hamlet of Kostino.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007273–274_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007273–274-159">[151]</a></sup> In March 1914, concerned over a potential escape attempt, the authorities moved Stalin to the hamlet of <a href="/wiki/Kureika_(village)" title="Kureika (village)">Kureika</a> on the edge of the <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Circle" title="Arctic Circle">Arctic Circle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199155Service2004105–106Montefiore2007277–278Khlevniuk201529_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199155Service2004105–106Montefiore2007277–278Khlevniuk201529-160">[152]</a></sup> In the hamlet, Stalin had a relationship with Lidia Pereprygina, who was fourteen at the time but within the legal <a href="/wiki/Age_of_consent" title="Age of consent">age of consent</a> in Tsarist Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuny2020559Khlevniuk201530_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuny2020559Khlevniuk201530-161">[153]</a></sup> In or about December 1914, their child was born but the infant soon died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007292–293_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007292–293-162">[154]</a></sup> Their second child, Alexander, was born circa April 1917.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007298,_300_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007298,_300-163">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Siberian_Times'',_6_April_2016_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Siberian_Times'',_6_April_2016-164">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Kureika, Stalin lived closely with the <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Siberia" title="Indigenous peoples of Siberia">indigenous</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tunguses" title="Tunguses">Tunguses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ostyak" title="Ostyak">Ostyak</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007287_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007287-165">[157]</a></sup> and spent much of his time fishing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199156Service2004110Montefiore2007288–289_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199156Service2004110Montefiore2007288–289-166">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1917:_Russian_Revolution">1917: Russian Revolution</span></h3>
<p>While Stalin was in exile, Russia entered the <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">First World War</a>, and in October 1916 Stalin and other exiled Bolsheviks were <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_the_Russian_Empire" title="Conscription in the Russian Empire">conscripted into the Russian Army</a>, leaving for Monastyrskoe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199157Service2004113–114Montefiore2007300Kotkin2014155_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199157Service2004113–114Montefiore2007300Kotkin2014155-167">[159]</a></sup> They arrived in <a href="/wiki/Krasnoyarsk" title="Krasnoyarsk">Krasnoyarsk</a> in February 1917,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199157Montefiore2007301–302Kotkin2014155_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199157Montefiore2007301–302Kotkin2014155-168">[160]</a></sup> where a medical examiner ruled Stalin unfit for military service because of his crippled arm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004114Montefiore2007302Kotkin2014155_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004114Montefiore2007302Kotkin2014155-169">[161]</a></sup> Stalin was required to serve four more months on his exile, and he successfully requested that he serve it in nearby <a href="/wiki/Achinsk" title="Achinsk">Achinsk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004114Montefiore2007302_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004114Montefiore2007302-170">[162]</a></sup> Stalin was in the city when the <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a> took place; uprisings broke out in Petrograd — as Saint Petersburg had been renamed — and Tsar Nicholas II abdicated to escape being violently overthrown. The Russian Empire became a <i>de facto</i> republic, headed by a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a> dominated by liberals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199157–58Service2004116–117Montefiore2007302–303Kotkin2014178Khlevniuk201542_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199157–58Service2004116–117Montefiore2007302–303Kotkin2014178Khlevniuk201542-171">[163]</a></sup> In a celebratory mood, Stalin travelled by train to Petrograd in March.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199115,_19Service2004117Montefiore2007304Kotkin2014173_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199115,_19Service2004117Montefiore2007304Kotkin2014173-172">[164]</a></sup> There, Stalin and a fellow Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kamenev" title="Lev Kamenev">Lev Kamenev</a> assumed control of <i>Pravda</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199119Service2004120Montefiore2007310_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199119Service2004120Montefiore2007310-173">[165]</a></sup> and Stalin was appointed the Bolshevik representative to the Executive Committee of the <a href="/wiki/Petrograd_Soviet" title="Petrograd Soviet">Petrograd Soviet</a>, an influential council of the city's workers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199159–60Montefiore2007310_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199159–60Montefiore2007310-174">[166]</a></sup> In April, Stalin came third in the Bolshevik elections for the party's Central Committee; Lenin came first and Zinoviev came second.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199164Service2004131Montefiore2007316Kotkin2014193Khlevniuk201546_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199164Service2004131Montefiore2007316Kotkin2014193Khlevniuk201546-175">[167]</a></sup> This reflected his senior standing in the party at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007316_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007316-176">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1062260506">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>The existing government of landlords and capitalists must be replaced by a new government, a government of workers and peasants.<br/>The existing pseudo-government which was not elected by the people and which is not accountable to the people must be replaced by a government recognised by the people, elected by representatives of the workers, soldiers and peasants and held accountable to their representatives.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Stalin's editorial in <i>Pravda</i>, October 1917<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004144_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004144-177">[169]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
