<p>Stalin helped organise the <a href="/wiki/July_Days" title="July Days">July Days</a> uprising, an armed display of strength by Bolshevik supporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199165Montefiore2007319–320_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199165Montefiore2007319–320-178">[170]</a></sup> After the demonstration was suppressed, the Provisional Government initiated a crackdown on the Bolsheviks, raiding <i>Pravda</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200732_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200732-179">[171]</a></sup> During this raid, Stalin smuggled Lenin out of the newspaper's office and took charge of the Bolshevik leader's safety, moving him between Petrograd safe houses before smuggling him to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Razliv" title="Razliv">Razliv</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007322–324Kotkin2014203Khlevniuk201548–49_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007322–324Kotkin2014203Khlevniuk201548–49-180">[172]</a></sup> In Lenin's absence, Stalin continued editing <i>Pravda</i> and served as acting leader of the Bolsheviks, overseeing the party's <a href="/wiki/6th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Social_Democratic_Labour_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)">Sixth Congress</a>, which was held covertly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007326Kotkin2014204_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007326Kotkin2014204-181">[173]</a></sup> Lenin began calling for the Bolsheviks to seize power by toppling the Provisional Government in a <i><a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a></i>. Stalin and a fellow senior Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a> both endorsed Lenin's plan of action, but it was initially opposed by Kamenev and other party members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199168Service2004138_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199168Service2004138-182">[174]</a></sup> Lenin returned to Petrograd and secured a majority in favour of a <i>coup</i> at a meeting of the Central Committee on 10 October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007332–333,_335_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007332–333,_335-183">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 24 October, police raided the Bolshevik newspaper offices, smashing machinery and presses; Stalin salvaged some of this equipment to continue his activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004144Montefiore2007337–338_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004144Montefiore2007337–338-184">[176]</a></sup> In the early hours of 25 October, Stalin joined Lenin in a Central Committee meeting in the <a href="/wiki/Smolny_Institute" title="Smolny Institute">Smolny Institute</a>, from where the Bolshevik <i>coup</i> — the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a> — was directed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004145Montefiore2007341_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004145Montefiore2007341-185">[177]</a></sup> Bolshevik militia seized Petrograd's electric power station, main post office, state bank, telephone exchange, and several bridges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007341–342_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007341–342-186">[178]</a></sup> A Bolshevik-controlled ship, the <i><a href="/wiki/Russian_cruiser_Aurora" title="Russian cruiser Aurora">Aurora</a></i>, opened fire on the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Palace" title="Winter Palace">Winter Palace</a>; the Provisional Government's assembled delegates surrendered and were arrested by the Bolsheviks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007344–346_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007344–346-187">[179]</a></sup> Although he had been tasked with briefing the Bolshevik delegates of the <a href="/wiki/All-Russian_Congress_of_Soviets#Second_Congress" title="All-Russian Congress of Soviets">Second Congress of Soviets</a> about the developing situation, Stalin's role in the coup had not been publicly visible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004145,_147_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004145,_147-188">[180]</a></sup> Trotsky and other later Bolshevik opponents of Stalin used this as evidence that his role in the coup had been insignificant, although later historians reject this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004144–146Kotkin2014224Khlevniuk201552_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004144–146Kotkin2014224Khlevniuk201552-189">[181]</a></sup> According to the historian <a href="/wiki/Oleg_Khlevniuk" title="Oleg Khlevniuk">Oleg Khlevniuk</a>, Stalin "filled an important role [in the October Revolution]... as a senior Bolshevik, member of the party's Central Committee, and editor of its main newspaper";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201553_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201553-190">[182]</a></sup> the historian <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Kotkin" title="Stephen Kotkin">Stephen Kotkin</a> similarly noted that Stalin had been "in the thick of events" in the build-up to the coup.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014177_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014177-191">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="In_Lenin.27s_government"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Lenin's_government">In Lenin's government</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin_during_the_Russian_Revolution,_Civil_War,_and_the_Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="Joseph Stalin during the Russian Revolution, Civil War, and the Polish–Soviet War">Joseph Stalin during the Russian Revolution, Civil War, and the Polish–Soviet War</a></div>
<h3><span id="1917.E2.80.931918:_Consolidating_power"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1917–1918:_Consolidating_power">1917–1918: Consolidating power</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="275" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg/220px-Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg/330px-Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg/440px-Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1917-1.1A.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Joseph Stalin in 1917 as a young People's Commissar.</div></div></div>
<p>On 26 October 1917, Lenin declared himself chairman of a new government, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_People%27s_Commissars" title="Council of People's Commissars">Council of People's Commissars</a> ("Sovnarkom").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004147–148Kotkin2014227–228,_229Khlevniuk201552_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004147–148Kotkin2014227–228,_229Khlevniuk201552-192">[184]</a></sup> Stalin backed Lenin's decision not to form a coalition with the Mensheviks and <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Revolutionary_Party" title="Socialist Revolutionary Party">Socialist Revolutionary Party</a>, although they did form a coalition government with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Left_Socialist_Revolutionaries" title="Left Socialist Revolutionaries">Left Socialist Revolutionaries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199128–29Service2004148_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199128–29Service2004148-193">[185]</a></sup> Stalin became part of an informal foursome leading the government, alongside Lenin, Trotsky, and Sverdlov;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Kotkin2014228_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Kotkin2014228-194">[186]</a></sup> of these, Sverdlov was regularly absent and died in March 1919.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171,_90Kotkin2014318_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171,_90Kotkin2014318-195">[187]</a></sup> Stalin's office was based near to Lenin's in the <a href="/wiki/Smolny_Institute" title="Smolny Institute">Smolny Institute</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Kotkin2014229_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Kotkin2014229-196">[188]</a></sup> and he and Trotsky were the only individuals allowed access to Lenin's study without an appointment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200327Kotkin2014226_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200327Kotkin2014226-197">[189]</a></sup> Although not so publicly well known as Lenin or Trotsky,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004150_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004150-198">[190]</a></sup> Stalin's importance among the Bolsheviks grew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003157_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003157-199">[191]</a></sup> He co-signed Lenin's decrees shutting down hostile newspapers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004149_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004149-200">[192]</a></sup> and along with Sverdlov, he chaired the sessions of the committee drafting <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Russia_Constitution_of_1918" title="Soviet Russia Constitution of 1918">a constitution</a> for the new <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004155_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004155-201">[193]</a></sup> He strongly supported Lenin's formation of the <a href="/wiki/Cheka" title="Cheka">Cheka</a> security service and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror" title="Red Terror">Red Terror</a> that it initiated; noting that state violence had proved an effective tool for capitalist powers, he believed that it would prove the same for the Soviet government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004158_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004158-202">[194]</a></sup> Unlike senior Bolsheviks like Kamenev and <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Bukharin" title="Nikolai Bukharin">Nikolai Bukharin</a>, Stalin never expressed concern about the rapid growth and expansion of the Cheka and Red Terror.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004158_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004158-202">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG/220px-Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG/330px-Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG/440px-Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Moscow_Kremlin_and_Bolshoy_Kamenny_Bridge_late_evening_01.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Moscow Kremlin, which Stalin moved into in 1918</div></div></div>
<p>Having dropped his editorship of <i>Pravda</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004148_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004148-203">[195]</a></sup> Stalin was appointed the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Commissariat" title="People's Commissariat">People's Commissar</a> for Nationalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199170Volkogonov199130Service2004148Kotkin2014228Khlevniuk201552_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199170Volkogonov199130Service2004148Kotkin2014228Khlevniuk201552-204">[196]</a></sup> He took <a href="/wiki/Nadezhda_Alliluyeva" title="Nadezhda Alliluyeva">Nadezhda Alliluyeva</a> as his secretary<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004151_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004151-205">[197]</a></sup> and at some point married her, although the wedding date is unknown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004167Kotkin2014264Khlevniuk201549_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004167Kotkin2014264Khlevniuk201549-206">[198]</a></sup> In November 1917, he signed the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Rights_of_the_Peoples_of_Russia" title="Declaration of the Rights of the Peoples of Russia">Decree on Nationality</a>, according ethnic and national minorities living in Russia the right of secession and self-determination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171-207">[199]</a></sup> The decree's purpose was primarily strategic; the Bolsheviks wanted to gain favour among ethnic minorities but hoped that the latter would not actually desire independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Service2004152_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Service2004152-208">[200]</a></sup> That month, he travelled to <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">Helsinki</a> to talk with the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Finland" title="Social Democratic Party of Finland">Finnish Social-Democrats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Finland" title="Independence of Finland">granting Finland's request for independence in December</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Service2004152_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199171Service2004152-208">[200]</a></sup> His department allocated funds for establishment of presses and schools in the languages of various ethnic minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004153_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004153-209">[201]</a></sup> Socialist revolutionaries accused Stalin's talk of <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federalism</a> and national self-determination as a front for Sovnarkom's centralising and <a href="/wiki/Imperialism" title="Imperialism">imperialist</a> policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004155_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004155-201">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of the ongoing First World War, in which Russia was fighting the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> of <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, Lenin's government relocated from Petrograd to Moscow in March 1918. Stalin, Trotsky, Sverdlov, and Lenin lived at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" title="Moscow Kremlin">Kremlin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004150–151Kotkin2014259–264_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199172Service2004150–151Kotkin2014259–264-210">[202]</a></sup> Stalin supported Lenin's desire to sign an armistice with the Central Powers regardless of the cost in territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199175Service2004158–161Kotkin2014250_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199175Service2004158–161Kotkin2014250-211">[203]</a></sup> Stalin thought it necessary because — unlike Lenin — he was unconvinced that Europe was on the verge of <a href="/wiki/Proletarian_revolution" title="Proletarian revolution">proletarian revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004159–160Kotkin2014250_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004159–160Kotkin2014250-212">[204]</a></sup> Lenin eventually convinced the other senior Bolsheviks of his viewpoint, resulting in signing of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk_(Russia%E2%80%93Central_Powers)" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (Russia–Central Powers)">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> in March 1918.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199175Service2004161Kotkin2014257–258_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199175Service2004161Kotkin2014257–258-213">[205]</a></sup> The treaty gave vast areas of land and resources to the Central Powers and angered many in Russia; the Left Socialist Revolutionaries withdrew from the coalition government over the issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004161Kotkin2014258–259,_265_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004161Kotkin2014258–259,_265-214">[206]</a></sup> The governing RSDLP party was soon renamed, becoming the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Russian Communist Party</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014259_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014259-215">[207]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1918.E2.80.931921:_Military_Command"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1918–1921:_Military_Command">1918–1921: Military Command</span></h3>
<p>After the Bolsheviks seized power, both right and left-wing armies rallied against them, generating the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004165Kotkin2014268–270_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004165Kotkin2014268–270-216">[208]</a></sup> To secure access to the dwindling food supply, in May 1918 Sovnarkom sent Stalin to <a href="/wiki/Volgograd" title="Volgograd">Tsaritsyn</a> to take charge of food procurement in southern Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199177Volkogonov199139Montefiore200327Service2004163Kotkin2014300–301Khlevniuk201554_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199177Volkogonov199139Montefiore200327Service2004163Kotkin2014300–301Khlevniuk201554-217">[209]</a></sup> Eager to prove himself as a commander,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004173_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004173-218">[210]</a></sup> once there he took control of regional military operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004164Kotkin2014302–303_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004164Kotkin2014302–303-219">[211]</a></sup> He befriended two military figures, <a href="/wiki/Kliment_Voroshilov" title="Kliment Voroshilov">Kliment Voroshilov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Semyon_Budyonny" title="Semyon Budyonny">Semyon Budyonny</a>, who would form the nucleus of his military and political support base.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199178,_82Montefiore200728Khlevniuk201555_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199178,_82Montefiore200728Khlevniuk201555-220">[212]</a></sup> Believing that victory was assured by numerical superiority, he sent large numbers of <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> troops into battle against the region's anti-Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">White armies</a>, resulting in heavy losses; Lenin was concerned by this costly tactic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199181Service2004170_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199181Service2004170-221">[213]</a></sup> In Tsaritsyn, Stalin commanded the local Cheka branch to execute suspected counter-revolutionaries, sometimes without trial<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199146Montefiore200727Kotkin2014305,_307Khlevniuk201556–57_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199146Montefiore200727Kotkin2014305,_307Khlevniuk201556–57-222">[214]</a></sup> and — in contravention of government orders — purged the military and food collection agencies of middle-class specialists, some of whom he also executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199178–79Volkogonov199140Service2004166Khlevniuk201555_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199178–79Volkogonov199140Service2004166Khlevniuk201555-223">[215]</a></sup> His use of state violence and terror was at a greater scale than most Bolshevik leaders approved of;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004171_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004171-224">[216]</a></sup> for instance, he ordered several villages to be torched to ensure compliance with his food procurement program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004169_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004169-225">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 1918, Stalin was sent to <a href="/wiki/Perm,_Russia" title="Perm, Russia">Perm</a> to lead an inquiry into how <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Kolchak" title="Alexander Kolchak">Alexander Kolchak</a>'s White forces had been able to decimate Red troops based there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199183–84Service2004172Kotkin2014314_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199183–84Service2004172Kotkin2014314-226">[218]</a></sup> He returned to Moscow between January and March 1919,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004172_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004172-227">[219]</a></sup> before being assigned to the Western Front at Petrograd.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199185Service2004172_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199185Service2004172-228">[220]</a></sup> When the Red Third Regiment defected, he ordered the public execution of captured defectors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004172_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004172-227">[219]</a></sup> In September he was returned to the Southern Front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004172_227-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004172-227">[219]</a></sup> During the war, he proved his worth to the Central Committee, displaying decisiveness, determination, and willingness to take on responsibility in conflict situations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004173_218-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004173-218">[210]</a></sup> At the same time, he disregarded orders and repeatedly threatened to resign when affronted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004173,_174_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004173,_174-229">[221]</a></sup> He was reprimanded by Lenin at the <a href="/wiki/8th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">8th Party Congress</a> for employing tactics which resulted in far too many deaths of Red Army soldiers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004185_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004185-230">[222]</a></sup> In November 1919, the government nonetheless awarded him the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Red_Banner" title="Order of the Red Banner">Order of the Red Banner</a> for his wartime service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199186Volkogonov199145Kotkin2014331_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199186Volkogonov199145Kotkin2014331-231">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Bolsheviks won the Russian civil war by the end of 1919.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004175_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004175-232">[224]</a></sup> By that time, Sovnarkom had turned its attention to spreading proletarian revolution abroad, to this end forming the <a href="/wiki/Communist_International" title="Communist International">Communist International</a> in March 1919; Stalin attended its inaugural ceremony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199191Service2004175_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199191Service2004175-233">[225]</a></sup> Although Stalin did not share Lenin's belief that Europe's proletariat were on the verge of revolution, he acknowledged that as long as it stood alone, Soviet Russia remained vulnerable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004176_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004176-234">[226]</a></sup> In December 1918, he drew up decrees recognising Marxist-governed Soviet republics in <a href="/wiki/Commune_of_the_Working_People_of_Estonia" title="Commune of the Working People of Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic_(1918%E2%80%9319)" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1918–19)">Lithuania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Latvian_Socialist_Soviet_Republic" title="Latvian Socialist Soviet Republic">Latvia</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004199_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004199-235">[227]</a></sup> during the civil war these Marxist governments were overthrown and the Baltic countries became fully independent of Russia, an act Stalin regarded as illegitimate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004203,_190_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004203,_190-236">[228]</a></sup> In February 1920, he was appointed to head the <a href="/wiki/Rabkrin" title="Rabkrin">Workers' and Peasants' Inspectorate</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004174_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004174-237">[229]</a></sup> that same month he was also transferred to the Caucasian Front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004178_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004178-238">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1920-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1986" data-file-width="1555" decoding="async" height="281" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_1920-1.jpg/220px-Stalin_1920-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_1920-1.jpg/330px-Stalin_1920-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_1920-1.jpg/440px-Stalin_1920-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1920-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Joseph Stalin in 1920.</div></div></div>
<p>Following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_westward_offensive_of_1918%E2%80%9319" title="Soviet westward offensive of 1918–19">earlier clashes</a> between Polish and Russian troops, the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="Polish–Soviet War">Polish–Soviet War</a> broke out in early 1920, with the Poles invading Ukraine and taking <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> on 7 May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004176Kotkin2014352–354_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004176Kotkin2014352–354-239">[231]</a></sup> On 26 May, Stalin was moved to Ukraine, on the Southwest Front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004178Kotkin2014357Khlevniuk201559_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004178Kotkin2014357Khlevniuk201559-240">[232]</a></sup> The Red Army retook Kyiv on 10 June and soon forced the Polish troops back into Poland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004176–177_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004176–177-241">[233]</a></sup> On 16 July, the Central Committee decided to take the war into Polish territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004177_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004177-242">[234]</a></sup> Lenin believed that the Polish proletariat would rise up to support the Russians against <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski" title="Józef Piłsudski">Józef Piłsudski</a>'s Polish government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004177_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004177-242">[234]</a></sup> Stalin had cautioned against this; he believed that <a href="/wiki/Polish_nationalism" title="Polish nationalism">nationalism</a> would lead the Polish working-classes to support their government's war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004177_242-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004177-242">[234]</a></sup> He also believed that the Red Army was ill-prepared to conduct an offensive war and that it would give White Armies a chance to resurface in <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, potentially reigniting the civil war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004177_242-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004177-242">[234]</a></sup> Stalin lost the argument, after which he accepted Lenin's decision and supported it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004178_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004178-238">[230]</a></sup> Along the Southwest Front, he became determined to conquer <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>; in focusing on this goal he disobeyed orders in early August to transfer his troops to assist <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Tukhachevsky" title="Mikhail Tukhachevsky">Mikhail Tukhachevsky</a>'s forces that were attacking Warsaw.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199187Service2004179Kotkin2014362Khlevniuk201560_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199187Service2004179Kotkin2014362Khlevniuk201560-243">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>In mid-August 1920, the Poles <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_(1920)" title="Battle of Warsaw (1920)">repulsed the Russian advance</a>, and Stalin returned to Moscow to attend the Politburo meeting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004180,_182Kotkin2014364_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004180,_182Kotkin2014364-244">[236]</a></sup> In Moscow, Lenin and Trotsky blamed him for his behaviour in the Polish–Soviet war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004182_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004182-245">[237]</a></sup> Stalin felt humiliated and under-appreciated; on 17 August, he demanded demission from the military, which was granted on 1 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004182Kotkin2014364–365_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004182Kotkin2014364–365-246">[238]</a></sup> At the 9th Bolshevik Conference in late September, Trotsky accused Stalin of "strategic mistakes" in his handling of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavies2003211Service2004183–185Kotkin2014376–377_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies2003211Service2004183–185Kotkin2014376–377-247">[239]</a></sup> Trotsky claimed that Stalin sabotaged the campaign by disobeying troop transfer orders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014377_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014377-248">[240]</a></sup> Lenin joined Trotsky in criticising him, and nobody spoke on his behalf at the conference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004184–185Kotkin2014377_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004184–185Kotkin2014377-249">[241]</a></sup> Stalin felt disgraced and increased his antipathy toward Trotsky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004185_230-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004185-230">[222]</a></sup> The Polish-Soviet War ended on 18 March 1921, when <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Riga" title="Peace of Riga">a peace treaty</a> was signed in <a href="/wiki/Riga" title="Riga">Riga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014392_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014392-250">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1921.E2.80.931923:_Lenin.27s_final_years"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1921–1923:_Lenin's_final_years">1921–1923: Lenin's final years</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1921-1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1099" data-file-width="1479" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Stalin_1921-1.jpg/220px-Stalin_1921-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Stalin_1921-1.jpg/330px-Stalin_1921-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Stalin_1921-1.jpg/440px-Stalin_1921-1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_1921-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin wearing an <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Red_Banner" title="Order of the Red Banner">Order of the Red Banner</a>. According to info published in Pravda (Pravda. 24 December 1939. No: 354 (8039)), this photograph was taken in <a href="/wiki/Sergo_Ordzhonikidze" title="Sergo Ordzhonikidze">Ordzhonikidze</a>'s house in 1921.</div></div></div>
<p>The Soviet government sought to bring neighbouring states under its domination; <a href="/wiki/Red_Army_invasion_of_Georgia" title="Red Army invasion of Georgia">in February 1921 it invaded</a> the Menshevik-governed <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Georgia" title="Democratic Republic of Georgia">Georgia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014396–397_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014396–397-251">[243]</a></sup> while in April 1921, Stalin ordered the Red Army into <a href="/wiki/Turkestan_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Turkestan Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic">Turkestan</a> to reassert Russian state control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014388_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014388-252">[244]</a></sup> As People's Commissar for Nationalities, Stalin believed that each national and ethnic group should have the right to self-expression,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004202_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004202-253">[245]</a></sup> facilitated through "<a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republics" title="Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republics">autonomous republics</a>" within the Russian state in which they could oversee various regional affairs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004199–200Kotkin2014371_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004199–200Kotkin2014371-254">[246]</a></sup> In taking this view, some Marxists accused him of bending too much to <a href="/wiki/Bourgeois_nationalism" title="Bourgeois nationalism">bourgeois nationalism</a>, while others accused him of remaining too Russocentric by seeking to retain these nations within the Russian state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004202_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004202-253">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin's native Caucasus posed a particular problem because of its highly multi-ethnic mix.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004200_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004200-255">[247]</a></sup> Stalin opposed the idea of separate Georgian, Armenian, and Azerbaijani autonomous republics, arguing that these would likely oppress ethnic minorities within their respective territories; instead he called for a <a href="/wiki/Transcaucasian_Socialist_Federative_Soviet_Republic" title="Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic">Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004194–196Kotkin2014400_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004194–196Kotkin2014400-256">[248]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Georgia_(Soviet_Union)" title="Communist Party of Georgia (Soviet Union)">Georgian Communist Party</a> opposed the idea, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Georgian_affair" title="Georgian affair">Georgian affair</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004194–195Kotkin2014479–481_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004194–195Kotkin2014479–481-257">[249]</a></sup> In mid-1921, Stalin returned to the southern Caucasus, there calling on Georgian Communists to avoid the chauvinistic Georgian nationalism which marginalised the <a href="/wiki/Abkhazians" title="Abkhazians">Abkhazian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ossetian_people" title="Ossetian people">Ossetian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Adjarians" title="Adjarians">Adjarian</a> minorities in Georgia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004203–205Kotkin2014400_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004203–205Kotkin2014400-258">[250]</a></sup> On this trip, Stalin met with his son Yakov, and brought him back to Moscow;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004232_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004232-259">[251]</a></sup> Nadezhda had given birth to another of Stalin's sons, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Stalin" title="Vasily Stalin">Vasily</a>, in March 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004232_259-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004232-259">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the civil war, workers' strikes and peasant uprisings broke out across Russia, largely in opposition to Sovnarkom's food requisitioning project; as an antidote, Lenin introduced market-oriented reforms: the <a href="/wiki/New_Economic_Policy" title="New Economic Policy">New Economic Policy</a> (NEP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199189Service2004187Kotkin2014344Khlevniuk201564_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199189Service2004187Kotkin2014344Khlevniuk201564-260">[252]</a></sup> There was also internal turmoil in the Communist Party, as Trotsky led a faction calling for abolition of trade unions; Lenin opposed this, and Stalin helped rally opposition to Trotsky's position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004186_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004186-261">[253]</a></sup> Stalin also agreed to supervise the Department of Agitation and Propaganda in the Central Committee Secretariat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004188_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004188-262">[254]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/11th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="11th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">11th Party Congress</a> in 1922, Lenin nominated Stalin as the party's new <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">General Secretary</a>. Although concerns were expressed that adopting this new post on top of his others would overstretch his workload and give him too much power, Stalin was appointed to the position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199196Volkogonov199178–70Service2004189–190Kotkin2014411_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199196Volkogonov199178–70Service2004189–190Kotkin2014411-263">[255]</a></sup> For Lenin, it was advantageous to have a key ally in this crucial post.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004190_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004190-264">[256]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1062260506" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>Stalin is too crude, and this defect which is entirely acceptable in our milieu and in relationships among us as communists, becomes unacceptable in the position of General Secretary. I therefore propose to comrades that they should devise a means of removing him from this job and should appoint to this job someone else who is distinguished from comrade Stalin in all other respects only by the single superior aspect that he should be more tolerant, more polite and more attentive towards comrades, less capricious, etc.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Lenin's Testament, 4 January 1923;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2000369Service2004209Kotkin2014504_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2000369Service2004209Kotkin2014504-265">[257]</a></sup> this was possibly composed by Krupskaya rather than Lenin himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014501_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014501-266">[258]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="904" data-file-width="788" decoding="async" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg/220px-Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg/330px-Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg/440px-Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lenin_and_stalin_crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin (right) confers with an ailing Lenin at Gorki in September 1922</div></div></div>
<p>In May 1922, a massive stroke left Lenin partially paralysed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199197Volkogonov199153Service2004191_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199197Volkogonov199153Service2004191-267">[259]</a></sup> Residing at his <a href="/wiki/Gorki_Leninskiye" title="Gorki Leninskiye">Gorki dacha</a>, Lenin's main connection to Sovnarkom was through Stalin, who was a regular visitor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004191–192Kotkin2014413_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004191–192Kotkin2014413-268">[260]</a></sup> Lenin twice asked Stalin to procure poison so that he could commit suicide, but Stalin never did so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004192Kotkin2014414Khlevniuk201568_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004192Kotkin2014414Khlevniuk201568-269">[261]</a></sup> Despite this comradeship, Lenin disliked what he referred to as Stalin's "Asiatic" manner and told his sister <a href="/wiki/Maria_Ilyinichna_Ulyanova" title="Maria Ilyinichna Ulyanova">Maria</a> that Stalin was "not intelligent".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991102Service2004191–192Kotkin2014528_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991102Service2004191–192Kotkin2014528-270">[262]</a></sup> Lenin and Stalin argued on the issue of foreign trade; Lenin believed that the Soviet state should have a monopoly on foreign trade, but Stalin supported <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grigori_Sokolnikov" title="Grigori Sokolnikov">Grigori Sokolnikov</a>'s view that doing so was impractical at that stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199198Service2004193Kotkin2014483Khlevniuk201569–70_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199198Service2004193Kotkin2014483Khlevniuk201569–70-271">[263]</a></sup> Another disagreement came over the Georgian affair, with Lenin backing the Georgian Central Committee's desire for a Georgian Soviet Republic over Stalin's idea of a Transcaucasian one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199195Service2004195Khlevniuk201571–72_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199195Service2004195Khlevniuk201571–72-272">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>They also disagreed on the nature of the Soviet state. Lenin called for establishment of a new federation named the "Union of Soviet Republics of Europe and Asia", reflecting his desire for expansion across the two continents and insisted that the Russian state should join this union on equal terms with the other Soviet states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004195_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004195-273">[265]</a></sup> Stalin believed this would encourage independence sentiment among non-Russians, instead arguing that ethnic minorities would be content as "autonomous republics" within the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199171Service2004194Kotkin2014475–476Khlevniuk201568–69_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199171Service2004194Kotkin2014475–476Khlevniuk201568–69-274">[266]</a></sup> Lenin accused Stalin of "Great Russian chauvinism"; Stalin accused Lenin of "national liberalism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199198–99Service2004195Kotkin2014477,_478Khlevniuk201569_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199198–99Service2004195Kotkin2014477,_478Khlevniuk201569-275">[267]</a></sup> A compromise was reached, in which the federation would be renamed the "Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" (USSR).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004195_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004195-273">[265]</a></sup> The USSR's formation was ratified in December 1922; although officially a federal system, all major decisions were taken by the governing <a href="/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> in Moscow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199174Service2004206Kotkin2014485_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199174Service2004206Kotkin2014485-276">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>Their differences also became personal; Lenin was particularly angered when Stalin was rude to his wife Krupskaya during a telephone conversation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199199–100,_103Volkogonov199172–74Service2004210–211Khlevniuk201570–71_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199199–100,_103Volkogonov199172–74Service2004210–211Khlevniuk201570–71-277">[269]</a></sup> In the final years of his life, Krupskaya provided governing figures with <a href="/wiki/Lenin%27s_Testament" title="Lenin's Testament">Lenin's Testament</a>, a series of increasingly disparaging notes about Stalin. These criticised Stalin's rude manners and excessive power, suggesting that Stalin should be removed from the position of general secretary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991100–101Volkogonov199153,_79–82Service2004208–209Khlevniuk201571_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991100–101Volkogonov199153,_79–82Service2004208–209Khlevniuk201571-278">[270]</a></sup> Some historians have questioned whether Lenin ever produced these, suggesting instead that they may have been written by Krupskaya, who had personal differences with Stalin;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014501_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014501-266">[258]</a></sup> Stalin, however, never publicly voiced concerns about their authenticity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014528_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014528-279">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Consolidation_of_power">Consolidation of power</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Rise of Joseph Stalin">Rise of Joseph Stalin</a></div>
<h3><span id="1924.E2.80.931927:_Succeeding_Lenin"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1924–1927:_Succeeding_Lenin">1924–1927: Succeeding Lenin</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2422" data-file-width="2090" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg/220px-Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg/330px-Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg/440px-Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_Rykov_Kamenev_Zinoviev_1925.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>(From left to right) Stalin, <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Rykov" title="Alexei Rykov">Alexei Rykov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kamenev" title="Lev Kamenev">Lev Kamenev</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grigori_Zinoviev" title="Grigori Zinoviev">Grigori Zinoviev</a> in 1925</div></div></div>
<p>Lenin died in January 1924.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991104Montefiore200330Service2004219Kotkin2014534Khlevniuk201579_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991104Montefiore200330Service2004219Kotkin2014534Khlevniuk201579-280">[272]</a></sup> Stalin took charge of the funeral and was one of its pallbearers; against the wishes of Lenin's widow, the Politburo embalmed his corpse and placed it within a <a href="/wiki/Lenin%27s_Mausoleum" title="Lenin's Mausoleum">mausoleum</a> in Moscow's <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991110Montefiore200330Service2004219Kotkin2014542–543_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991110Montefiore200330Service2004219Kotkin2014542–543-281">[273]</a></sup> It was incorporated into a growing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Personality_cult" title="Personality cult">personality cult</a> devoted to Lenin, with Petrograd being renamed "Leningrad" that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130Montefiore200330Service2004221Kotkin2014540_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130Montefiore200330Service2004221Kotkin2014540-282">[274]</a></sup> To bolster his image as a devoted Leninist, Stalin gave nine lectures at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sverdlov_University" title="Sverdlov University">Sverdlov University</a> on the "<a href="/wiki/Foundations_of_Leninism" title="Foundations of Leninism">Foundations of Leninism</a>", later published in book form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991111–112Volkogonov1991117–118Service2004221Kotkin2014544_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991111–112Volkogonov1991117–118Service2004221Kotkin2014544-283">[275]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/13th_Congress_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="13th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">13th Party Congress</a> in May 1924, "<a href="/wiki/Lenin%27s_Testament" title="Lenin's Testament">Lenin's Testament</a>" was read only to the leaders of the provincial delegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004222–224Khlevniuk201579_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004222–224Khlevniuk201579-284">[276]</a></sup> Embarrassed by its contents, Stalin offered his resignation as General Secretary; this act of humility saved him and he was retained in the position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991111Volkogonov199193–94Service2004222–224Kotkin2014546–548Khlevniuk201579_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991111Volkogonov199193–94Service2004222–224Kotkin2014546–548Khlevniuk201579-285">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>As General Secretary, Stalin had a free hand in making appointments to his own staff, implanting his loyalists throughout the party and administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014426_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014426-286">[278]</a></sup> Favouring new Communist Party members, many from worker and peasant backgrounds, to the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Bolsheviks" title="Old Bolsheviks">Old Bolsheviks</a>" who tended to be university educated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014453_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014453-287">[279]</a></sup> he ensured he had loyalists dispersed across the country's regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014455_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014455-288">[280]</a></sup> Stalin had much contact with young party functionaries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014469_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014469-289">[281]</a></sup> and the desire for promotion led many provincial figures to seek to impress Stalin and gain his favour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014432_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014432-290">[282]</a></sup> Stalin also developed close relations with the trio at the heart of the secret police (first the Cheka and then its replacement, the <a href="/wiki/State_Political_Directorate" title="State Political Directorate">State Political Directorate</a>): <a href="/wiki/Felix_Dzerzhinsky" title="Felix Dzerzhinsky">Felix Dzerzhinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genrikh_Yagoda" title="Genrikh Yagoda">Genrikh Yagoda</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Menzhinsky" title="Vyacheslav Menzhinsky">Vyacheslav Menzhinsky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014495–496_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014495–496-291">[283]</a></sup> In his private life, he divided his time between his Kremlin apartment and a <a href="/wiki/Dacha" title="Dacha">dacha</a> at Zubalova;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004235_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004235-292">[284]</a></sup> his wife gave birth to a daughter, <a href="/wiki/Svetlana_Alliluyeva" title="Svetlana Alliluyeva">Svetlana</a>, in February 1926.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004238_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991127Service2004238-293">[285]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the wake of Lenin's death, various protagonists emerged in the struggle to become his successor: alongside Stalin was Trotsky, Zinoviev, Kamenev, Bukharin, <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Rykov" title="Alexei Rykov">Alexei Rykov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Tomsky" title="Mikhail Tomsky">Mikhail Tomsky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFainsodHough1979111_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFainsodHough1979111-294">[286]</a></sup> Stalin saw Trotsky — whom he personally despised<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991136_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991136-295">[287]</a></sup> — as the main obstacle to his dominance within the party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200327_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200327-296">[288]</a></sup> While Lenin had been ill Stalin had forged an anti-Trotsky alliance with Kamenev and Zinoviev.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199198Kotkin2014474Khlevniuk201552_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199198Kotkin2014474Khlevniuk201552-297">[289]</a></sup> Although Zinoviev was concerned about Stalin's growing authority, he rallied behind him at the 13th Congress as a counterweight to Trotsky, who now led a party faction known as the <a href="/wiki/Left_Opposition" title="Left Opposition">Left Opposition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004214–215,_217_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004214–215,_217-298">[290]</a></sup> The Left Opposition believed the NEP conceded too much to capitalism; Stalin was called a "rightist" for his support of the policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201587_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201587-299">[291]</a></sup> Stalin built up a retinue of his supporters in the Central Committee,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004225_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004225-300">[292]</a></sup> while the Left Opposition were gradually removed from their positions of influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004227_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004227-301">[293]</a></sup> He was supported in this by Bukharin, who, like Stalin, believed that the Left Opposition's proposals would plunge the Soviet Union into instability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004228_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004228-302">[294]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ordzhonikidze,_Stalin_and_Mikoyan,_1925.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1060" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg/220px-Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg/330px-Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg/440px-Ordzhonikidze%2C_Stalin_and_Mikoyan%2C_1925.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ordzhonikidze,_Stalin_and_Mikoyan,_1925.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin and his close associates <a href="/wiki/Anastas_Mikoyan" title="Anastas Mikoyan">Anastas Mikoyan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sergo_Ordzhonikidze" title="Sergo Ordzhonikidze">Sergo Ordzhonikidze</a> in Tbilisi, 1925</div></div></div>
<p>In late 1924, Stalin moved against Kamenev and Zinoviev, removing their supporters from key positions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004228Kotkin2014563_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004228Kotkin2014563-303">[295]</a></sup> In 1925, the two moved into open opposition to Stalin and Bukharin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004240_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004240-304">[296]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/14th_Congress_of_the_All-Union_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="14th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">14th Party Congress</a> in December, they launched an attack against Stalin's faction, but it was unsuccessful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004240–243Khlevniuk201582–83_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004240–243Khlevniuk201582–83-305">[297]</a></sup> Stalin in turn accused Kamenev and Zinoviev of reintroducing factionalism — and thus instability — into the party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004240–243Khlevniuk201582–83_305-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004240–243Khlevniuk201582–83-305">[297]</a></sup> In mid-1926, Kamenev and Zinoviev joined with Trotsky's supporters to form the <a href="/wiki/United_Opposition_(Soviet_Union)" title="United Opposition (Soviet Union)">United Opposition</a> against Stalin;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991126Conquest200811Kotkin2014614Khlevniuk201583_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991126Conquest200811Kotkin2014614Khlevniuk201583-306">[298]</a></sup> in October they agreed to stop factional activity under threat of expulsion, and later publicly recanted their views under Stalin's command.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991137,_138Kotkin2014614_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991137,_138Kotkin2014614-307">[299]</a></sup> The factionalist arguments continued, with Stalin threatening to resign in October and then December 1926 and again in December 1927.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004247Kotkin2014614,_618Khlevniuk201591_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004247Kotkin2014614,_618Khlevniuk201591-308">[300]</a></sup> In October 1927, Zinoviev and Trotsky were removed from the Central Committee;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201585_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201585-309">[301]</a></sup> the latter was exiled to Kazakhstan and later deported from the country in 1929.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991139,_151Service2004282–283Conquest200811–12Kotkin2014676–677Khlevniuk201585_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991139,_151Service2004282–283Conquest200811–12Kotkin2014676–677Khlevniuk201585-310">[302]</a></sup> Some of those United Opposition members who were repentant were later rehabilitated and returned to government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991164Service2004282_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991164Service2004282-311">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin was now the party's supreme leader,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004276_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004276-312">[304]</a></sup> although he was not the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, a task he entrusted to his key ally <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Molotov" title="Vyacheslav Molotov">Vyacheslav Molotov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004277–278_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004277–278-313">[305]</a></sup> Other important supporters on the Politburo were Voroshilov, <a href="/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich" title="Lazar Kaganovich">Lazar Kaganovich</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sergo_Ordzhonikidze" title="Sergo Ordzhonikidze">Sergo Ordzhonikidze</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004277,_280Conquest200812–13_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004277,_280Conquest200812–13-314">[306]</a></sup> with Stalin ensuring his allies ran the various state institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004278_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004278-315">[307]</a></sup> According to Montefiore, at this point "Stalin was the leader of the oligarchs but he was far from a dictator".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200339_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200339-316">[308]</a></sup> His growing influence was reflected in naming of various locations after him; in June 1924 the Ukrainian mining town of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yuzovka" title="Yuzovka">Yuzovka</a> became Stalino,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130-317">[309]</a></sup> and in April 1925, Tsaritsyn was renamed Stalingrad on the order of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kalinin" title="Mikhail Kalinin">Mikhail Kalinin</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avel_Enukidze" title="Avel Enukidze">Avel Enukidze</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130Volkogonov1991160Kotkin2014689_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991130Volkogonov1991160Kotkin2014689-318">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1926, Stalin published <i>On Questions of Leninism</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004244_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004244-319">[311]</a></sup> Here, he argued for the concept of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialism_in_One_Country" title="Socialism in One Country">Socialism in One Country</a>", which he presented as an orthodox Leninist perspective. It nevertheless clashed with established Bolshevik views that socialism could not be established in one country but could only be achieved globally through the process of <a href="/wiki/World_revolution" title="World revolution">world revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004244_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004244-319">[311]</a></sup> In 1927, there was some argument in the party over Soviet policy regarding China. Stalin had called for the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communists</a> to ally themselves with <a href="/wiki/National_Revolutionary_Army" title="National Revolutionary Army">Kuomintang</a> (KMT) nationalists, viewing a Communist-Kuomintang alliance as the best bulwark against Japanese imperial expansionism. Instead, the KMT repressed the Communists and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_civil_war" title="Chinese civil war">civil war broke out</a> between the two sides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004392Kotkin2014626–631Khlevniuk201589–90_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004392Kotkin2014626–631Khlevniuk201589–90-320">[312]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span id="1927.E2.80.931931:_Dekulakisation.2C_collectivisation.2C_and_industrialisation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1927–1931:_Dekulakisation,_collectivisation,_and_industrialisation">1927–1931: Dekulakisation, collectivisation, and industrialisation</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_policy">Economic policy</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1062260506" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>We have fallen behind the advanced countries by fifty to a hundred years. We must close that gap in ten years. Either we do this or we'll be crushed.
</p><p>This is what our obligations before the workers and peasants of the USSR dictate to us.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">— Stalin, February 1931<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004273_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004273-321">[313]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>The Soviet Union lagged behind the industrial development of Western countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004256_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004256-322">[314]</a></sup> and there had been a shortfall of grain; 1927 produced only 70% of grain produced in 1926.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004254_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004254-323">[315]</a></sup> Stalin's government feared attack from Japan, France, the United Kingdom, Poland, and Romania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991172–173Service2004256Kotkin2014638–639_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991172–173Service2004256Kotkin2014638–639-324">[316]</a></sup> Many Communists, including in <a href="/wiki/Komsomol" title="Komsomol">Komsomol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joint_State_Political_Directorate" title="Joint State Political Directorate">OGPU</a>, and the Red Army, were eager to be rid of the NEP and its market-oriented approach;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991144,_146Service2004258_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991144,_146Service2004258-325">[317]</a></sup> they had concerns about those who profited from the policy: affluent peasants known as "<a href="/wiki/Kulak" title="Kulak">kulaks</a>" and small business owners or "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nepmen" title="Nepmen">Nepmen</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004256Kotkin2014571_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004256Kotkin2014571-326">[318]</a></sup> At this point, Stalin turned against the NEP, which put him on a course to the "left" even of Trotsky or Zinoviev.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004253Khlevniuk2015101_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004253Khlevniuk2015101-327">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 1928 Stalin travelled to <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk" title="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a>, where he alleged that kulaks were hoarding their grain and ordered that the kulaks be arrested and their grain confiscated, with Stalin bringing much of the area's grain back to Moscow with him in February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991147–148Service2004257–258Kotkin2014661,_668–669,_679–684Khlevniuk2015102–103_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991147–148Service2004257–258Kotkin2014661,_668–669,_679–684Khlevniuk2015102–103-328">[320]</a></sup> At his command, grain procurement squads surfaced across Western Siberia and the Urals, with violence breaking out between these squads and the peasantry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004258Khlevniuk2015103_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004258Khlevniuk2015103-329">[321]</a></sup> Stalin announced that both kulaks and the "middle peasants" must be coerced into releasing their harvest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004258_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004258-330">[322]</a></sup> Bukharin and several other Central Committee members were angry that they had not been consulted about this measure, which they deemed rash.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004258Khlevniuk2015105_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004258Khlevniuk2015105-331">[323]</a></sup> In January 1930, the Politburo approved the liquidation of the kulak class; accused kulaks were rounded up and exiled to other parts of the country or to concentration camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004267_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004267-332">[324]</a></sup> Large numbers died during the journey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991160Volkogonov1991166_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991160Volkogonov1991166-333">[325]</a></sup> By July 1930, over 320,000 households had been affected by the de-kulakisation policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004267_332-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004267-332">[324]</a></sup> According to Stalin biographer <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Volkogonov" title="Dmitri Volkogonov">Dmitri Volkogonov</a>, de-kulakisation was "the first mass terror applied by Stalin in his own country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991167_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991167-334">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stakhanov.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2678" data-file-width="4060" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stakhanov.JPG/220px-Stakhanov.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stakhanov.JPG/330px-Stakhanov.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Stakhanov.JPG/440px-Stakhanov.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stakhanov.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aleksei_Grigorievich_Stakhanov" title="Aleksei Grigorievich Stakhanov">Aleksei Grigorievich Stakhanov</a> with a fellow miner; Stalin's government initiated the Stakhanovite movement to encourage hard work. It was partly responsible for a substantial rise in production during the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999231_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999231-335">[327]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 1929, the Politburo announced the <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Collectivization in the Soviet Union">mass collectivisation of agriculture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004265–266Khlevniuk2015110–111_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004265–266Khlevniuk2015110–111-336">[328]</a></sup> establishing both <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kolkhozy" title="Kolkhozy">kolkhozy</a></i> collective farms and <i><a href="/wiki/Sovkhoz" title="Sovkhoz">sovkhoz</a></i> state farms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999234_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999234-337">[329]</a></sup> Stalin barred kulaks from joining these collectives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004266Khlevniuk2015112_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004266Khlevniuk2015112-338">[330]</a></sup> Although officially voluntary, many peasants joined the collectives out of fear they would face the fate of the kulaks; others joined amid intimidation and violence from party loyalists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015113_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015113-339">[331]</a></sup> By 1932, about 62% of households involved in agriculture were part of collectives, and by 1936 this had risen to 90%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004271_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004271-340">[332]</a></sup> Many of the collectivised peasants resented the loss of their private farmland,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004270_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004270-341">[333]</a></sup> and productivity slumped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004270Khlevniuk2015116_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004270Khlevniuk2015116-342">[334]</a></sup> Famine broke out in many areas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004272Khlevniuk2015116_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004272Khlevniuk2015116-343">[335]</a></sup> with the Politburo frequently ordering distribution of emergency food relief to these regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004272_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004272-344">[336]</a></sup>
</p><p>Armed peasant uprisings against dekulakisation and collectivisation broke out in Ukraine, northern Caucasus, southern Russia, and central Asia, reaching their apex in March 1930; these were suppressed by the Red Army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004270Khlevniuk2015113–114_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004270Khlevniuk2015113–114-345">[337]</a></sup> Stalin responded to the uprisings with <a href="/wiki/Dizzy_with_Success" title="Dizzy with Success">an article</a> insisting that collectivisation was voluntary and blaming any violence and other excesses on local officials.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991160Khlevniuk2015114_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991160Khlevniuk2015114-346">[338]</a></sup> Although he and Stalin had been close for many years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991174_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991174-347">[339]</a></sup> Bukharin expressed concerns about these policies; he regarded them as a return to Lenin's old "<a href="/wiki/War_communism" title="War communism">war communism</a>" policy and believed that it would fail. By mid-1928 he was unable to rally sufficient support in the party to oppose the reforms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991172Service2004260Kotkin2014708_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991172Service2004260Kotkin2014708-348">[340]</a></sup> In November 1929 Stalin removed him from the Politburo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991158Service2004266Conquest200818_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991158Service2004266Conquest200818-349">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Officially, the Soviet Union had replaced the "irrationality" and "wastefulness" of a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> organised along a long-term, precise, and scientific framework; in reality, Soviet economics were based on <i>ad hoc</i> commandments issued from the centre, often to make short-term targets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999227,_229_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999227,_229-350">[342]</a></sup> In 1928, the <a href="/wiki/First_five-year_plan" title="First five-year plan">first five-year plan</a> was launched, its main focus on boosting heavy industry;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004259_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004259-351">[343]</a></sup> it was finished a year ahead of schedule, in 1932.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004274_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004274-352">[344]</a></sup> The USSR underwent a massive economic transformation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004265_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004265-353">[345]</a></sup> New mines were opened, new cities like <a href="/wiki/Magnitogorsk" title="Magnitogorsk">Magnitogorsk</a> constructed, and work on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_Sea-Baltic_Canal" title="White Sea-Baltic Canal">White Sea-Baltic Canal</a> began.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004265_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004265-353">[345]</a></sup> Millions of peasants moved to the cities, although urban house building could not keep up with the demand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004265_353-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004265-353">[345]</a></sup> Large debts were accrued purchasing foreign-made machinery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015118_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015118-354">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of major construction projects, including the White Sea-Baltic Canal and the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Metro" title="Moscow Metro">Moscow Metro</a>, were constructed largely through forced labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991186,_190_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991186,_190-355">[347]</a></sup> The last elements of workers' control over industry were removed, with factory managers increasing their authority and receiving privileges and perks;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999231–233_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999231–233-356">[348]</a></sup> Stalin defended wage disparity by pointing to Marx's argument that it was necessary during the lower stages of socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999241–242_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999241–242-357">[349]</a></sup> To promote intensification of labour, a series of medals and awards as well as the <a href="/wiki/Stakhanovite_movement" title="Stakhanovite movement">Stakhanovite movement</a> were introduced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999231_335-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999231-335">[327]</a></sup> Stalin's message was that socialism was being established in the USSR while capitalism was crumbling amid the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wall_Street_crash" title="Wall Street crash">Wall Street crash</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004269_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004269-358">[350]</a></sup> His speeches and articles reflected his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Utopianism" title="Utopianism">utopian</a> vision of the Soviet Union rising to unparalleled heights of human development, creating a "<a href="/wiki/New_Soviet_man" title="New Soviet man">new Soviet person</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004300_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004300-359">[351]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_and_foreign_policy">Cultural and foreign policy</span></h4>
<p>In 1928, Stalin declared that class war between the proletariat and their enemies would intensify as socialism developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991152–153Sandle1999214Khlevniuk2015107–108_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991152–153Sandle1999214Khlevniuk2015107–108-360">[352]</a></sup> He warned of a "danger from the right", including in the Communist Party itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015108_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015108-361">[353]</a></sup> The first major <a href="/wiki/Show_trial" title="Show trial">show trial</a> in the USSR was the <a href="/wiki/Shakhty_Trial" title="Shakhty Trial">Shakhty Trial</a> of 1928, in which several
