middle-class "industrial specialists" were convicted of sabotage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991152–155Service2004259Kotkin2014687,_702–704,_709Khlevniuk2015107_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991152–155Service2004259Kotkin2014687,_702–704,_709Khlevniuk2015107-362">[354]</a></sup> From 1929 to 1930, further show trials were held to intimidate opposition:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004268_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004268-363">[355]</a></sup> these included the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Party_Trial" title="Industrial Party Trial">Industrial Party Trial</a>, <a href="/wiki/1931_Menshevik_Trial" title="1931 Menshevik Trial">Menshevik Trial</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Metro-Vickers_Affair" title="Metro-Vickers Affair">Metro-Vickers Trial</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991155_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991155-364">[356]</a></sup> Aware that the ethnic Russian majority may have concerns about being ruled by a Georgian,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004324_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004324-365">[357]</a></sup> he promoted ethnic Russians throughout the state hierarchy and made the <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a> compulsory throughout schools and offices, albeit to be used in tandem with local languages in areas with non-Russian majorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004326_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004326-366">[358]</a></sup> Nationalist sentiment among ethnic minorities was suppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004301_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004301-367">[359]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Social_conservatism" title="Social conservatism">Conservative social policies</a> were promoted to enhance social discipline and boost population growth; this included a focus on strong family units and motherhood, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="LGBT rights in the Soviet Union">re-criminalisation of homosexuality</a>, restrictions placed on abortion and divorce, and abolition of the <i><a href="/wiki/Zhenotdel" title="Zhenotdel">Zhenotdel</a></i> women's department.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999244,_246_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999244,_246-368">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="610" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg/220px-Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg/330px-Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg/440px-Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Christ_saviour_explosion.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Photograph taken of the 1931 demolition of the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour" title="Cathedral of Christ the Saviour">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a> in Moscow in order to make way for the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Soviets" title="Palace of the Soviets">Palace of the Soviets</a></div></div></div>
<p>Stalin desired a "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution_(USSR)" title="Cultural Revolution (USSR)">cultural revolution</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004299_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004299-369">[361]</a></sup> entailing both creation of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Culture of the Soviet Union">a culture</a> for the "masses" and wider dissemination of previously elite culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004304_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004304-370">[362]</a></sup> He oversaw proliferation of schools, newspapers, and libraries, as well as advancement of literacy and <a href="/wiki/Numeracy" title="Numeracy">numeracy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991111,_127Service2004308_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991111,_127Service2004308-371">[363]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">Socialist realism</a> was promoted throughout arts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999246Montefiore200385_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999246Montefiore200385-372">[364]</a></sup> while Stalin personally wooed prominent writers, namely <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Sholokhov" title="Mikhail Sholokhov">Mikhail Sholokhov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_Nikolayevich_Tolstoy" title="Aleksey Nikolayevich Tolstoy">Aleksey Nikolayevich Tolstoy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004302–303_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004302–303-373">[365]</a></sup> He also expressed patronage for scientists whose research fitted within his preconceived interpretation of Marxism; for instance, he endorsed research of an agrobiologist <a href="/wiki/Trofim_Lysenko" title="Trofim Lysenko">Trofim Lysenko</a> despite the fact that it was rejected by the majority of Lysenko's scientific peers as <a href="/wiki/Pseudoscience" title="Pseudoscience">pseudo-scientific</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991211,_276–277Service2004307_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991211,_276–277Service2004307-374">[366]</a></sup> The government's anti-religious campaign was re-intensified,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991157_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991157-375">[367]</a></sup> with increased funding given to the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Militant_Atheists" title="League of Militant Atheists">League of Militant Atheists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004301_367-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004301-367">[359]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union">Christian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Islam in the Soviet Union">Muslim</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhist</a> clergy faced persecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004268_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004268-363">[355]</a></sup> Many religious buildings were demolished, most notably Moscow's <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour" title="Cathedral of Christ the Saviour">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a>, destroyed in 1931 to make way for the (never completed) <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Soviets" title="Palace of the Soviets">Palace of the Soviets</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991191_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991191-376">[368]</a></sup> Religion retained an influence over much of the population; in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Census_(1937)" title="Soviet Census (1937)">1937 census</a>, 57% of respondents identified as religious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015325_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015325-377">[369]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout the 1920s and beyond, Stalin placed a high priority on foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004379_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004379-378">[370]</a></sup> He personally met with a range of Western visitors, including <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a> and <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>, both of whom were impressed with him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991183–184_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991183–184-379">[371]</a></sup> Through the Communist International, Stalin's government exerted a strong influence over Marxist parties elsewhere in the world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004282_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004282-380">[372]</a></sup> initially, Stalin left the running of the organisation largely to Bukharin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004261_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004261-381">[373]</a></sup> At its 6th Congress in July 1928, Stalin informed delegates that the main threat to socialism came not from the right but from non-Marxist socialists and <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">social democrats</a>, whom he called "<a href="/wiki/Social_fascism" title="Social fascism">social fascists</a>";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott1995410–411Conquest1991176Service2004261,_383Kotkin2014720_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott1995410–411Conquest1991176Service2004261,_383Kotkin2014720-382">[374]</a></sup> Stalin recognised that in many countries, the social democrats were the Marxist-Leninists' main rivals for working-class support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991173_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991173-383">[375]</a></sup> This preoccupation with opposing rival leftists concerned Bukharin, who regarded the growth of <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Far-right_politics" title="Far-right politics">far right</a> across Europe as a far greater threat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004261_381-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004261-381">[373]</a></sup> After Bukharin's departure, Stalin placed the Communist International under the administration of <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Manuilsky" title="Dmitry Manuilsky">Dmitry Manuilsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Osip_Piatnitsky" title="Osip Piatnitsky">Osip Piatnitsky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004282_380-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004282-380">[372]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin faced problems in his family life. In 1929, his son Yakov unsuccessfully attempted suicide; his failure earned Stalin's contempt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004289Kotkin2014595_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004289Kotkin2014595-384">[376]</a></sup> His relationship with Nadezhda was also strained amid their arguments and her mental health problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004289_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004289-385">[377]</a></sup> In November 1932, after a group dinner in the Kremlin in which Stalin flirted with other women, Nadezhda shot herself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991169Montefiore200390Service2004291–292_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991169Montefiore200390Service2004291–292-386">[378]</a></sup>
Publicly, the cause of death was given as <a href="/wiki/Appendicitis" title="Appendicitis">appendicitis</a>; Stalin also concealed the real cause of death from his children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200394,_95Service2004292,_294_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200394,_95Service2004292,_294-387">[379]</a></sup> Stalin's friends noted that he underwent a significant change following her suicide, becoming emotionally harder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004297_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004297-388">[380]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span id="1932.E2.80.931939:_Major_crises"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1932–1939:_Major_crises">1932–1939: Major crises</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Famine">Famine</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%9333" title="Soviet famine of 1932–33">Soviet famine of 1932–33</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kazakh_famine_of_1932%E2%80%9333" title="Kazakh famine of 1932–33">Kazakh famine of 1932–33</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="905" data-file-width="649" decoding="async" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg/220px-Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg/330px-Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg/440px-Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Famine_en_URSS_1933.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%9333" title="Soviet famine of 1932–33">Soviet famine of 1932–33</a>. Areas of most disastrous famine marked with black.</div></div></div>
<p>Within the Soviet Union, there was widespread civic disgruntlement against Stalin's government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004316_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004316-389">[381]</a></sup> Social unrest, previously restricted largely to the countryside, was increasingly evident in urban areas, prompting Stalin to ease on some of his economic policies in 1932.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004310_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004310-390">[382]</a></sup> In May 1932, he introduced a system of kolkhoz markets where peasants could trade their surplus produce.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004310DaviesWheatcroft2006627_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004310DaviesWheatcroft2006627-391">[383]</a></sup> At the same time, penal sanctions became more severe; at Stalin's instigation, in August 1932 a decree was introduced wherein the theft of even a handful of grain could be a capital offence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628-392">[384]</a></sup> The second five-year plan had its production quotas reduced from that of the first, with the main emphasis now being on improving living conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004310_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004310-390">[382]</a></sup> It therefore emphasised the expansion of housing space and the production of consumer goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004310_390-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004310-390">[382]</a></sup> Like its predecessor, this plan was repeatedly amended to meet changing situations; there was for instance an increasing emphasis placed on armament production after <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> became <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_Germany" title="Chancellor of Germany">German chancellor</a> in 1933.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004318_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004318-393">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Soviet Union experienced a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%9333" title="Soviet famine of 1932–33">major famine which peaked in the winter of 1932–33</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004312Conquest200819–20Khlevniuk2015117_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004312Conquest200819–20Khlevniuk2015117-394">[386]</a></sup> between five and seven million people died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015117_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015117-395">[387]</a></sup> The worst affected areas were Ukraine and the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>, although the famine also affected Kazakhstan and several Russian provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015119_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015119-396">[388]</a></sup> Historians have long debated whether Stalin's government had intended the famine to occur or not;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005823_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005823-397">[389]</a></sup> there are no known documents in which Stalin or his government explicitly called for starvation to be used against the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005824DaviesWheatcroft2006628,_631_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005824DaviesWheatcroft2006628,_631-398">[390]</a></sup> The 1931 and 1932 harvests had been poor ones because of weather conditions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005823–824DaviesWheatcroft2006626Khlevniuk2015117_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005823–824DaviesWheatcroft2006626Khlevniuk2015117-399">[391]</a></sup> and had followed several years in which lower productivity had resulted in a gradual decline in output.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015117_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015117-395">[387]</a></sup> Government policies—including the focus on rapid industrialisation, the socialisation of livestock, and the emphasis on sown areas over <a href="/wiki/Crop_rotation" title="Crop rotation">crop rotation</a>—exacerbated the problem;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005834_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005834-400">[392]</a></sup> the state had also failed to build reserve grain stocks for such an emergency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006626_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006626-401">[393]</a></sup> Stalin blamed the famine on hostile elements and sabotage within the peasantry;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005824DaviesWheatcroft2006627–628Khlevniuk2015120_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005824DaviesWheatcroft2006627–628Khlevniuk2015120-402">[394]</a></sup> his government provided small amounts of food to famine-struck rural areas, although this was wholly insufficient to deal with the levels of starvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006627_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006627-403">[395]</a></sup> The Soviet government believed that food supplies should be prioritised for the urban workforce;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2005833Kuromiya2008665_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2005833Kuromiya2008665-404">[396]</a></sup> for Stalin, the fate of Soviet industrialisation was far more important than the lives of the peasantry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628Ellman2007664_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628Ellman2007664-405">[397]</a></sup> Grain exports, which were a major means of Soviet payment for machinery, declined heavily.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006627_403-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006627-403">[395]</a></sup> Stalin would not acknowledge that his policies had contributed to the famine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628_392-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2006628-392">[384]</a></sup> the existence of which was kept secret from foreign observers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991164Kotkin2014724_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991164Kotkin2014724-406">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ideological_and_foreign_affairs">Ideological and foreign affairs</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stalin%27s_cult_of_personality" title="Stalin's cult of personality">Stalin's cult of personality</a></div>
<p>In 1935–36, Stalin oversaw a new constitution; its dramatic liberal features were designed as propaganda weapons, for all power rested in the hands of Stalin and his Politburo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004319_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004319-407">[399]</a></sup> He declared that "socialism, which is the first phase of communism, has basically been achieved in this country".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004319_407-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004319-407">[399]</a></sup> In 1938, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_History_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union_(Bolsheviks)" title="The History of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (Bolsheviks)">The History of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (Bolsheviks)</a></i>, colloquially known as the <i>Short Course</i>, was released;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991212Volkogonov1991552–443Service2004361_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991212Volkogonov1991552–443Service2004361-408">[400]</a></sup> biographer Robert Conquest later referred to it as the "central text of Stalinism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991212_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991212-409">[401]</a></sup> A number of authorised Stalin biographies were also published,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004361_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004361-410">[402]</a></sup> although Stalin generally wanted to be portrayed as the embodiment of the Communist Party rather than have his life story explored.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004362_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004362-411">[403]</a></sup> During the later 1930s, Stalin placed "a few limits on the worship of his own greatness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004362_411-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004362-411">[403]</a></sup> By 1938, Stalin's inner circle had gained a degree of stability, containing the personalities who would remain there until Stalin's death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991216_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991216-412">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="782" data-file-width="1297" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png/220px-Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png/330px-Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png/440px-Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_armor_in_the_spanish_civil_war.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Review of Soviet armoured fighting vehicles used to equip the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Army" title="Republican People's Army">Republican People's Army</a> during the Spanish Civil War</div></div></div>
<p>Seeking improved international relations, in 1934 the Soviet Union secured membership of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>, from which it had previously been excluded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004386_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004386-413">[405]</a></sup> Stalin initiated confidential communications with Hitler in October 1933, shortly after the latter came to power in Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991217_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991217-414">[406]</a></sup> Stalin admired Hitler, particularly his manoeuvres to remove rivals within the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Party" title="Nazi Party">Nazi Party</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Night_of_the_Long_Knives" title="Night of the Long Knives">Night of the Long Knives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991176Montefiore2003116Service2004340_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991176Montefiore2003116Service2004340-415">[407]</a></sup> Stalin nevertheless recognised the threat posed by fascism and sought to establish better links with the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">liberal democracies</a> of Western Europe;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991218Khlevniuk2015123,_135_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991218Khlevniuk2015123,_135-416">[408]</a></sup> in May 1935, the Soviets signed a <a href="/wiki/Franco-Soviet_Treaty_of_Mutual_Assistance" title="Franco-Soviet Treaty of Mutual Assistance">treaty of mutual assistance</a> with France and Czechoslovakia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015135_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015135-417">[409]</a></sup> At the Communist International's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seventh_World_Congress_of_the_Comintern" title="Seventh World Congress of the Comintern">7th Congress</a>, held in July–August 1935, the Soviet government encouraged Marxist-Leninists to unite with other leftists as part of a <a href="/wiki/Popular_front" title="Popular front">popular front</a> against fascism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaslam1979682–683Conquest1991218Service2004385Khlevniuk2015135_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaslam1979682–683Conquest1991218Service2004385Khlevniuk2015135-418">[410]</a></sup> In turn, the anti-communist governments of Germany, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Fascist Italy</a> and Japan signed the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Comintern_Pact" title="Anti-Comintern Pact">Anti-Comintern Pact</a> of 1936.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004392Khlevniuk2015154_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004392Khlevniuk2015154-419">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a> broke out in July 1936, the Soviets sent 648 aircraft and 407 tanks to the left-wing <a href="/wiki/Republican_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War)" title="Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)">Republican faction</a>; these were accompanied by 3,000 Soviet troops and 42,000 members of the <a href="/wiki/International_Brigades" title="International Brigades">International Brigades</a> set up by the Communist International.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991219Service2004387_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991219Service2004387-420">[412]</a></sup> Stalin took a strong personal involvement in the Spanish situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015154_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015154-421">[413]</a></sup> Germany and Italy backed the <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_faction_(Spanish_Civil_War)" title="Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)">Nationalist faction</a>, which was ultimately victorious in March 1939.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004387,_389_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004387,_389-422">[414]</a></sup> With the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> in July 1937, the Soviet Union and China signed a <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Non-Aggression_Pact" title="Sino-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact">non-aggression pact</a> the following August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015156_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015156-423">[415]</a></sup> Stalin aided the Chinese as the KMT and the Communists had suspended their civil war and formed the desired <a href="/wiki/Second_United_Front" title="Second United Front">United Front</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004392_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004392-424">[416]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Great_Terror">The Great Terror</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vinnycia16.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="325" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Vinnycia16.jpg/220px-Vinnycia16.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Vinnycia16.jpg/330px-Vinnycia16.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Vinnycia16.jpg/440px-Vinnycia16.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vinnycia16.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Exhumed mass grave of the <a href="/wiki/Vinnytsia_massacre" title="Vinnytsia massacre">Vinnytsia massacre</a></div></div></div>
<p>Stalin often gave conflicting signals regarding state repression.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015126_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015126-425">[417]</a></sup> In May 1933, he released from prison many convicted of minor offences, ordering the security services not to enact further mass arrests and deportations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015125_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015125-426">[418]</a></sup> In September 1934, he launched a commission to investigate false imprisonments; that same month he called for the execution of workers at the Stalin Metallurgical Factory accused of spying for Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015126_425-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015126-425">[417]</a></sup> This mixed approach began to change in December 1934, after prominent party member <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Kirov" title="Sergei Kirov">Sergey Kirov</a> was murdered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991179Montefiore2003126–127Service2004314Khlevniuk2015128–129_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991179Montefiore2003126–127Service2004314Khlevniuk2015128–129-427">[419]</a></sup> After the murder, Stalin became increasingly concerned by the threat of assassination, improved his personal security, and rarely went out in public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOvery2004327_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOvery2004327-428">[420]</a></sup> State repression intensified after Kirov's death;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015128,_137_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015128,_137-429">[421]</a></sup> Stalin instigated this, reflecting his prioritisation of security above other considerations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004347_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004347-430">[422]</a></sup> Stalin issued a decree establishing <a href="/wiki/NKVD_troika" title="NKVD troika">NKVD troikas</a> which could mete out rulings without involving the courts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004315_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004315-431">[423]</a></sup> In 1935, he ordered the NKVD to expel suspected counter-revolutionaries from urban areas;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004318_393-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004318-393">[385]</a></sup> in early 1935, over 11,000 were expelled from Leningrad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004318_393-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004318-393">[385]</a></sup> In 1936, <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Yezhov" title="Nikolai Yezhov">Nikolai Yezhov</a> became head of the NKVD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015139_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015139-432">[424]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>
<p>Stalin orchestrated the arrest of many former opponents in the Communist Party <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Committee_elected_by_the_17th_Congress_of_the_All-Union_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="Central Committee elected by the 17th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">as well as sitting members of the Central Committee</a>: denounced as Western-backed mercenaries, many were imprisoned or exiled internally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004314–317_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004314–317-433">[425]</a></sup> The first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moscow_Trials" title="Moscow Trials">Moscow Trial</a> took place in August 1936; Kamenev and Zinoviev were among those accused of plotting assassinations, found guilty in a show trial, and executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003139,_154–155,_164–172,_175–176Service2004320Khlevniuk2015139_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003139,_154–155,_164–172,_175–176Service2004320Khlevniuk2015139-434">[426]</a></sup> The second Moscow Show Trial took place in January 1937,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015139–140_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015139–140-435">[427]</a></sup> and the third in March 1938, in which Bukharin and Rykov were accused of involvement in the alleged Trotskyite-Zinovievite terrorist plot and sentenced to death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003192–193Service2004346Conquest200824Khlevniuk2015140_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003192–193Service2004346Conquest200824Khlevniuk2015140-436">[428]</a></sup> By late 1937, all remnants of collective leadership were gone from the Politburo, which was controlled entirely by Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015176–177_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015176–177-437">[429]</a></sup>
There were mass expulsions from the party,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004349_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004349-438">[430]</a></sup> with Stalin commanding foreign communist parties to also purge anti-Stalinist elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004391_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004391-439">[431]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="718" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_910794_Memorial_events_in_Bykovnya_Graves_reserve.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Victims of Stalin's <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Terror</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Bykivnia_graves" title="Bykivnia graves">Bykivnia mass graves</a></div></div></div>
<p>Repressions further intensified in December 1936 and remained at a high level until November 1938, a period known as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004347_430-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004347-430">[422]</a></sup> By the latter part of 1937, the purges had moved beyond the party and were affecting the wider population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015141,_150_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015141,_150-440">[432]</a></sup> In July 1937, the Politburo ordered a purge of "anti-Soviet elements" in society, targeting anti-Stalin Bolsheviks, former Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, priests, ex-White Army soldiers, and common criminals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004350Khlevniuk2015150–151_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004350Khlevniuk2015150–151-441">[433]</a></sup> That month, Stalin and Yezhov signed <a href="/wiki/NKVD_Order_No._00447" title="NKVD Order No. 00447">Order No. 00447</a>, listing 268,950 people for arrest, of whom 75,950 were executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003203–204Service2004350–351Khlevniuk2015150_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003203–204Service2004350–351Khlevniuk2015150-442">[434]</a></sup> He also initiated "national operations", the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> of non-Soviet ethnic groups—among them Poles, Germans, Latvians, Finns, Greeks, Koreans, and Chinese—through internal or external exile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003204Service2004351,_390Khlevniuk2015151_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003204Service2004351,_390Khlevniuk2015151-443">[435]</a></sup> During these years, approximately 1.6 million people were arrested,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151-444">[436]</a></sup> 700,000 were shot, and an unknown number died under NKVD torture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151_444-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151-444">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1930s and 1940s, NKVD groups assassinated defectors and opponents abroad;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004394_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004394-445">[437]</a></sup> in August 1940, Trotsky was assassinated in Mexico, eliminating the last of Stalin's opponents among the former Party leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991230Service2004394Overy2004338Khlevniuk2015174_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991230Service2004394Overy2004338Khlevniuk2015174-446">[438]</a></sup> In May, this was followed by the arrest of most members of the military Supreme Command and mass arrests throughout the military, often on fabricated charges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003201Service2004349Khlevniuk2015140_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003201Service2004349Khlevniuk2015140-447">[439]</a></sup> These purges replaced most of the party's old guard with younger officials who did not remember a time before Stalin's leadership and who were regarded as more personally loyal to him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015137–138,_147_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015137–138,_147-448">[440]</a></sup> Party functionaries readily carried out their commands and sought to ingratiate themselves with Stalin to avoid becoming the victim of the purge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015140_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015140-449">[441]</a></sup> Such functionaries often carried out a greater number of arrests and executions than their quotas set by Stalin's central government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003204_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003204-450">[442]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin initiated all key decisions during the Terror, personally directing many of its operations and taking an interest in their implementation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151,_159_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151,_159-451">[443]</a></sup> His motives in doing so have been much debated by historians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151_444-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015151-444">[436]</a></sup> His personal writings from the period were — according to Khlevniuk — "unusually convoluted and incoherent", filled with claims about enemies encircling him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015152_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015152-452">[444]</a></sup> He was particularly concerned at the success that right-wing forces had in overthrowing the leftist Spanish government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004347–248Khlevniuk2015125,_156–157_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004347–248Khlevniuk2015125,_156–157-453">[445]</a></sup> fearing a domestic <a href="/wiki/Fifth_column" title="Fifth column">fifth column</a> in the event of future war with Japan and Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015153,_156–157_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015153,_156–157-454">[446]</a></sup> The Great Terror ended when Yezhov was removed as the head of the NKVD, to be replaced by <a href="/wiki/Lavrentiy_Beria" title="Lavrentiy Beria">Lavrentiy Beria</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004367_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004367-455">[447]</a></sup> a man totally devoted to Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003245_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003245-456">[448]</a></sup> Yezhov was arrested in April 1939 and executed in 1940.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991209Service2004369Khlevniuk2015160_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991209Service2004369Khlevniuk2015160-457">[449]</a></sup> The Terror damaged the Soviet Union's reputation abroad, particularly among sympathetic leftists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015162_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015162-458">[450]</a></sup> As it wound down, Stalin sought to deflect responsibility from himself,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015157_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015157-459">[451]</a></sup> blaming its "excesses" and "violations of law" on Yezhov.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015159_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015159-460">[452]</a></sup> According to historian James Harris, contemporary archival research shows that the motivation behind the purges was not Stalin attempting to establish his own personal dictatorship; evidence suggests he was committed to building the socialist state envisioned by Lenin. The real motivation for the terror, according to Harris, was an excessive fear of counterrevolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris20171–5,_16_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris20171–5,_16-461">[453]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_in_World_War_II" title="Soviet Union in World War II">Soviet Union in World War II</a></div>
<h3><span id="1939.E2.80.931941:_Pact_with_Nazi_Germany"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1939–1941:_Pact_with_Nazi_Germany">1939–1941: Pact with Nazi Germany</span></h3>
<p>As a Marxist–Leninist, Stalin considered conflict between competing capitalist powers inevitable; after Nazi Germany <a href="/wiki/Anschluss" title="Anschluss">annexed Austria</a> and then <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Czechoslovakia" title="German occupation of Czechoslovakia">part of Czechoslovakia</a> in 1938, he recognised a war was looming.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003308_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003308-462">[454]</a></sup> He sought to maintain Soviet neutrality, hoping that a German war against France and Britain would lead to Soviet dominance in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220–221Service2004380–381_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220–221Service2004380–381-463">[455]</a></sup> Militarily, the Soviets also faced a threat from the east, with Soviet troops <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_border_conflicts" title="Soviet–Japanese border conflicts">clashing with the expansionist Japanese</a> in the latter part of the 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004392–393Khlevniuk2015163,_168–169_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004392–393Khlevniuk2015163,_168–169-464">[456]</a></sup> Stalin initiated a military build-up, with the Red Army more than doubling between January 1939 and June 1941, although in its haste to expand many of its officers were poorly trained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015185–186_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015185–186-465">[457]</a></sup> Between 1940 and 1941 he also purged the military, leaving it with a severe shortage of trained officers when war broke out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991232–233,_236_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991232–233,_236-466">[458]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337,_Moskau,_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1562" data-file-width="1185" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg/170px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg/255px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg/340px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337,_Moskau,_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin greeting the German foreign minister <a href="/wiki/Joachim_von_Ribbentrop" title="Joachim von Ribbentrop">Joachim von Ribbentrop</a> in the Kremlin, 1939</div></div></div>
<p>As Britain and France seemed unwilling to commit to an alliance with the Soviet Union, Stalin saw a better deal with the Germans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004399–400_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004399–400-467">[459]</a></sup> On 3 May 1939, Stalin replaced his western-oriented foreign minister <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Litvinov" title="Maxim Litvinov">Maxim Litvinov</a> with <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Molotov" title="Vyacheslav Molotov">Vyacheslav Molotov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENekrich1997109_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENekrich1997109-468">[460]</a></sup> Germany began negotiations with the Soviets, proposing that Eastern Europe be divided between the two powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220Khlevniuk2015166_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220Khlevniuk2015166-469">[461]</a></sup> Stalin saw this as an opportunity both for territorial expansion and temporary peace with Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220Khlevniuk2015168,_169_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991220Khlevniuk2015168,_169-470">[462]</a></sup> In August 1939, the Soviet Union signed the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov-Ribbentrop pact</a> with Germany, a non-aggression pact negotiated by Molotov and German foreign minister <a href="/wiki/Joachim_von_Ribbentrop" title="Joachim von Ribbentrop">Joachim von Ribbentrop</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991221Roberts199257–78Service2004399Khlevniuk2015166_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991221Roberts199257–78Service2004399Khlevniuk2015166-471">[463]</a></sup> A week later, <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Germany invaded Poland</a>, sparking the UK and France to declare war on Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991222Roberts199257–78Khlevniuk2015169_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991222Roberts199257–78Khlevniuk2015169-472">[464]</a></sup> On 17 September, <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">the Red Army entered eastern Poland</a>, officially to restore order amid the collapse of the Polish state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991222Roberts200643_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991222Roberts200643-473">[465]</a></sup> On 28 September, Germany and the Soviet Union exchanged some of their newly conquered territories; Germany gained the linguistically Polish-dominated areas of Lublin Province and part of Warsaw Province while the Soviets gained Lithuania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991223Service2004402–403Wettig200820_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991223Service2004402–403Wettig200820-474">[466]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German%E2%80%93Soviet_Frontier_Treaty" title="German–Soviet Frontier Treaty">German–Soviet Frontier Treaty</a> was signed shortly after, in Stalin's presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991224_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991224-475">[467]</a></sup> The two states <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nazi%E2%80%93Soviet_economic_relations_(1934%E2%80%9341)" title="Nazi–Soviet economic relations (1934–41)">continued trading</a>, undermining the <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Germany_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="Blockade of Germany (1939–1945)">British blockade of Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991224Service2004405_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991224Service2004405-476">[468]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Soviets further demanded parts of eastern Finland, but the Finnish government refused. The <a href="/wiki/Winter_War" title="Winter War">Soviets invaded Finland</a> in November 1939, yet despite numerical inferiority, the Finns kept the Red Army at bay.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991228Service2004403Khlevniuk2015172–173_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991228Service2004403Khlevniuk2015172–173-477">[469]</a></sup> International opinion backed Finland, with the Soviets being expelled from the League of Nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991279Khlevniuk2015173_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991279Khlevniuk2015173-478">[470]</a></sup> Embarrassed by their inability to defeat the Finns, the Soviets signed an <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Peace_Treaty" title="Moscow Peace Treaty">interim peace treaty</a>, in which they received territorial concessions from Finland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004403Khlevniuk2015173_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004403Khlevniuk2015173-479">[471]</a></sup> In June 1940, the Red Army occupied the Baltic states, which were forcibly <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">merged into the Soviet Union</a> in August;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991227Service2004404–405Wettig200820–21Khlevniuk2015173_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991227Service2004404–405Wettig200820–21Khlevniuk2015173-480">[472]</a></sup> they also invaded and annexed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_northern_Bukovina" title="Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and northern Bukovina">Bessarabia and northern Bukovina</a>, parts of Romania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrackman2001341Khlevniuk2015173_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrackman2001341Khlevniuk2015173-481">[473]</a></sup> The Soviets sought to forestall dissent in these new East European territories with mass repressions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015170_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015170-482">[474]</a></sup> One of the most noted instances was the <a href="/wiki/Katyn_massacre" title="Katyn massacre">Katyn massacre</a> of April and May 1940, in which around 22,000 members of the Polish armed forces, police, and intelligentsia were executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Khlevniuk2015170_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Khlevniuk2015170-483">[475]</a></sup>
</p><p>The speed of the German victory over and occupation of France in mid-1940 took Stalin by surprise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Service2004405_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Service2004405-484">[476]</a></sup> He increasingly focused on appeasement with the Germans to delay any conflict with them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Service2004406_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991229Service2004406-485">[477]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">Tripartite Pact</a> was signed by <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis Powers</a> Germany, Japan, and Italy in October 1940, Stalin proposed that <a href="/wiki/German%E2%80%93Soviet_Axis_talks" title="German–Soviet Axis talks">the USSR also join the Axis alliance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991231Brackman2001341,_343Roberts200658_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991231Brackman2001341,_343Roberts200658-486">[478]</a></sup> To demonstrate peaceful intentions toward Germany, in April 1941 the Soviets signed <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_Neutrality_Pact" title="Soviet–Japanese Neutrality Pact">a neutrality pact</a> with Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991233Roberts200663_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991233Roberts200663-487">[479]</a></sup> Although <i>de facto</i> head of government for a decade and a half, Stalin concluded that relations with Germany had deteriorated to such an extent that he needed to deal with the problem as <i>de jure</i> head of government as well: on 6 May, Stalin replaced Molotov as <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Premier of the Soviet Union">Premier of the Soviet Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991234Khlevniuk2015180_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991234Khlevniuk2015180-488">[480]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1941.E2.80.931942:_German_invasion"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1941–1942:_German_invasion">1941–1942: German invasion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Moscow.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="971" data-file-width="1393" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Battle_of_Moscow.jpg/220px-Battle_of_Moscow.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Battle_of_Moscow.jpg/330px-Battle_of_Moscow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Battle_of_Moscow.jpg/440px-Battle_of_Moscow.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Moscow.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>With all the men at the front, women dig <a href="/wiki/Anti-tank_trench" title="Anti-tank trench">anti-tank trenches</a> around Moscow in 1941</div></div></div>
<p>In June 1941, Germany <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a>, initiating the war on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004410–411Roberts200682Khlevniuk2015198_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004410–411Roberts200682Khlevniuk2015198-489">[481]</a></sup> Despite intelligence agencies repeatedly warning him of Germany's intentions, Stalin was taken by surprise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004408–409,_411–412Roberts200667Khlevniuk2015199–200,_202_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004408–409,_411–412Roberts200667Khlevniuk2015199–200,_202-490">[482]</a></sup> He formed a <a href="/wiki/State_Defense_Committee" title="State Defense Committee">State Defense Committee</a>, which he headed as Supreme Commander,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004414–415Khlevniuk2015206–207_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004414–415Khlevniuk2015206–207-491">[483]</a></sup> as well as a military Supreme Command (<a href="/wiki/Stavka" title="Stavka">Stavka</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004413_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004413-492">[484]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Zhukov" title="Georgy Zhukov">Georgy Zhukov</a> as its Chief of Staff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004420_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004420-493">[485]</a></sup> The German tactic of <i><a href="/wiki/Blitzkrieg" title="Blitzkrieg">blitzkrieg</a></i> was initially highly effective; the Soviet air force in the western borderlands was destroyed within two days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004417Khlevniuk2015201–202_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004417Khlevniuk2015201–202-494">[486]</a></sup> The German <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> pushed deep into Soviet territory;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991235Service2004416_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991235Service2004416-495">[487]</a></sup> soon, Ukraine, Byelorussia, and the Baltic states were under German occupation, and <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad" title="Siege of Leningrad">Leningrad was under siege</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004418_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004418-496">[488]</a></sup> and Soviet refugees were flooding into Moscow and surrounding cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004417_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004417-497">[489]</a></sup> By July, Germany's <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> was bombing Moscow,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004418_496-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004418-496">[488]</a></sup> and by October the Wehrmacht was amassing for a full assault on the capital. Plans were made for the Soviet government to evacuate to <a href="/wiki/Samara" title="Samara">Kuibyshev</a>, although Stalin decided to remain in Moscow, believing his flight would damage troop morale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991248–249Service2004420Khlevniuk2015214–215_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991248–249Service2004420Khlevniuk2015214–215-498">[490]</a></sup> The German advance on Moscow was halted after <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow" title="Battle of Moscow">two months of battle</a> in increasingly harsh weather conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGlantz200126_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGlantz200126-499">[491]</a></sup>
</p><p>Going against the advice of Zhukov and other generals, Stalin emphasised attack over defence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004421,_424Khlevniuk2015220_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004421,_424Khlevniuk2015220-500">[492]</a></sup> In June 1941, he ordered a <a href="/wiki/Scorched_earth" title="Scorched earth">scorched earth</a> policy of destroying infrastructure and food supplies before the Germans could seize them,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004482Roberts200690_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004482Roberts200690-501">[493]</a></sup> also commanding the <a href="/wiki/NKVD_prisoner_massacres" title="NKVD prisoner massacres">NKVD to kill</a> around 100,000 political prisoners in areas the Wehrmacht approached.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGellately2007391_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGellately2007391-502">[494]</a></sup> He purged the military command; several high-ranking figures were demoted or reassigned and others were arrested and executed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991239–240Roberts200698Khlevniuk2015209_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991239–240Roberts200698Khlevniuk2015209-503">[495]</a></sup> With <a href="/wiki/Order_No._270" title="Order No. 270">Order No. 270</a>, Stalin commanded soldiers risking capture to fight to the death describing the captured as traitors;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991241Khlevniuk2015210_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991241Khlevniuk2015210-504">[496]</a></sup> among those taken as a <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">prisoner of war</a> by the Germans was Stalin's son Yakov, who died in their custody.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991241–242Service2004521_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991241–242Service2004521-505">[497]</a></sup> Stalin issued <a href="/wiki/Order_No._227" title="Order No. 227">Order No. 227</a> in July 1942, which directed that those retreating unauthorised would be placed in "penal battalions" used as <a href="/wiki/Cannon_fodder" title="Cannon fodder">cannon fodder</a> on the front lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006132Khlevniuk2015223_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006132Khlevniuk2015223-506">[498]</a></sup> Amid the fighting, both the German and Soviet armies disregarded the <a href="/wiki/Law_of_war" title="Law of war">law of war</a> set forth in the <a href="/wiki/Geneva_Conventions" title="Geneva Conventions">Geneva Conventions</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004423_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004423-507">[499]</a></sup> the Soviets heavily publicised Nazi massacres of communists, Jews, and <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Romani</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004422_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004422-508">[500]</a></sup> Stalin exploited Nazi anti-Semitism, and in April 1942 he sponsored the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Anti-Fascist_Committee" title="Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee">Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee</a> (JAC) to garner Jewish and foreign support for the Soviet war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOvery2004568_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOvery2004568-509">[501]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3543" data-file-width="5332" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_602161_Center_of_Stalingrad_after_liberation.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The center of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stalingrad" title="Stalingrad">Stalingrad</a> after liberation, 2 February 1943</div></div></div>
<p>The Soviets allied with the United Kingdom and United States;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015211_510-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015211-510">[502]</a></sup> although the U.S. joined the war against Germany in 1941, little direct American assistance reached the Soviets until late 1942.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004423_507-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004423-507">[499]</a></sup> Responding to the invasion, the Soviets intensified their industrial enterprises in central Russia, focusing almost entirely on production for the military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004421_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004421-511">[503]</a></sup> They achieved high levels of industrial productivity, outstripping that of Germany.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004422_508-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004422-508">[500]</a></sup> During the war, Stalin was more tolerant of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>, allowing it to resume some of its activities and meeting with <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Sergius_of_Moscow" title="Patriarch Sergius of Moscow">Patriarch Sergius</a> in September 1943.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004442–443Khlevniuk2015242–243_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004442–443Khlevniuk2015242–243-512">[504]</a></sup> He also permitted a wider range of cultural expression, notably permitting formerly suppressed writers and artists like <a href="/wiki/Anna_Akhmatova" title="Anna Akhmatova">Anna Akhmatova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Shostakovich" title="Dmitri Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a> to disperse their work more widely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004441_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004441-513">[505]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Internationale" title="The Internationale">The Internationale</a> was dropped as the country's <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">national anthem</a>, to be replaced with <a href="/wiki/State_Anthem_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="State Anthem of the Soviet Union">a more patriotic song</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004442_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004442-514">[506]</a></sup> The government increasingly promoted <a href="/wiki/Pan-Slavism" title="Pan-Slavism">Pan-Slavist</a> sentiment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004446_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004446-515">[507]</a></sup> while encouraging increased criticism of <a href="/wiki/Cosmopolitanism" title="Cosmopolitanism">cosmopolitanism</a>, particularly the idea of "rootless cosmopolitanism", an approach with particular repercussions for Soviet Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004446–447_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004446–447-516">[508]</a></sup> Comintern was dissolved in 1943,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991260Service2004444_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991260Service2004444-517">[509]</a></sup> and Stalin encouraged foreign Marxist–Leninist parties to emphasise nationalism over internationalism to broaden their domestic appeal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004446_515-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004446-515">[507]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 1942, Stalin overrode Stavka by ordering the Soviets' first serious counter-attack, an attempt to seize German-held <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a> in eastern Ukraine. This attack proved unsuccessful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991254Service2004424Khlevniuk2015221–222_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991254Service2004424Khlevniuk2015221–222-518">[510]</a></sup> That year, Hitler shifted his primary goal from an overall victory on the Eastern Front, to the goal of securing the oil fields in the southern Soviet Union crucial to a long-term German war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006117–118_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006117–118-519">[511]</a></sup> While Red Army generals saw evidence that Hitler would shift efforts south, Stalin considered this to be a flanking move in a renewed effort to take Moscow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006124_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006124-520">[512]</a></sup> In June 1942, the German Army began a <a href="/wiki/Case_Blue" title="Case Blue">major offensive</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Russia" title="Southern Russia">Southern Russia</a>, threatening Stalingrad; Stalin ordered the Red Army to hold the city at all costs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004425_521-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004425-521">[513]</a></sup> This resulted in the protracted <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004426_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004426-522">[514]</a></sup> In December 1942, he placed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Konstantin_Rokossovski" title="Konstantin Rokossovski">Konstantin Rokossovski</a> in charge of holding the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004427_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004427-523">[515]</a></sup> In February 1943, the German troops attacking Stalingrad surrendered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004428Khlevniuk2015225_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004428Khlevniuk2015225-524">[516]</a></sup> The Soviet victory there marked a major turning point in the war;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015225_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015225-525">[517]</a></sup> in commemoration, Stalin declared himself <a href="/wiki/Marshal_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Marshal of the Soviet Union">Marshal of the Soviet Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004429Khlevniuk2015226_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004429Khlevniuk2015226-526">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[519]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1942.E2.80.931945:_Soviet_counter-attack"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1942–1945:_Soviet_counter-attack">1942–1945: Soviet counter-attack</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:227px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teheran_conference-1943.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4602" data-file-width="5805" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/225px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/338px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/450px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teheran_conference-1943.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Big Three: Stalin, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">British Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">Tehran Conference</a>, November 1943</div></div></div>
<p>By November 1942, the Soviets had begun to repulse the important German strategic southern campaign and, although there were 2.5 million Soviet casualties in that effort, it permitted the Soviets to take the offensive for most of the rest of the war on the Eastern Front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006155_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006155-528">[520]</a></sup> Germany <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk" title="Battle of Kursk">attempted an encirclement attack at Kursk</a>, which was successfully repulsed by the Soviets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991255Roberts2006156Khlevniuk2015227_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991255Roberts2006156Khlevniuk2015227-529">[521]</a></sup> By the end of 1943, the Soviets occupied half of the territory taken by the Germans from 1941 to 1942.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006159_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006159-530">[522]</a></sup> Soviet military industrial output also had increased substantially from late 1941 to early 1943 after Stalin had moved factories well to the east of the front, safe from German invasion and aerial assault.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006163_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006163-531">[523]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Allied countries, Stalin was increasingly depicted in a positive light over the course of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004452_532-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004452-532">[524]</a></sup> In 1941, the <a href="/wiki/London_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="London Philharmonic Orchestra">London Philharmonic Orchestra</a> performed a concert to celebrate his birthday,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004466_533-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004466-533">[525]</a></sup> and in 1942, <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine named him "<a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year">Man of the Year</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004452_532-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004452-532">[524]</a></sup> When Stalin learned that people in Western countries affectionately called him "Uncle Joe" he was initially offended, regarding it as undignified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991317Service2004466_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991317Service2004466-534">[526]</a></sup> There remained mutual suspicions between Stalin, British Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, and U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, who were together known as the "Big Three".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004458_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004458-535">[527]</a></sup> Churchill flew to Moscow to visit Stalin in August 1942 and again in October 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991252Service2004460224,_244Khlevniuk2015_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991252Service2004460224,_244Khlevniuk2015-536">[528]</a></sup> Stalin scarcely left Moscow throughout the war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004456_537-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004456-537">[529]</a></sup> with Roosevelt and Churchill frustrated with his reluctance to travel to meet them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004460_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004460-538">[530]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1943, Stalin met with Churchill and Roosevelt <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">in Tehran</a>, a location of Stalin's choosing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991262Service2004460Roberts2006180Khlevniuk2015229–230_539-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991262Service2004460Roberts2006180Khlevniuk2015229–230-539">[531]</a></sup> There, Stalin and Roosevelt got on well, with both desiring the post-war dismantling of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004462_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004462-540">[532]</a></sup> At Tehran, the trio agreed that to prevent Germany rising to military prowess yet again, the German state should be broken up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004463_541-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004463-541">[533]</a></sup> Roosevelt and Churchill also agreed to Stalin's demand that the German city of <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6nigsberg" title="Königsberg">Königsberg</a> be declared Soviet territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004463_541-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004463-541">[533]</a></sup> Stalin was impatient for the UK and U.S. to open up a <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Western Front (World War II)">Western Front</a> to take the pressure off of the East; they eventually did so in mid-1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991244,_251Service2004461,_469Roberts2006185Khlevniuk2015223,_229_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991244,_251Service2004461,_469Roberts2006185Khlevniuk2015223,_229-542">[534]</a></sup> Stalin insisted that, after the war, the Soviet Union should incorporate the portions of Poland it occupied pursuant to the Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact with Germany, which Churchill opposed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006186–187_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006186–187-543">[535]</a></sup> Discussing the fate of the Balkans, later in 1944 Churchill agreed to Stalin's suggestion that after the war, Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, and Yugoslavia would come under the Soviet sphere of influence while Greece would come under that of the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004464–465Khlevniuk2015244_544-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004464–465Khlevniuk2015244-544">[536]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_soldiers_in_Polozk_(Belarus),_passing_by_propaganda_poster_celebrating_the_reconquest_of_the_city_and_urging_the_liberation_of_the_Baltic_from_Nazi_German_occupation._July_4,_1944.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="597" data-file-width="797" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Soviet_soldiers_in_Polozk_%28Belarus%29%2C_passing_by_propaganda_poster_celebrating_the_reconquest_of_the_city_and_urging_the_liberation_of_the_Baltic_from_Nazi_German_occupation._July_4%2C_1944.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Soviet_soldiers_in_Polozk_%28Belarus%29%2C_passing_by_propaganda_poster_celebrating_the_reconquest_of_the_city_and_urging_the_liberation_of_the_Baltic_from_Nazi_German_occupation._July_4%2C_1944.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Soviet_soldiers_in_Polozk_%28Belarus%29%2C_passing_by_propaganda_poster_celebrating_the_reconquest_of_the_city_and_urging_the_liberation_of_the_Baltic_from_Nazi_German_occupation._July_4%2C_1944.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Soviet_soldiers_in_Polozk_(Belarus),_passing_by_propaganda_poster_celebrating_the_reconquest_of_the_city_and_urging_the_liberation_of_the_Baltic_from_Nazi_German_occupation._July_4,_1944.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Soviet soldiers in <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">Polotsk</a>, 4 July 1944</div></div></div>
