<p>In 1944, the Soviet Union made significant advances across Eastern Europe toward Germany,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006194–195_545-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006194–195-545">[537]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Operation_Bagration" title="Operation Bagration">Operation Bagration</a>, a massive offensive in the <a href="/wiki/Byelorussian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic">Byelorussian SSR</a> against the German Army Group Centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004469Roberts2006199–201_546-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004469Roberts2006199–201-546">[538]</a></sup> In 1944 the German armies were pushed out of the Baltic states (with the exception of the <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ostland" title="Reichskommissariat Ostland">Ostland</a>), which were then re-annexed into the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004492_547-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004492-547">[539]</a></sup> As the Red Army reconquered the Caucasus and Crimea, various ethnic groups living in the region—the <a href="/wiki/Kalmyks" title="Kalmyks">Kalmyks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chechens" title="Chechens">Chechens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ingush_people" title="Ingush people">Ingushi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karachai" title="Karachai">Karachai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balkars" title="Balkars">Balkars</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a>—were accused of having collaborated with the Germans. Using the idea of <a href="/wiki/Collective_responsibility" title="Collective responsibility">collective responsibility</a> as a basis, Stalin's government abolished their autonomous republics and between late 1943 and 1944 deported the majority of their populations to Central Asia and Siberia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991258Service2004492Khlevniuk2015232–233_548-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991258Service2004492Khlevniuk2015232–233-548">[540]</a></sup> Over one million people were deported as a result of the policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015233_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015233-549">[541]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 1945, the three leaders met at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991264Service2004465Khlevniuk2015244_550-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991264Service2004465Khlevniuk2015244-550">[542]</a></sup> Roosevelt and Churchill conceded to Stalin's demand that Germany pay the Soviet Union 20 billion dollars in reparations, and that his country be permitted to annexe <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurile_Islands" title="Kurile Islands">Kuril Islands</a> in exchange for entering the war against Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004465–466_551-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004465–466-551">[543]</a></sup> An agreement was also made that a post-war Polish government should be a coalition consisting of both communist and conservative elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004465–466Roberts2006241–244_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004465–466Roberts2006241–244-552">[544]</a></sup> Privately, Stalin sought to ensure that Poland would come fully under Soviet influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004471Khlevniuk2015245_553-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004471Khlevniuk2015245-553">[545]</a></sup> The Red Army withheld assistance to Polish resistance fighters battling the Germans in the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising" title="Warsaw Uprising">Warsaw Uprising</a>, with Stalin believing that any victorious Polish militants could interfere with his aspirations to dominate Poland through a future Marxist government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004471–472Khlevniuk2015244_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004471–472Khlevniuk2015244-554">[546]</a></sup> Although concealing his desires from the other Allied leaders, Stalin placed great emphasis on capturing Berlin first, believing that this would enable him to bring more of Europe under long-term Soviet control. Churchill was concerned that this was the case and unsuccessfully tried to convince the U.S. that the Western Allies should pursue the same goal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004473_555-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004473-555">[547]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1945:_Victory">1945: Victory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2008" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg/220px-Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg/330px-Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg/440px-Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Potsdam_conference_1945-8.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">British Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Clement_Attlee" title="Clement Attlee">Clement Attlee</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> and Joseph Stalin at the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">Potsdam Conference</a>, July 1945</div></div></div>
<p>In April 1945, the Red Army <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">seized Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Adolf_Hitler" title="Death of Adolf Hitler">Hitler committed suicide</a>, and Germany surrendered in May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004474Khlevniuk2015247_556-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004474Khlevniuk2015247-556">[548]</a></sup> Stalin had wanted Hitler captured alive; he had his remains brought to Moscow to prevent them becoming a relic for Nazi sympathisers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004479–480_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004479–480-557">[549]</a></sup> As the Red Army had conquered German territory, they discovered the <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camp" title="Extermination camp">extermination camps</a> that the Nazi administration had run.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004473_555-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004473-555">[547]</a></sup> Many Soviet soldiers engaged in looting, pillaging, and rape, both in Germany and parts of Eastern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991265Service2004473Khlevniuk2015234_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991265Service2004473Khlevniuk2015234-558">[550]</a></sup> Stalin refused to punish the offenders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004473_555-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004473-555">[547]</a></sup> After receiving a complaint about this from Yugoslav communist <a href="/wiki/Milovan_Djilas" title="Milovan Djilas">Milovan Djilas</a>, Stalin asked how after experiencing the traumas of war a soldier could "react normally? And what is so awful in his having fun with a woman, after such horrors?"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991265–266Service2004473Khlevniuk2015235_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991265–266Service2004473Khlevniuk2015235-559">[551]</a></sup>
</p><p>With Germany defeated, Stalin switched focus to the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War" title="Soviet–Japanese War">war with Japan</a>, transferring half a million troops to the Far East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004474_560-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004474-560">[552]</a></sup> Stalin was pressed by his allies to enter the war and wanted to cement the Soviet Union's strategic position in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGlantz1983_561-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGlantz1983-561">[553]</a></sup> On 8 August, in between the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki</a>, the Soviet army <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Soviet invasion of Manchuria">invaded Japanese-occupied Manchuria</a> and defeated the <a href="/wiki/Kwantung_Army" title="Kwantung Army">Kwantung Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004476Khlevniuk2015248–249_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004476Khlevniuk2015248–249-562">[554]</a></sup> These events led to the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">Japanese surrender</a> and the war's end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991268Khlevniuk2015248_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991268Khlevniuk2015248-563">[555]</a></sup> Soviet forces continued to expand until they occupied all their territorial concessions, but the U.S. rebuffed Stalin's desire for the Red Army to take a role in the Allied <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan" title="Occupation of Japan">occupation of Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991267Khlevniuk2015249_564-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991267Khlevniuk2015249-564">[556]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin attended the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">Potsdam Conference</a> in July–August 1945, alongside his new British and U.S. counterparts, Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Clement_Attlee" title="Clement Attlee">Clement Attlee</a> and President <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry Truman</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991267Service2004475_565-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991267Service2004475-565">[557]</a></sup> At the conference, Stalin repeated previous promises to Churchill that he would refrain from a "Sovietization" of Eastern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts2006274–275_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts2006274–275-566">[558]</a></sup> Stalin pushed for reparations from Germany without regard to the base minimum supply for German citizens' survival, which worried Truman and Churchill who thought that Germany would become a financial burden for Western powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWettig200890–91_567-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWettig200890–91-567">[559]</a></sup> He also pushed for "war booty", which would permit the Soviet Union to directly seize property from conquered nations without quantitative or qualitative limitation, and a clause was added permitting this to occur with some limitations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWettig200890–91_567-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWettig200890–91-567">[559]</a></sup> Germany was divided into four zones: Soviet, U.S., British, and French, with Berlin itself—located within the Soviet area—also subdivided thusly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004506_568-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004506-568">[560]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-war_era_and_death">Post-war era and death</span></h2>
<h3><span id="1945.E2.80.931947:_Post-war_reconstruction_and_famine"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1945–1947:_Post-war_reconstruction_and_famine">1945–1947: Post-war reconstruction and famine</span></h3>
<p>After the war, Stalin was—according to Service—at the "apex of his career".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004481_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004481-569">[561]</a></sup> Within the Soviet Union he was widely regarded as the embodiment of victory and patriotism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004484_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004484-570">[562]</a></sup> His armies controlled <a href="/wiki/Central_and_Eastern_Europe" title="Central and Eastern Europe">Central and Eastern Europe</a> up to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Elbe" title="River Elbe">River Elbe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004481_569-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004481-569">[561]</a></sup> In June 1945, Stalin adopted the title of <a href="/wiki/Generalissimus_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Generalissimus of the Soviet Union">Generalissimus</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004493Khlevniuk2015247_571-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004493Khlevniuk2015247-571">[563]</a></sup> and stood atop Lenin's Mausoleum to watch a <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Victory_Parade_of_1945" title="Moscow Victory Parade of 1945">celebratory parade</a> led by Zhukov through Red Square.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004480–481_572-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004480–481-572">[564]</a></sup> At a banquet held for army commanders, he described the Russian people as "the outstanding nation" and "leading force" within the Soviet Union, the first time that he had unequivocally endorsed the Russians over other Soviet nationalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004479_573-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004479-573">[565]</a></sup> In 1946, the state published Stalin's <i>Collected Works</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004541_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004541-574">[566]</a></sup> In 1947, it brought out a second edition of his official biography, which eulogised him to a greater extent than its predecessor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004543–544_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004543–544-575">[567]</a></sup> He was quoted in <i>Pravda</i> on a daily basis and pictures of him remained pervasive on the walls of workplaces and homes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004548_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004548-576">[568]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376,_Budapest,_II._Weltfestspiele,_Festumzug,_Komsomolzen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="763" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="259" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg/170px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg/255px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg/340px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376%2C_Budapest%2C_II._Weltfestspiele%2C_Festumzug%2C_Komsomolzen.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R78376,_Budapest,_II._Weltfestspiele,_Festumzug,_Komsomolzen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Banner of Stalin in Budapest in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>Despite his strengthened international position, Stalin was cautious about internal dissent and desire for change among the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004485Khlevniuk2015262_577-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004485Khlevniuk2015262-577">[569]</a></sup> He was also concerned about his returning armies, who had been exposed to a wide range of consumer goods in Germany, much of which they had looted and brought back with them. In this he recalled the 1825 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decembrist_Revolt" title="Decembrist Revolt">Decembrist Revolt</a> by Russian soldiers returning from having defeated France in the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004485_578-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004485-578">[570]</a></sup> He ensured that returning Soviet prisoners of war went through "filtration" camps as they arrived in the Soviet Union, in which 2,775,700 were interrogated to determine if they were traitors. About half were then imprisoned in labour camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004493Roberts2006202_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004493Roberts2006202-579">[571]</a></sup> In the Baltic states, where there was much opposition to Soviet rule, de-kulakisation and de-clericalisation programs were initiated, resulting in 142,000 deportations between 1945 and 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004492_547-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004492-547">[539]</a></sup> The Gulag system of forced labour camps was expanded further. By January 1953, three per cent of the Soviet population was imprisoned or in internal exile, with 2.8 million in "special settlements" in isolated areas and another 2.5 million in camps, penal colonies, and prisons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015268_580-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015268-580">[572]</a></sup>
</p><p>The NKVD were ordered to catalogue the scale of destruction during the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004482_581-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004482-581">[573]</a></sup> It was established that 1,710 Soviet towns and 70,000 villages had been destroyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004482–483_582-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004482–483-582">[574]</a></sup> The NKVD recorded that <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">between 26 and 27 million Soviet citizens had been killed</a>, with millions more being wounded, malnourished, or orphaned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004482Khlevniuk2015261_583-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004482Khlevniuk2015261-583">[575]</a></sup> In the war's aftermath, some of Stalin's associates suggested modifications to government policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004500_584-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004500-584">[576]</a></sup> Post-war Soviet society was more tolerant than its pre-war phase in various respects. Stalin allowed the Russian Orthodox Church to retain the churches it had opened during the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004496_585-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004496-585">[577]</a></sup> Academia and the arts were also allowed greater freedom than they had prior to 1941.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004497_586-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004497-586">[578]</a></sup> Recognising the need for drastic steps to be taken to combat inflation and promote economic regeneration, in December 1947 Stalin's government devalued the ruble and abolished the ration-book system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004497Khlevniuk2015274–278_587-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004497Khlevniuk2015274–278-587">[579]</a></sup> Capital punishment was abolished in 1947 but re-instituted in 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991289_588-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991289-588">[580]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin's health was deteriorating, and heart problems forced a two-month vacation in the latter part of 1945.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991269Service2004491_589-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991269Service2004491-589">[581]</a></sup> He grew increasingly concerned that senior political and military figures might try to oust him; he prevented any of them from becoming powerful enough to rival him and had their apartments bugged with listening devices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004526Khlevniuk2015268_590-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004526Khlevniuk2015268-590">[582]</a></sup> He demoted Molotov,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004531–532Khlevniuk2015272–273_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004531–532Khlevniuk2015272–273-591">[583]</a></sup> and increasingly favoured Beria and Malenkov for key positions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004534_592-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004534-592">[584]</a></sup> In 1949, he brought <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> from Ukraine to Moscow, appointing him a Central Committee secretary and the head of the city's party branch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015303_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015303-593">[585]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leningrad_Affair" title="Leningrad Affair">Leningrad Affair</a>, the city's leadership was purged amid accusations of treachery; executions of many of the accused took place in 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004534–535Khlevniuk2015282_594-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004534–535Khlevniuk2015282-594">[586]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the post-war period there were often food shortages in Soviet cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015300–301_595-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015300–301-595">[587]</a></sup> and the USSR experienced a major <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1946%E2%80%9347" title="Soviet famine of 1946–47">famine from 1946 to 1947</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004498Khlevniuk2015261_596-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004498Khlevniuk2015261-596">[588]</a></sup> Sparked by a drought and ensuing bad harvest in 1946, it was exacerbated by government policy towards food procurement, including the state's decision to build up stocks and export food internationally rather than distributing it to famine hit areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2000611,_618–620_597-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2000611,_618–620-597">[589]</a></sup> Current estimates indicate that between one million and 1.5 million people died from malnutrition or disease as a result.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman2000622Khlevniuk2015261_598-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman2000622Khlevniuk2015261-598">[590]</a></sup> While agricultural production stagnated, Stalin focused on a series of major infrastructure projects, including the construction of hydroelectric plants, canals, and railway lines running to the polar north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015299_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015299-599">[591]</a></sup> Much of this was constructed by prison labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015299_599-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015299-599">[591]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1947.E2.80.931950:_Cold_War_policy"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1947–1950:_Cold_War_policy">1947–1950: Cold War policy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:227px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mao,_Bulganin,_Stalin,_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1092" data-file-width="1663" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg/225px-Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg/338px-Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg/450px-Mao%2C_Bulganin%2C_Stalin%2C_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg 2x" width="225"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mao,_Bulganin,_Stalin,_Ulbricht_Tsedenbal.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Joseph Stalin at his 71st birthday celebration with (left to right) <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Bulganin" title="Nikolai Bulganin">Nikolai Bulganin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Ulbricht" title="Walter Ulbricht">Walter Ulbricht</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yumjaagiin_Tsedenbal" title="Yumjaagiin Tsedenbal">Yumjaagiin Tsedenbal</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the aftermath of the Second World War, the British Empire declined, leaving the U.S. and USSR as the dominant world powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004502–503_600-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004502–503-600">[592]</a></sup> Tensions among these former Allies grew,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004484_570-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004484-570">[562]</a></sup> resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004503_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004503-601">[593]</a></sup> Although Stalin publicly described the British and U.S. governments as aggressive, he thought it unlikely that a war with them would be imminent, believing that several decades of peace was likely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004487_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004487-602">[594]</a></sup> He nevertheless secretly intensified Soviet research into nuclear weaponry, intent on creating an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atom_bomb" title="Atom bomb">atom bomb</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004481_569-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004481-569">[561]</a></sup> Still, Stalin foresaw the undesirability of a nuclear conflict, saying in 1949 that "atomic weapons can hardly be used without spelling the end of the world."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaddis200557_603-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis200557-603">[595]</a></sup> He personally took a keen interest in the development of the weapon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004508_604-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004508-604">[596]</a></sup> In August 1949, the bomb was successfully tested in the <a href="/wiki/Semipalatinsk_Test_Site" title="Semipalatinsk Test Site">deserts outside Semipalatinsk</a> in Kazakhstan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004508Khlevniuk2015293_605-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004508Khlevniuk2015293-605">[597]</a></sup> Stalin also initiated a new military build-up; the Soviet army was expanded from 2.9 million soldiers, as it stood in 1949, to 5.8 million by 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015297_606-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015297-606">[598]</a></sup>
</p><p>The US began pushing its interests on every continent, acquiring air force bases in Africa and Asia and ensuring pro-U.S. regimes took power across Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004502_607-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004502-607">[599]</a></sup> It launched the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> in June 1947, with which it sought to undermine Soviet hegemony in eastern Europe. The US also offered financial assistance to countries as part of the Marshall Plan on the condition that they opened their markets to trade, aware that the Soviets would never agree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004504Khlevniuk2015267_608-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004504Khlevniuk2015267-608">[600]</a></sup>
The Allies demanded that Stalin withdraw the Red Army from northern Iran. He initially refused, leading to an <a href="/wiki/Iran_crisis_of_1946" title="Iran crisis of 1946">international crisis in 1946</a>, but one year later Stalin finally relented and moved the Soviet troops out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004504_609-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004504-609">[601]</a></sup> Stalin also tried to maximise Soviet influence on the world stage, unsuccessfully pushing for Libya—recently liberated from Italian occupation—to become a Soviet protectorate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004494_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004494-610">[602]</a></sup> He sent Molotov as his representative to <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> to take part in negotiations to form the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, insisting that the Soviets have a place on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Security_Council" title="Security Council">Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004503_601-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004503-601">[593]</a></sup> In April 1949, the Western powers established the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">North Atlantic Treaty Organisation</a> (NATO), an international military alliance of capitalist countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004507Khlevniuk2015281_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004507Khlevniuk2015281-611">[603]</a></sup> Within Western countries, Stalin was increasingly portrayed as the "most evil dictator alive" and compared to Hitler.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004551_612-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004551-612">[604]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1948, Stalin edited and rewrote sections of <i><a href="/wiki/Falsifiers_of_History" title="Falsifiers of History">Falsifiers of History</a></i>, published as a series of <i>Pravda</i> articles in February 1948 and then in book form. Written in response to public revelations of the 1939 Soviet alliance with Germany, it focused on blaming Western powers for the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts200296–98_613-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts200296–98-613">[605]</a></sup> He erroneously claimed that the initial German advance in the early part of the war was not a result of Soviet military weakness, but rather a deliberate Soviet strategic retreat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015264_614-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015264-614">[606]</a></sup> In 1949, celebrations took place to mark Stalin's seventieth birthday (although he was 71 at the time,) at which Stalin attended an event in the <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theatre" title="Bolshoi Theatre">Bolshoi Theatre</a> alongside Marxist–Leninist leaders from across Europe and Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991296Service2004548–549Khlevniuk2015290_615-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991296Service2004548–549Khlevniuk2015290-615">[607]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_Bloc">Eastern Bloc</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="333" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg/220px-EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg/330px-EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg/440px-EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EasternBloc_BasicMembersOnly.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> until 1989</div></div></div>
<p>After the war, Stalin sought to retain Soviet dominance across Eastern Europe while expanding its influence in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004492_547-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004492-547">[539]</a></sup> Cautiously regarding the responses from the Western Allies, Stalin avoided immediately installing Communist Party governments across Eastern Europe, instead initially ensuring that Marxist-Leninists were placed in coalition ministries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004494_610-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004494-610">[602]</a></sup> In contrast to his approach to the Baltic states, he rejected the proposal of merging the new communist states into the Soviet Union, rather recognising them as independent nation-states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004517_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004517-616">[608]</a></sup>
He was faced with the problem that there were few Marxists left in Eastern Europe, with most having been killed by the Nazis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004483_617-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004483-617">[609]</a></sup> He demanded that war reparations be paid by Germany and its Axis allies Hungary, Romania, and the <a href="/wiki/Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945)" title="Slovak Republic (1939–1945)">Slovak Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004484_570-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004484-570">[562]</a></sup> Aware that these countries had been pushed toward socialism through invasion rather than by proletarian revolution, Stalin referred to them not as "dictatorships of the proletariat" but as "people's democracies", suggesting that in these countries there was a pro-socialist alliance combining the proletariat, peasantry, and lower middle-class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004518_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004518-618">[610]</a></sup>
</p><p>Churchill observed that an "<a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a>" had been drawn across Europe, separating the east from the west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991279Service2004503_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991279Service2004503-619">[611]</a></sup> In September 1947, a meeting of East European communist leaders was held in <a href="/wiki/Szklarska_Por%C4%99ba" title="Szklarska Poręba">Szklarska Poręba</a>, Poland, from which was formed <a href="/wiki/Cominform" title="Cominform">Cominform</a> to co-ordinate the Communist Parties across Eastern Europe and also in France and Italy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991286Service2004506Khlevniuk2015267_620-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991286Service2004506Khlevniuk2015267-620">[612]</a></sup> Stalin did not personally attend the meeting, sending <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Zhdanov" title="Andrei Zhdanov">Zhdanov</a> in his place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004506_568-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004506-568">[560]</a></sup> Various East European communists also visited Stalin in Moscow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004511_621-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004511-621">[613]</a></sup> There, he offered advice on their ideas; for instance he cautioned against the Yugoslav idea for a Balkan federation incorporating Bulgaria and Albania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004511_621-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004511-621">[613]</a></sup> Stalin had a particularly strained relationship with Yugoslav leader <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> due to the latter's continued calls for Balkan federation and for Soviet aid for the communist forces in the ongoing <a href="/wiki/Greek_Civil_War" title="Greek Civil War">Greek Civil War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991286–287Service2004515_622-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991286–287Service2004515-622">[614]</a></sup> In March 1948, Stalin launched an anti-Tito campaign, accusing the Yugoslav communists of adventurism and deviating from Marxist–Leninist doctrine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004515_623-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004515-623">[615]</a></sup> At the second Cominform conference, held in Bucharest in June 1948, East European communist leaders all denounced Tito's government, accusing them of being fascists and agents of Western capitalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004516_624-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004516-624">[616]</a></sup> Stalin ordered several assassination attempts on Tito's life and contemplated invading Yugoslavia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991287_625-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991287-625">[617]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin suggested that a unified, but demilitarised, German state be established, hoping that it would either come under Soviet influence or remain neutral.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004507_626-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004507-626">[618]</a></sup> When the US and UK remained opposed to this, Stalin sought to force their hand by <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Blockade" title="Berlin Blockade">blockading Berlin</a> in June 1948.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991280Service2004507Khlevniuk2015281_627-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991280Service2004507Khlevniuk2015281-627">[619]</a></sup> He gambled that the others would not risk war, but they airlifted supplies into West Berlin until May 1949, when Stalin relented and ended the blockade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004507Khlevniuk2015281_611-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004507Khlevniuk2015281-611">[603]</a></sup> In September 1949 the Western powers transformed Western Germany into an independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Germany" title="Federal Republic of Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a>; in response the Soviets formed East Germany into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_Democratic_Republic" title="German Democratic Republic">German Democratic Republic</a> in October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004507_626-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004507-626">[618]</a></sup> In accordance with their earlier agreements, the Western powers expected Poland to become an independent state with free democratic elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004476_628-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004476-628">[620]</a></sup> In Poland, the Soviets merged various socialist parties into the <a href="/wiki/Polish_United_Workers%27_Party" title="Polish United Workers' Party">Polish United Workers' Party</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">vote rigging</a> was used to ensure that it secured office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004515_623-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004515-623">[615]</a></sup> The 1947 Hungarian elections were also rigged, with the <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Working_People%27s_Party" title="Hungarian Working People's Party">Hungarian Working People's Party</a> taking control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004515_623-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004515-623">[615]</a></sup> In Czechoslovakia, where the communists did have a level of popular support, they were elected the largest party in 1946.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004512,_513_629-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004512,_513-629">[621]</a></sup> Monarchy was abolished in Bulgaria and Romania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004513_630-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004513-630">[622]</a></sup> Across Eastern Europe, the Soviet model was enforced, with a termination of political pluralism, agricultural collectivisation, and investment in heavy industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004516_624-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004516-624">[616]</a></sup> It was aimed for economic <a href="/wiki/Autarky" title="Autarky">autarky</a> within the Eastern Bloc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004516_624-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004516-624">[616]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asia">Asia</span></h4>
<p>In October 1949, Chinese Communist leader <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> took power in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991301Service2004509Khlevniuk2015286_631-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991301Service2004509Khlevniuk2015286-631">[623]</a></sup> With this accomplished, Marxist governments now controlled a third of the world's land mass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004509_632-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004509-632">[624]</a></sup> Privately, Stalin revealed that he had underestimated the Chinese Communists and their ability to win the civil war, instead encouraging them to make another peace with the KMT.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004553_633-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004553-633">[625]</a></sup> In December 1949, Mao visited Stalin. Initially Stalin refused to repeal the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Alliance" title="Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance">Sino-Soviet Treaty of 1945</a>, which significantly benefited the Soviet Union over China, although in January 1950 he relented and agreed to sign <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship,_Alliance_and_Mutual_Assistance" title="Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance and Mutual Assistance">a new treaty between the two countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004509Khlevniuk2015287–291_634-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004509Khlevniuk2015287–291-634">[626]</a></sup> Stalin was concerned that Mao might follow Tito's example by pursuing a course independent of Soviet influence, and made it known that if displeased he would withdraw assistance from China; the Chinese desperately needed said assistance after decades of civil war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004552Khlevniuk2015287_635-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004552Khlevniuk2015287-635">[627]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the end of the Second World War, the Soviet Union and the United States divided up the Korean Peninsula, formerly a Japanese colonial possession, along the <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">38th parallel</a>, setting up a communist government in the north and a pro-Western government in the south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004552Khlevniuk2015294_636-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004552Khlevniuk2015294-636">[628]</a></sup> North Korean leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a> visited Stalin in March 1949 and again in March 1950; he wanted to invade the south and although Stalin was initially reluctant to provide support, he eventually agreed by May 1950.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991302Service2004553Khlevniuk2015294–295_637-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991302Service2004553Khlevniuk2015294–295-637">[629]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Army" title="Korean People's Army">North Korean Army</a> launched the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> by invading the south in June 1950, making swift gains and capturing <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004554_638-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004554-638">[630]</a></sup> Both Stalin and Mao believed that a swift victory would ensue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004554_638-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004554-638">[630]</a></sup> The U.S. went to the UN Security Council—which the Soviets were boycotting over its refusal to recognise Mao's government—and secured military support for the South Koreans. U.S. led forces pushed the North Koreans back.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004554Khlevniuk2015295–296_639-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004554Khlevniuk2015295–296-639">[631]</a></sup> Stalin wanted to avoid direct Soviet conflict with the U.S., convincing the Chinese to aid the North.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004555–556Khlevniuk2015296_640-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004555–556Khlevniuk2015296-640">[632]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Soviet Union was one of the first nations to extend diplomatic recognition to the newly created <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Israel" title="State of Israel">state of Israel</a> in 1948, in hopes of obtaining an ally in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYegorov,_15_December_2017_641-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYegorov,_15_December_2017-641">[633]</a></sup> When the Israeli ambassador <a href="/wiki/Golda_Meir" title="Golda Meir">Golda Meir</a> arrived in the USSR, Stalin was angered by the Jewish crowds who gathered to greet her.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291_642-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291-642">[634]</a></sup> He was further angered by Israel's <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Israel–United States relations">growing alliance with the U.S.</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015285_643-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015285-643">[635]</a></sup> After Stalin fell out with Israel, he launched an anti-Jewish campaign within the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004518_618-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004518-618">[610]</a></sup> In November 1948, he abolished the JAC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291Service2004577Khlevniuk2015284_644-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291Service2004577Khlevniuk2015284-644">[636]</a></sup> and show trials took place for some of its members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991567Brackman2001384–385_645-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991567Brackman2001384–385-645">[637]</a></sup> The Soviet press engaged in attacks on <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>, Jewish culture, and "rootless cosmopolitanism",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291Khlevniuk2015308–309_646-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991291Khlevniuk2015308–309-646">[638]</a></sup> with growing levels of anti-Semitism being expressed across Soviet society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004576–577_647-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004576–577-647">[639]</a></sup> Stalin's increasing tolerance of anti-Semitism may have stemmed from his increasing Russian nationalism or from the recognition that anti-Semitism had proved a useful mobilising tool for Hitler and that he could do the same;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991290_648-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991290-648">[640]</a></sup> he may have increasingly viewed the Jewish people as a "counter-revolutionary" nation whose members were loyal to the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015286_649-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015286-649">[641]</a></sup> There were rumours, although they have never been substantiated, that Stalin was planning on deporting all Soviet Jews to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Autonomous_Region" title="Jewish Autonomous Region">Jewish Autonomous Region</a> in <a href="/wiki/Birobidzhan" title="Birobidzhan">Birobidzhan</a>, eastern Siberia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004577Overy2004565Khlevniuk2015309_650-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004577Overy2004565Khlevniuk2015309-650">[642]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1950.E2.80.931953:_Final_years"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1950–1953:_Final_years">1950–1953: Final years</span></h3>
<p>In his later years, Stalin was in poor health.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004571_651-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004571-651">[643]</a></sup> He took increasingly long holidays; in 1950 and again in 1951 he spent almost five months vacationing at his Abkhazian dacha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004572Khlevniuk2015195_652-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004572Khlevniuk2015195-652">[644]</a></sup> Stalin nevertheless mistrusted his doctors; in January 1952 he had one imprisoned after they suggested that he should retire to improve his health.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004571_651-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004571-651">[643]</a></sup> In September 1952, several Kremlin doctors were arrested for allegedly plotting to kill senior politicians in what came to be known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doctors%27_Plot" title="Doctors' Plot">Doctors' Plot</a>; the majority of the accused were Jewish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991309Etinger1995104Service2004576Khlevniuk2015307_653-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991309Etinger1995104Service2004576Khlevniuk2015307-653">[645]</a></sup> He instructed the arrested doctors to be tortured to ensure confession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991309Khlevniuk2015307–308_654-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991309Khlevniuk2015307–308-654">[646]</a></sup> In November, the <a href="/wiki/Sl%C3%A1nsk%C3%BD_trial" title="Slánský trial">Slánský trial</a> took place in Czechoslovakia as 13 senior Communist Party figures, 11 of them Jewish, were accused and convicted of being part of a vast Zionist-American conspiracy to subvert Eastern Bloc governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991308Khlevniuk2015307_655-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991308Khlevniuk2015307-655">[647]</a></sup> That same month, a much publicised trial of accused Jewish industrial wreckers took place in Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991308_656-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991308-656">[648]</a></sup> In 1951, he initiated the <a href="/wiki/Mingrelian_affair" title="Mingrelian affair">Mingrelian affair</a>, a purge of the Georgian branch of the Communist Party which resulted in over 11,000 deportations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015304–305_657-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015304–305-657">[649]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1946 until his death, Stalin only gave three public speeches, two of which lasted only a few minutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004560_658-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004560-658">[650]</a></sup> The amount of written material that he produced also declined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004560_658-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004560-658">[650]</a></sup> In 1950, Stalin issued the article "<a href="/wiki/Marxism_and_Problems_of_Linguistics" title="Marxism and Problems of Linguistics">Marxism and Problems of Linguistics</a>", which reflected his interest in questions of Russian nationhood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004564–565_659-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004564–565-659">[651]</a></sup>
In 1952, Stalin's last book, <i><a href="/wiki/Economic_Problems_of_Socialism_in_the_USSR" title="Economic Problems of Socialism in the USSR">Economic Problems of Socialism in the USSR</a></i>, was published. It sought to provide a guide to leading the country after his death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991307Service2004566–567_660-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991307Service2004566–567-660">[652]</a></sup> In October 1952, Stalin gave an hour and a half speech at the Central Committee plenum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004578_661-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004578-661">[653]</a></sup> There, he emphasised what he regarded as leadership qualities necessary in the future and highlighted the weaknesses of various potential successors, particularly Molotov and Mikoyan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004579Khlevniuk2015306_662-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004579Khlevniuk2015306-662">[654]</a></sup> In 1952, he also eliminated the Politburo and replaced it with a larger version which he called the Presidium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015305–306_663-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015305–306-663">[655]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Death.2C_funeral_and_aftermath"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Death,_funeral_and_aftermath">Death, funeral and aftermath</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Joseph_Stalin" title="Death and state funeral of Joseph Stalin">Death and state funeral of Joseph Stalin</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="877" data-file-width="1583" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg/220px-Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg/330px-Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg/440px-Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin%27s_casket_on_howitzer_carriage_draught_by_horses.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin's casket on howitzer carriage drawn by horses, caught on camera by US assistant army attaché Major Martin Manhoff from the embassy balcony</div></div></div>
<p>On 1 March 1953, Stalin's staff found him semi-conscious on the bedroom floor of his <a href="/wiki/Kuntsevo_Dacha" title="Kuntsevo Dacha">Kuntsevo Dacha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311Volkogonov1991571–572Service2004582–584Khlevniuk2015142,_191_664-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311Volkogonov1991571–572Service2004582–584Khlevniuk2015142,_191-664">[656]</a></sup> He had suffered a <a href="/wiki/Intracerebral_hemorrhage" title="Intracerebral hemorrhage">cerebral haemorrhage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312_665-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312-665">[657]</a></sup> He was moved onto a couch and remained there for three days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311–312Volkogonov1991572Khlevniuk2015142_666-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311–312Volkogonov1991572Khlevniuk2015142-666">[658]</a></sup> He was hand-fed using a spoon, given various medicines and injections, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leech_therapy" title="Leech therapy">leeches were applied to him</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312_665-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312-665">[657]</a></sup> Svetlana and Vasily were called to the dacha on 2 March; the latter was drunk and angrily shouted at the doctors, resulting in him being sent home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312Khlevniuk2015250_667-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312Khlevniuk2015250-667">[659]</a></sup> Stalin died on 5 March 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991313Volkogonov1991574Service2004586Khlevniuk2015313_668-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991313Volkogonov1991574Service2004586Khlevniuk2015313-668">[660]</a></sup> According to Svetlana, it had been "a difficult and terrible death".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991313Khlevniuk2015313–314_669-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991313Khlevniuk2015313–314-669">[661]</a></sup> An autopsy revealed that he had died of a cerebral haemorrhage and that he also suffered from severe damage to his cerebral arteries due to <a href="/wiki/Atherosclerosis" title="Atherosclerosis">atherosclerosis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015189_670-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015189-670">[662]</a></sup> It is conjectured that Stalin was murdered;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004587_671-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004587-671">[663]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lavrentiy_Beria" title="Lavrentiy Beria">Beria</a> has been suspected of murder, although no firm evidence has ever appeared.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312_665-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991312-665">[657]</a></sup> According to a report published in <i>The New York Times</i>, Stalin was poisoned by <a href="/wiki/Warfarin" title="Warfarin">warfarin</a> by his own Politburo members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wines_2003_672-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wines_2003-672">[664]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin's death was announced on 6 March.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004588_673-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004588-673">[665]</a></sup> The body was embalmed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004588Khlevniuk2015314_674-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004588Khlevniuk2015314-674">[666]</a></sup> and then placed on display in Moscow's House of Unions for three days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015317_675-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015317-675">[667]</a></sup> Crowds were such that a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_stampede" title="Human stampede">crush</a> killed about 100 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004588Khlevniuk2015317_676-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004588Khlevniuk2015317-676">[668]</a></sup> The funeral involved the body being laid to rest in <a href="/wiki/Lenin%27s_Mausoleum" title="Lenin's Mausoleum">Lenin's Mausoleum</a> in Red Square on 9 March; hundreds of thousands attended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991576Service2004589Khlevniuk2015318_677-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991576Service2004589Khlevniuk2015318-677">[669]</a></sup> That month featured a surge in arrests for "anti-Soviet agitation" as those celebrating Stalin's death came to police attention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015319_678-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015319-678">[670]</a></sup> The Chinese government instituted a period of official mourning for Stalin's death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi200975_679-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi200975-679">[671]</a></sup> A memorial service in his honor was also held at <a href="/wiki/St_George_the_Martyr,_Holborn" title="St George the Martyr, Holborn">St George the Martyr, Holborn</a> in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-680"><a href="#cite_note-680">[672]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-681"><a href="#cite_note-681">[673]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin left no anointed successor nor a framework within which a transfer of power could take place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015310_682-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015310-682">[674]</a></sup> The Central Committee met on the day of his death, with Malenkov, Beria, and Khrushchev emerging as the party's key figures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004586–587_683-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004586–587-683">[675]</a></sup> The system of <a href="/wiki/Collective_leadership_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Collective leadership in the Soviet Union">collective leadership</a> was restored, and measures introduced to prevent any one member attaining autocratic domination again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015312_684-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015312-684">[676]</a></sup> The collective leadership included the following eight senior members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Central_Committee_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Politburo of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union</a> listed according to the order of precedence presented formally on 5 March 1953: <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Malenkov" title="Georgy Malenkov">Georgy Malenkov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lavrentiy_Beria" title="Lavrentiy Beria">Lavrentiy Beria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Molotov" title="Vyacheslav Molotov">Vyacheslav Molotov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kliment_Voroshilov" title="Kliment Voroshilov">Kliment Voroshilov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Bulganin" title="Nikolai Bulganin">Nikolai Bulganin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich" title="Lazar Kaganovich">Lazar Kaganovich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anastas_Mikoyan" title="Anastas Mikoyan">Anastas Mikoyan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERa'anan200620_685-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERa'anan200620-685">[677]</a></sup> Reforms to the Soviet system were immediately implemented.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004591_686-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004591-686">[678]</a></sup> Economic reform scaled back the mass construction projects, placed a new emphasis on house building, and eased the levels of taxation on the peasantry to stimulate production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015315_687-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015315-687">[679]</a></sup> The new leaders sought rapprochement with Yugoslavia and a less hostile relationship with the U.S.,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004593_688-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004593-688">[680]</a></sup> pursuing a negotiated end to the Korean War in July 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015316_689-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015316-689">[681]</a></sup> The doctors who had been imprisoned were released and the anti-Semitic purges ceased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995120–121Conquest1991314Khlevniuk2015314_690-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995120–121Conquest1991314Khlevniuk2015314-690">[682]</a></sup> A mass amnesty for those imprisoned for non-political crimes was issued, halving the country's inmate population, while the state security and Gulag systems were reformed, with torture being banned in April 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015315_687-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015315-687">[679]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_ideology">Political ideology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002,_Dresden,_Tod_Stalin,_Parade_KVP.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="584" decoding="async" height="301" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg/330px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg/440px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002%2C_Dresden%2C_Tod_Stalin%2C_Parade_KVP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-18684-0002,_Dresden,_Tod_Stalin,_Parade_KVP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A mourning parade in honour of Stalin in <a href="/wiki/Dresden" title="Dresden">Dresden</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a></div></div></div>
<p>Stalin claimed to have embraced Marxism at the age of fifteen,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERieber200532_691-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERieber200532-691">[683]</a></sup> and it served as the guiding philosophy throughout his adult life;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20049_692-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20049-692">[684]</a></sup> according to Kotkin, Stalin held "zealous Marxist convictions",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014xi_693-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014xi-693">[685]</a></sup> while Montefiore suggested that Marxism held a "quasi-religious" value for Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007336_694-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007336-694">[686]</a></sup> Although he never became a <a href="/wiki/Georgian_nationalism" title="Georgian nationalism">Georgian nationalist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERieber200543_695-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERieber200543-695">[687]</a></sup> during his early life elements from Georgian nationalist thought blended with Marxism in his outlook.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200767_696-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200767-696">[688]</a></sup> The historian Alfred J. Rieber noted that he had been raised in "a society where rebellion was deeply rooted in folklore and popular rituals".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERieber200543_695-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERieber200543-695">[687]</a></sup> Stalin believed in the need to adapt Marxism to changing circumstances; in 1917, he declared that "there is dogmatic Marxism and there is creative Marxism. I stand on the ground of the latter".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004136Kotkin2014205Khlevniuk201547_697-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004136Kotkin2014205Khlevniuk201547-697">[689]</a></sup> Volkogonov believed that Stalin's Marxism was shaped by his "dogmatic turn of mind", suggesting that this had been instilled in the Soviet leader during his education in religious institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19917_698-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19917-698">[690]</a></sup> According to scholar Robert Service, Stalin's "few innovations in ideology were crude, dubious developments of Marxism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20049_692-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20049-692">[684]</a></sup> Some of these derived from political expediency rather than any sincere intellectual commitment;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20049_692-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20049-692">[684]</a></sup> Stalin would often turn to ideology <i>post hoc</i> to justify his decisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20067_699-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20067-699">[691]</a></sup> Stalin referred to himself as a <i>praktik</i>, meaning that he was more of a practical revolutionary than a theoretician.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200492Kotkin2014462_700-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200492Kotkin2014462-700">[692]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a Marxist and an anti-capitalist, Stalin believed in an inevitable "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Class_struggle" title="Class struggle">class war</a>" between the world's proletariat and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bourgeoise" title="Bourgeoise">bourgeoise</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200493Khlevniuk20157_701-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200493Khlevniuk20157-701">[693]</a></sup> He believed that the working classes would prove successful in this struggle and would establish a <a href="/wiki/Dictatorship_of_the_proletariat" title="Dictatorship of the proletariat">dictatorship of the proletariat</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200493_702-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200493-702">[694]</a></sup> regarding the Soviet Union as an example of such a state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999216_703-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999216-703">[695]</a></sup> He also believed that this proletarian state would need to introduce repressive measures against foreign and domestic "enemies" to ensure the full crushing of the propertied classes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200493–94_704-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200493–94-704">[696]</a></sup> and thus the class war would intensify with the advance of socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999214Khlevniuk20158_705-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999214Khlevniuk20158-705">[697]</a></sup> As a propaganda tool, the shaming of "enemies" explained all inadequate economic and political outcomes, the hardships endured by the populace, and military failures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20158_706-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20158-706">[698]</a></sup> The new state would then be able to ensure that all citizens had access to work, food, shelter, healthcare, and education, with the wastefulness of capitalism eliminated by a new, standardised economic system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200494_707-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200494-707">[699]</a></sup> According to Sandle, Stalin was "committed to the creation of a society that was industrialised, collectivised, centrally planned and technologically advanced."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999211_708-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999211-708">[700]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin adhered to the <a href="/wiki/Leninism" title="Leninism">Leninist</a> variant of Marxism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196686Kotkin201410,_699_709-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutscher196686Kotkin201410,_699-709">[701]</a></sup> In his book, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Foundations_of_Leninism" title="The Foundations of Leninism"><i>Foundations of Leninism</i></a>, he stated that "Leninism is the Marxism of the epoch of imperialism and of the proletarian revolution".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014545_710-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014545-710">[702]</a></sup> He claimed to be a loyal Leninist,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200492_711-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200492-711">[703]</a></sup> although was—according to Service—"not a blindly obedient Leninist".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200494_707-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200494-707">[699]</a></sup> Stalin respected Lenin, but not uncritically,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007211_712-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007211-712">[704]</a></sup> and spoke out when he believed that Lenin was wrong.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200494_707-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200494-707">[699]</a></sup> During the period of his revolutionary activity, Stalin regarded some of Lenin's views and actions as being the self-indulgent activities of a spoiled émigré, deeming them counterproductive for those Bolshevik activists based within the Russian Empire itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200495Montefiore2007211_713-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200495Montefiore2007211-713">[705]</a></sup> After the October Revolution, they continued to have differences. Whereas Lenin believed that all countries across Europe and Asia would readily unite as a single state following proletariat revolution, Stalin argued that national pride would prevent this, and that different socialist states would have to be formed; in his view, a country like Germany would not readily submit to being part of a Russian-dominated federal state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004179–180_714-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004179–180-714">[706]</a></sup> Stalin biographer <a href="/wiki/Oleg_Khlevniuk" title="Oleg Khlevniuk">Oleg Khlevniuk</a> nevertheless believed that the pair developed a "strong bond" over the years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201567_715-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201567-715">[707]</a></sup> while Kotkin suggested that Stalin's friendship with Lenin was "the single most important relationship in Stalin's life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014531_716-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014531-716">[708]</a></sup> After Lenin's death, Stalin relied heavily on Lenin's writings—far more so than those of Marx and Engels—to guide him in the affairs of state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201593–94_717-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201593–94-717">[709]</a></sup> Stalin adopted the Leninist view on the need for a revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Vanguardism" title="Vanguardism">vanguard</a> who could lead the proletariat rather than being led by them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200493_702-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200493-702">[694]</a></sup> Leading this vanguard, he believed that the Soviet peoples needed a strong, central figure—akin to a Tsar—whom they could rally around.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004333Kotkin2014586_718-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004333Kotkin2014586-718">[710]</a></sup> In his words, "the people need a Tsar, whom they can worship and for whom they can live and work".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003158_719-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003158-719">[711]</a></sup> He read about, and admired, two Tsars in particular: <a href="/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible" title="Ivan the Terrible">Ivan the Terrible</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999256Service2004333Khlevniuk201594_720-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999256Service2004333Khlevniuk201594-720">[712]</a></sup> In the personality cult constructed around him, he was known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Vozhd" title="Vozhd">vozhd</a></i>, an equivalent to the Italian <i><a href="/wiki/Duce" title="Duce">duce</a></i> and German <i><a href="/wiki/F%C3%BChrer" title="Führer">führer</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin20177_721-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin20177-721">[713]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Grutas_Stalin.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Grutas_Stalin.jpg/220px-Grutas_Stalin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Grutas_Stalin.jpg/330px-Grutas_Stalin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Grutas_Stalin.jpg/440px-Grutas_Stalin.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Grutas_Stalin.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A statue of Joseph Stalin in <a href="/wiki/Gr%C5%ABtas_Park" title="Grūtas Park">Grūtas Park</a> near <a href="/wiki/Druskininkai" title="Druskininkai">Druskininkai</a>, Lithuania. It originally stood in <a href="/wiki/Vilnius" title="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, Lithuania.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Stalinism" title="Stalinism">Stalinism</a> was a development of Leninism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007352_722-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007352-722">[714]</a></sup> and while Stalin avoided using the term "Marxism-Leninism-Stalinism", he allowed others to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004357_723-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004357-723">[715]</a></sup> Following Lenin's death, Stalin contributed to the theoretical debates within the Communist Party, namely by developing the idea of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialism_in_One_Country" title="Socialism in One Country">Socialism in One Country</a>". This concept was intricately linked to factional struggles within the party, particularly against Trotsky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999208–209_724-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999208–209-724">[716]</a></sup> He first developed the idea in December 1924 and elaborated upon in his writings of 1925–26.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999209_725-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999209-725">[717]</a></sup> Stalin's doctrine held that socialism could be completed in Russia but that its final victory there could not be guaranteed because of the threat from capitalist intervention. For this reason, he retained the Leninist view that world revolution was still a necessity to ensure the ultimate victory of socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999209_725-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999209-725">[717]</a></sup> Although retaining the Marxist belief that the state would wither away as socialism transformed into pure communism, he believed that the Soviet state would remain until the final defeat of international capitalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999261_726-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999261-726">[718]</a></sup> This concept synthesised Marxist and Leninist ideas with nationalist ideals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999211_708-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999211-708">[700]</a></sup> and served to discredit Trotsky—who promoted the idea of "<a href="/wiki/Permanent_revolution" title="Permanent revolution">permanent revolution</a>"—by presenting the latter as a defeatist with little faith in Russian workers' abilities to construct socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999210_727-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999210-727">[719]</a></sup>
