</p><p>Stalin viewed nations as contingent entities which were formed by capitalism and could merge into others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200498_728-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200498-728">[720]</a></sup> Ultimately he believed that all nations would merge into a single, global human community,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200498_728-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200498-728">[720]</a></sup> and regarded all nations as inherently equal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOvery2004552_729-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOvery2004552-729">[721]</a></sup> In his work, he stated that "the right of secession" should be offered to the ethnic-minorities of the Russian Empire, but that they should not be encouraged to take that option.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200499_730-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200499-730">[722]</a></sup> He was of the view that if they became fully autonomous, then they would end up being controlled by the most reactionary elements of their community; as an example he cited the largely illiterate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tatar" title="Tatar">Tatars</a>, whom he claimed would end up dominated by their <a href="/wiki/Mullah" title="Mullah">mullahs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200499_730-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200499-730">[722]</a></sup> Stalin argued that the Jews possessed a "national character" but were not a "nation" and were thus unassimilable. He argued that Jewish nationalism, particularly <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>, was hostile to socialism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOvery2004565_731-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOvery2004565-731">[723]</a></sup> According to Khlevniuk, Stalin reconciled Marxism with great-power imperialism and therefore expansion of the empire makes him a worthy to the Russian tsars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20158_706-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20158-706">[698]</a></sup> Service argued that Stalin's Marxism was imbued with a great deal of Russian nationalism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20049_692-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20049-692">[684]</a></sup> According to Montefiore, Stalin's embrace of the Russian nation was pragmatic, as the Russians were the core of the population of the USSR; it was not a rejection of his Georgian origins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003310,_579_732-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003310,_579-732">[724]</a></sup> Stalin's push for Soviet westward expansion into eastern Europe resulted in accusations of <a href="/wiki/Russian_imperialism" title="Russian imperialism">Russian imperialism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20045_733-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20045-733">[725]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life_and_characteristics">Personal life and characteristics</span></h2>
<p>Ethnically Georgian,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19911_734-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19911-734">[726]</a></sup> Stalin grew up speaking the Georgian language,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19911Khlevniuk201597_735-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19911Khlevniuk201597-735">[727]</a></sup> and did not begin learning <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> until the age of eight or nine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201597_736-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201597-736">[728]</a></sup> It has been argued that his ancestry was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ossetian_people" title="Ossetian people">Ossetian</a>, because his genetic haplotype (G2a-Z6653) is considered typical of the Ossetians, but he never acknowledged an Ossetian identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFoltz202194–97_737-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoltz202194–97-737">[729]</a></sup> He remained proud of his Georgian identity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200766–67_738-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200766–67-738">[730]</a></sup> and throughout his life retained a heavy Georgian accent when speaking Russian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19911Montefiore20032Montefiore200742Khlevniuk201597_739-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19911Montefiore20032Montefiore200742Khlevniuk201597-739">[731]</a></sup> According to Montefiore, despite Stalin's affinity for Russia and Russians, he remained profoundly Georgian in his lifestyle and personality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003579_740-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003579-740">[732]</a></sup> Some of Stalin's colleagues described him as "Asiatic", and he supposedly once told a Japanese journalist that "I am not a European man, but an Asian, a Russified Georgian".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERieber200518_741-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERieber200518-741">[733]</a></sup> Service also noted that Stalin "would never be Russian", could not credibly pass as one, and never tried to pretend that he was.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200485_742-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200485-742">[734]</a></sup> Montefiore was of the view that "after 1917, [Stalin] became quadri-national: Georgian by nationality, Russian by loyalty, internationalist by ideology, Soviet by citizenship."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007268_743-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007268-743">[735]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin had a soft voice,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991183Volkogonov19915Kotkin20175_744-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991183Volkogonov19915Kotkin20175-744">[736]</a></sup> and when speaking Russian did so slowly, carefully choosing his phrasing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19911_734-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19911-734">[726]</a></sup> In private he often used coarse language and profanity, although avoided doing so in public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199137_745-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199137-745">[737]</a></sup> Described as a poor orator,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991149Volkogonov199149Service2004334Khlevniuk201552_746-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991149Volkogonov199149Service2004334Khlevniuk201552-746">[738]</a></sup> according to Volkogonov, Stalin's speaking style was "simple and clear, without flights of fancy, catchy phrases or platform <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/histrionics#Noun" title="wikt:histrionics">histrionics</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991xx–xxi_747-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991xx–xxi-747">[739]</a></sup> He rarely spoke before large audiences, and preferred to express himself in written form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015329_748-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015329-748">[740]</a></sup> His writing style was similar, being characterised by its simplicity, clarity, and conciseness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199121Khlevniuk201597_749-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199121Khlevniuk201597-749">[741]</a></sup> Throughout his life, he used various nicknames and pseudonyms, including "Koba", "Soselo", and "Ivanov",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007395_750-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007395-750">[742]</a></sup> adopting "Stalin" in 1912; it was based on the Russian word for "steel" and has often been translated as "Man of Steel".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269_155-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHimmer1986269-155">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:227px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1552" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg/225px-Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg/338px-Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg/450px-Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lavrenti_Beria_Stalins_family.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lavrenti_Beria" title="Lavrenti Beria">Lavrenti Beria</a> with Stalin's daughter, Svetlana, on his lap and Stalin with <a href="/wiki/Nestor_Lakoba" title="Nestor Lakoba">Nestor Lakoba</a> seated in the background smoking a pipe. The photo was taken at Stalin's <a href="/wiki/Dacha" title="Dacha">dacha</a> near <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a> in the mid-1930s.</div></div></div>
<p>In adulthood, Stalin measured five feet seven inches (1.7 meters).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin201740_751-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin201740-751">[743]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-752"><a href="#cite_note-752">[744]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-753"><a href="#cite_note-753">[745]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-754"><a href="#cite_note-754">[746]</a></sup> His mustached face was pock-marked from <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> during childhood; this was airbrushed from published photographs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin20174_755-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin20174-755">[747]</a></sup> He was born with a <a href="/wiki/Webbed_toes" title="Webbed toes">webbed</a> left foot, and his left arm had been permanently injured in childhood which left it shorter than his right and lacking in flexibility,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200425Khlevniuk201513–14_756-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200425Khlevniuk201513–14-756">[748]</a></sup> which was probably the result of being hit, at the age of 12, by a horse-drawn carriage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200721,_29,_33–34_757-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200721,_29,_33–34-757">[749]</a></sup>
</p><p>During his youth, Stalin cultivated a scruffy appearance in rejection of middle-class aesthetic values.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200444_758-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200444-758">[750]</a></sup> By 1907, he grew his hair long and often wore a beard; for clothing, he often wore a traditional Georgian <i><a href="/wiki/Chokha" title="Chokha">chokha</a></i> or a red satin shirt with a grey coat and black fedora.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20079–10_759-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20079–10-759">[751]</a></sup> From mid-1918 until his death he favoured military-style clothing, in particular long black boots, light-coloured collarless tunics, and a gun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004167Kotkin20171_760-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004167Kotkin20171-760">[752]</a></sup> He was a lifelong smoker, who smoked both a pipe and cigarettes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991282Volkogonov1991146Service2004435,_438,_574Kotkin20171_761-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991282Volkogonov1991146Service2004435,_438,_574Kotkin20171-761">[753]</a></sup> He had few material demands and lived plainly, with simple and inexpensive clothing and furniture;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311Volkogonov1991102Montefiore200336–37Service2004497–498_762-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991311Volkogonov1991102Montefiore200336–37Service2004497–498-762">[754]</a></sup> his interest was in power rather than wealth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991102Service2004498_763-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991102Service2004498-763">[755]</a></sup>
</p><p>As leader of the Soviet Union, Stalin typically awoke around 11<span class="nowrap"> </span>am,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200360_764-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200360-764">[756]</a></sup> with lunch being served between 3 and 5<span class="nowrap"> </span>pm and dinner no earlier than 9<span class="nowrap"> </span>pm;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200360Service2004525_765-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200360Service2004525-765">[757]</a></sup> he then worked late into the evening.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004525_766-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004525-766">[758]</a></sup> He often dined with other Politburo members and their families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200335,_60_767-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200335,_60-767">[759]</a></sup> As leader, he rarely left Moscow unless to go to one of his dachas for holiday;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004331_768-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004331-768">[760]</a></sup> he disliked travel,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015102,_227_769-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015102,_227-769">[761]</a></sup> and refused to travel by plane.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015195Kotkin20173_770-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015195Kotkin20173-770">[762]</a></sup> His choice of favoured holiday house changed over the years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200364_771-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200364-771">[763]</a></sup> although he holidayed in southern parts of the USSR every year from 1925 to 1936 and again from 1945 to 1951.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015191_772-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015191-772">[764]</a></sup> Along with other senior figures, he had a dacha at Zubalova, 35 km outside Moscow,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200357–58Kotkin2014594_773-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200357–58Kotkin2014594-773">[765]</a></sup> although ceased using it after Nadezhda's 1932 suicide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003102_774-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003102-774">[766]</a></sup> After 1932, he favoured holidays in <a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Abkhazia</a>, being a friend of its leader, <a href="/wiki/Nestor_Lakoba" title="Nestor Lakoba">Nestor Lakoba</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200366–67Service2004296_775-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200366–67Service2004296-775">[767]</a></sup> In 1934, his new <a href="/wiki/Kuntsevo_Dacha" title="Kuntsevo Dacha">Kuntsevo Dacha</a> was built; 9 km from the Kremlin, it became his primary residence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991215Montefiore2003103Service2004295_776-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991215Montefiore2003103Service2004295-776">[768]</a></sup> In 1935 he began using a new dacha provided for him by Lakoba at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Novy_Afon" title="Novy Afon">Novy Afon</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003178_777-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003178-777">[769]</a></sup> in 1936, he had the <a href="/wiki/Kholodnaya_Rechka" title="Kholodnaya Rechka">Kholodnaya Rechka</a> dacha built on the Abkhazian coast, designed by <a href="/wiki/Miron_Merzhanov" title="Miron Merzhanov">Miron Merzhanov</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004572_778-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004572-778">[770]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Personality">Personality</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_birthday2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="557" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Stalin_birthday2.jpg/220px-Stalin_birthday2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Stalin_birthday2.jpg/330px-Stalin_birthday2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Stalin_birthday2.jpg/440px-Stalin_birthday2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stalin_birthday2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chinese Marxists celebrate Stalin's seventieth birthday in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>Trotsky and several other Soviet figures promoted the idea that Stalin was a mediocrity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviVolkogonov1991xxiiiService20044Montefiore2007xxiv_779-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviVolkogonov1991xxiiiService20044Montefiore2007xxiv-779">[771]</a></sup> This gained widespread acceptance outside the Soviet Union during his lifetime but was misleading.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxiv_780-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxiv-780">[772]</a></sup> According to biographer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simon_Sebag-Montefiore" title="Simon Sebag-Montefiore">Montefiore</a>, "it is clear from hostile and friendly witnesses alike that Stalin was always exceptional, even from childhood".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxiv_780-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxiv-780">[772]</a></sup> Stalin had a complex mind,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004343_781-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004343-781">[773]</a></sup> great self-control,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19918Service2004337_782-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19918Service2004337-782">[774]</a></sup> and an excellent memory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991193,_274Volkogonov199163Service2004115Kotkin2014425Khlevniuk2015148_783-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991193,_274Volkogonov199163Service2004115Kotkin2014425Khlevniuk2015148-783">[775]</a></sup> He was a hard worker,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200442Montefiore2007353Kotkin2014424,_465,_597_784-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200442Montefiore2007353Kotkin2014424,_465,_597-784">[776]</a></sup> and displayed a keen desire to learn;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004115_785-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004115-785">[777]</a></sup> when in power, he scrutinised many details of Soviet life, from film scripts to architectural plans and military hardware.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20154–5_786-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20154–5-786">[778]</a></sup> According to Volkogonov, "Stalin's private life and working life were one and the same"; he did not take days off from political activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991145_787-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991145-787">[779]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin could play different roles to different audiences,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991317Volkogonov1991xxviMcDermott200613_788-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991317Volkogonov1991xxviMcDermott200613-788">[780]</a></sup> and was adept at deception, often deceiving others as to his true motives and aims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviService200418McDermott200613_789-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviService200418McDermott200613-789">[781]</a></sup> Several historians have seen it as appropriate to follow <a href="/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich" title="Lazar Kaganovich">Lazar Kaganovich</a>'s description of there being "several Stalins" as a means of understanding his multi-faceted personality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott200612–13_790-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott200612–13-790">[782]</a></sup> He was a good organiser,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200342Kotkin2014424_791-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200342Kotkin2014424-791">[783]</a></sup> with a strategic mind,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014424_792-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014424-792">[784]</a></sup> and judged others according to their inner strength, practicality, and cleverness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004342_793-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004342-793">[785]</a></sup> He acknowledged that he could be rude and insulting,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991120Kotkin2014648_794-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991120Kotkin2014648-794">[786]</a></sup> but he rarely raised his voice in anger;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004337_795-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004337-795">[787]</a></sup> as his health deteriorated in later life he became increasingly unpredictable and bad tempered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015145_796-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015145-796">[788]</a></sup> Despite his tough-talking attitude, he could be very charming;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200392Montefiore200349–50Kotkin2014117,_465Kotkin20175_797-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200392Montefiore200349–50Kotkin2014117,_465Kotkin20175-797">[789]</a></sup> when relaxed, he cracked jokes and mimicked others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004115_785-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004115-785">[777]</a></sup> Montefiore suggested that this charm was "the foundation of Stalin's power in the Party".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200341_798-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200341-798">[790]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin was ruthless,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004338Khlevniuk201553_799-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004338Khlevniuk201553-799">[791]</a></sup> temperamentally cruel,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991318Khlevniuk20157_800-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991318Khlevniuk20157-800">[792]</a></sup> and had a propensity for violence high even among the Bolsheviks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004337_795-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004337-795">[787]</a></sup> He lacked compassion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19914Khlevniuk20157_801-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19914Khlevniuk20157-801">[793]</a></sup> something Volkogonov suggested might have been accentuated by his many years in prison and exile,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19918_802-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19918-802">[794]</a></sup> although he was capable of acts of kindness to strangers, even amid the Great Terror.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004334_803-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004334-803">[795]</a></sup> He was capable of self-righteous indignation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004258Montefiore2007285_804-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004258Montefiore2007285-804">[796]</a></sup> and was resentful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20044,_344_805-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20044,_344-805">[797]</a></sup> and vindictive,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014597Kotkin20176_806-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014597Kotkin20176-806">[798]</a></sup> holding on to grudges for many years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200410,_344Kotkin20175_807-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200410,_344Kotkin20175-807">[799]</a></sup> By the 1920s, he was also suspicious and conspiratorial, prone to believing that people were plotting against him and that there were vast international conspiracies behind acts of dissent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004336Kotkin2014736_808-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004336Kotkin2014736-808">[800]</a></sup> He never attended torture sessions or executions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003175_809-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003175-809">[801]</a></sup> although Service thought Stalin "derived deep satisfaction" from degrading and humiliating people and enjoyed keeping even close associates in a state of "unrelieved fear".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20045_733-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20045-733">[725]</a></sup> Montefiore thought Stalin's brutality marked him out as a "natural extremist";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200742_810-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200742-810">[802]</a></sup> Service suggested he had tendencies toward a paranoid and sociopathic personality disorder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004343_781-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004343-781">[773]</a></sup> According to historian <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Roberts" title="Geoffrey Roberts">Geoffrey Roberts</a>, Stalin wasn't a psychopath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> He was instead an emotionally intelligent and feeling intellectual.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> Other historians linked his brutality not to any personality trait, but to his unwavering commitment to the survival of the Soviet Union and the international Marxist–Leninist cause.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott200612_812-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott200612-812">[804]</a></sup>
</p><p>Keenly interested in the arts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014620_813-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014620-813">[805]</a></sup> Stalin admired artistic talent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200760_814-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200760-814">[806]</a></sup> He protected several Soviet writers from arrest and prosecution, such as <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov" title="Mikhail Bulgakov">Mikhail Bulgakov</a>, even when their work was labelled harmful to his regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201596_815-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201596-815">[807]</a></sup> He enjoyed listening to classical music,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200373Khlevniuk20156_816-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200373Khlevniuk20156-816">[808]</a></sup> owning around 2,700 <a href="/wiki/Phonograph_record" title="Phonograph record">records</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20156_817-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20156-817">[809]</a></sup> and frequently attending the Bolshoi Theatre during the 1930s and 1940s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991127,_148_818-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991127,_148-818">[810]</a></sup> His taste in music and theatre was conservative, favouring classical drama, opera, and ballet over what he dismissed as experimental "<a href="/wiki/Formalism_(art)" title="Formalism (art)">formalism</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201597_736-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201597-736">[728]</a></sup> He also favoured classical forms in the visual arts, disliking avant-garde styles like <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">cubism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Futurism" title="Futurism">futurism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991131_819-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991131-819">[811]</a></sup> He was a voracious reader and kept a personal library of over 20,000 books.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386Service20049McDermott200619Kotkin20171–2,_5_820-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386Service20049McDermott200619Kotkin20171–2,_5-820">[812]</a></sup> Little of this was fiction,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201593_821-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk201593-821">[813]</a></sup> although he could cite passages from <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Nekrasov" title="Nikolay Nekrasov">Nikolay Nekrasov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman" title="Walt Whitman">Walt Whitman</a> by heart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200760_814-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200760-814">[806]</a></sup> Stalin's favourite subject was history, closely followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxist_theory" title="Marxist theory">Marxist theory</a> and then fiction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> He favoured historical studies, keeping up with debates in the study of Russian, Mesopotamian, ancient Roman, and Byzantine history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004560_658-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004560-658">[650]</a></sup>  He was very interested in the reigns of <a href="/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible" title="Ivan the Terrible">Ivan the Terrible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Autodidacticism" title="Autodidacticism">autodidact</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386Kotkin2014117,_676_822-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386Kotkin2014117,_676-822">[814]</a></sup> he claimed to read as many as 500 pages a day,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200393Montefiore200386Service2004560McDermott200619_823-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200393Montefiore200386Service2004560McDermott200619-823">[815]</a></sup> with Montefiore regarding him as an <a href="/wiki/Intellectual" title="Intellectual">intellectual</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386_824-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200386-824">[816]</a></sup> Lenin was his favourite author but he also read, and sometimes appreciated, a great deal of writing by <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a> and other arch-enemies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> Like all Bolshevik leaders, Stalin believed that reading could help transform not just people's ideas and consciousness, but <a href="/wiki/Human_nature" title="Human nature">human nature</a> itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts20222_811-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts20222-811">[803]</a></sup> Stalin also enjoyed watching films late at night at cinemas installed in the Kremlin and his dachas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991127Khlevniuk20152–3_825-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991127Khlevniuk20152–3-825">[817]</a></sup> He liked the <a href="/wiki/Western_(genre)" title="Western (genre)">Western</a> genre,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991282McCauley200390_826-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991282McCauley200390-826">[818]</a></sup> although his favourite films were <i><a href="/wiki/Volga-Volga" title="Volga-Volga">Volga Volga</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Circus_(1936_film)" title="Circus (1936 film)">Circus</a></i> (both directed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grigori_Alexandrov" title="Grigori Alexandrov">Grigori Alexandrov</a> and starring <a href="/wiki/Lyubov_Orlova" title="Lyubov Orlova">Lyubov Orlova</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003145_827-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003145-827">[819]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin was a keen and accomplished <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Billiards" title="Billiards">billiards</a> player,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200358,_507Kotkin20171_828-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200358,_507Kotkin20171-828">[820]</a></sup> and collected watches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin20171_829-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin20171-829">[821]</a></sup> He also enjoyed practical jokes; for instance, he would place a tomato on the seat of Politburo members and wait for them to sit on it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991283Service2004437_830-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991283Service2004437-830">[822]</a></sup> When at social events, he encouraged singing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004522_831-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004522-831">[823]</a></sup> as well as alcohol consumption; he hoped that others would drunkenly reveal their secrets to him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200390Service2004437,_522–523Khlevniuk20155_832-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200390Service2004437,_522–523Khlevniuk20155-832">[824]</a></sup> As an infant, Stalin displayed a love of flowers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200724_833-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200724-833">[825]</a></sup> and later in life he became a keen gardener.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200724_833-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200724-833">[825]</a></sup> His Volynskoe suburb had a 20-hectare (50-acre) park, with Stalin devoting much attention to its agricultural activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20153–4_834-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk20153–4-834">[826]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin publicly condemned anti-Semitism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007319,_637_835-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007319,_637-835">[827]</a></sup> although <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stalin_and_antisemitism" title="Stalin and antisemitism">he was repeatedly accused of it</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200455_836-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200455-836">[828]</a></sup> People who knew him, such as Khrushchev, suggested he long harboured negative sentiments toward Jews,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995103Montefiore2007165_837-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995103Montefiore2007165-837">[829]</a></sup> and it has been argued that anti-Semitic trends in his policies were further fuelled by Stalin's struggle against Trotsky.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995103Rappaport1999297_838-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEtinger1995103Rappaport1999297-838">[830]</a></sup> After Stalin's death, Khrushchev claimed that Stalin encouraged him to incite anti-Semitism in Ukraine, allegedly telling him that "the good workers at the factory should be given clubs so they can beat the hell out of those Jews."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPinkus1984107–108Brackman2001390_839-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPinkus1984107–108Brackman2001390-839">[831]</a></sup> In 1946, Stalin allegedly said privately that "every Jew is a potential spy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrentNaumov2004184_840-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrentNaumov2004184-840">[832]</a></sup> Conquest stated that although Stalin had Jewish associates, he promoted anti-Semitism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest19918_841-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest19918-841">[833]</a></sup> Service cautioned that there was "no irrefutable evidence" of anti-Semitism in Stalin's published work, although his private statements and public actions were "undeniably reminiscent of crude antagonism towards Jews";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004567–568_842-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004567–568-842">[834]</a></sup> he added that throughout Stalin's lifetime, the Georgian "would be the friend, associate or leader of countless individual Jews".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200477_843-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200477-843">[835]</a></sup> Stalin also had Jewish in-laws and grandchildren.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-844"><a href="#cite_note-844">[836]</a></sup> Additionally, according to Beria, Stalin had affairs with several Jewish women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003237_845-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003237-845">[837]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationships_and_family">Relationships and family</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana,_1935.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1171" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg/220px-Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg/330px-Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg/440px-Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana%2C_1935.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Joseph_Stalin_with_daughter_Svetlana,_1935.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Stalin carrying his daughter, Svetlana</div></div></div>
<p>Friendship was important to Stalin,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200749Fitzpatrick201565_846-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200749Fitzpatrick201565-846">[838]</a></sup> and he used it to gain and maintain power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200749_847-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200749-847">[839]</a></sup> Kotkin observed that Stalin "generally gravitated to people like himself: parvenu intelligentsia of humble background".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin20149_848-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin20149-848">[840]</a></sup> He gave nicknames to his favourites, for instance referring to Yezhov as "my blackberry".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003151_849-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003151-849">[841]</a></sup> Stalin was sociable and enjoyed a joke.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004112_850-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004112-850">[842]</a></sup> According to Montefiore, Stalin's friendships "meandered between love, admiration, and venomous jealousy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003135_851-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003135-851">[843]</a></sup> While head of the Soviet Union he remained in contact with many of his old friends in Georgia, sending them letters and gifts of money.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004522Montefiore2003135Montefiore2007368_852-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004522Montefiore2003135Montefiore2007368-852">[844]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin was no womanizer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200313_853-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200313-853">[845]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Boris_Bazhanov" title="Boris Bazhanov">Boris Bazhanov</a>, Stalin's one-time secretary, "Women didn't interest him. His own woman [Alliluyeva] was enough for him, and he paid scant attention to her."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-854"><a href="#cite_note-854">[846]</a></sup> However, Montefiore noted that in his early life Stalin "rarely seems to have been without a girlfriend."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200773_855-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200773-855">[847]</a></sup> Montefiore described Stalin's favoured types as "young, malleable teenagers or buxom peasant women,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007209_856-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007209-856">[848]</a></sup> who would be supportive and unchallenging toward him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200480Montefiore2007209_857-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200480Montefiore2007209-857">[849]</a></sup> According to Service, Stalin "regarded women as a resource for sexual gratification and domestic comfort."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200480_858-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200480-858">[850]</a></sup> Stalin married twice and had several children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200390_859-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCauley200390-859">[851]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin married his first wife, <a href="/wiki/Kato_Svanidze" title="Kato Svanidze">Ekaterina Svanidze</a>, in 1906. According to Montefiore, theirs was "a true love match";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20075_860-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20075-860">[852]</a></sup> Volkogonov suggested that she was "probably the one human being he had really loved".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19914_861-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov19914-861">[853]</a></sup> When she died, Stalin allegedly said: "This creature softened my heart of stone."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007202_862-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007202-862">[854]</a></sup> They had a son, <a href="/wiki/Yakov_Dzhugashvili" title="Yakov Dzhugashvili">Yakov</a>, who often frustrated and annoyed Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991149Service200464Montefiore2007167Khlevniuk201525_863-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991149Service200464Montefiore2007167Khlevniuk201525-863">[855]</a></sup> Yakov had a daughter, <a href="/wiki/Galina_Dzhugashvili" title="Galina Dzhugashvili">Galina</a>, before fighting for the Red Army in the Second World War. He was captured by the German Army and then committed suicide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991150–151Montefiore2007364_864-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991150–151Montefiore2007364-864">[856]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin's second wife was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nadezhda_Alliluyeva-Stalina" title="Nadezhda Alliluyeva-Stalina">Nadezhda Alliluyeva</a>; theirs was not an easy relationship, and they often fought.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20038_865-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20038-865">[857]</a></sup> They had two biological children—a son, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vasily_Dzhugashvili" title="Vasily Dzhugashvili">Vasily</a>, and a daughter, <a href="/wiki/Svetlana_Alliluyeva" title="Svetlana Alliluyeva">Svetlana</a>—and adopted another son, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Artyom_Sergeyev_(general)" title="Artyom Sergeyev (general)">Artyom Sergeev</a>, in 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20039_866-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20039-866">[858]</a></sup> It is unclear if Stalin ever had a mistress during or after his marriage to Alliluyeva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2017_867-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2017-867">[859]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200313Khlevniuk2015255_868-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200313Khlevniuk2015255-868">[860]</a></sup> In any event, she suspected that he was unfaithful with other women,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200312_869-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200312-869">[861]</a></sup> and committed suicide in 1932.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991154Montefiore200316Khlevniuk2015255_870-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991154Montefiore200316Khlevniuk2015255-870">[862]</a></sup> Stalin regarded Vasily as spoiled and often chastised his behaviour; as Stalin's son, Vasily nevertheless was swiftly promoted through the ranks of the Red Army and allowed a lavish lifestyle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015257,_259–260_871-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015257,_259–260-871">[863]</a></sup> Conversely, Stalin had an affectionate relationship with Svetlana during her childhood,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991215Volkogonov1991153Montefiore20039,_227Khlevniuk2015256_872-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991215Volkogonov1991153Montefiore20039,_227Khlevniuk2015256-872">[864]</a></sup> and was also very fond of Artyom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20039_866-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore20039-866">[858]</a></sup> In later life, he disapproved of Svetlana's various suitors and husbands, putting a strain on his relationship with her.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991260Service2004521_873-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991260Service2004521-873">[865]</a></sup> After the Second World War, he made little time for his children and his family played a decreasingly important role in his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015250,_259_874-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015250,_259-874">[866]</a></sup> After Stalin's death, Svetlana changed her surname from Stalin to Alliluyeva,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004593_688-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004593-688">[680]</a></sup> and defected to the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015260_875-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015260-875">[867]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Nadezhda's death, Stalin became increasingly close to his sister-in-law Zhenya Alliluyeva;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003142–144_876-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003142–144-876">[868]</a></sup> Montefiore believed that they were lovers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003144_877-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003144-877">[869]</a></sup> There are unproven rumours that from 1934 onward he had a relationship with his housekeeper Valentina Istomina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004521_878-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004521-878">[870]</a></sup> Montefiore also claimed that Stalin had at least two illegitimate children,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007365_879-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007365-879">[871]</a></sup> although he never recognised them as being his.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015252_880-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015252-880">[872]</a></sup> One of them, <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Kuzakov" title="Konstantin Kuzakov">Konstantin Kuzakov</a>, later taught philosophy at the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_State_Technical_University" title="Baltic State Technical University">Leningrad Military Mechanical Institute</a>, but never met Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007365–366_881-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007365–366-881">[873]</a></sup> The other, Alexander, was the son of Lidia Pereprygina; he was raised as the son of a peasant fisherman and the Soviet authorities made him swear never to reveal that Stalin was his biological father.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007366_882-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007366-882">[874]</a></sup>
</p><p>It was long rumored that Stalin married a sister of <a href="/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich" title="Lazar Kaganovich">Lazar Kaganovich</a>. Although probably a hoax, the story of "Rosa Kaganovich" was spread by notable Soviet defectors, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trotsky" title="Trotsky">Trotsky</a>, who alleged that "Stalin married the sister of Kaganovich, thereby presenting the latter with hopes for a promising future."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-883"><a href="#cite_note-883">[875]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="527" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg/220px-Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg/330px-Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg/440px-Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fotothek_df_roe-neg_0006153_004_Blick_auf_die_Ehrentrib%C3%BCne_bei_der_Sportlerparad.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A poster of Stalin at the <a href="/wiki/3rd_World_Festival_of_Youth_and_Students" title="3rd World Festival of Youth and Students">3rd World Festival of Youth and Students</a> in East Berlin, East Germany, 1951</div></div></div>
<p>The historian <a href="/wiki/Robert_Conquest" title="Robert Conquest">Robert Conquest</a> stated that Stalin perhaps "determined the course of the twentieth century" more than any other individual.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xi_884-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xi-884">[876]</a></sup> Biographers like Service and Volkogonov have considered him an outstanding and exceptional politician;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991108Service20045_885-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991108Service20045-885">[877]</a></sup> Montefiore labelled Stalin as "that rare combination: both 'intellectual' and killer", a man who was "the ultimate politician" and "the most elusive and fascinating of the twentieth-century titans".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxii_886-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007xxii-886">[878]</a></sup> According to historian Kevin McDermott, interpretations of Stalin range from "the sycophantic and adulatory to the vitriolic and condemnatory."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061_887-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061-887">[879]</a></sup> For most Westerners and <a href="/wiki/Anti-communism" title="Anti-communism">anti-communist</a> Russians, he is viewed overwhelmingly negatively as a <a href="/wiki/Mass_murder" title="Mass murder">mass murderer</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061_887-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061-887">[879]</a></sup> for significant numbers of Russians and Georgians, he is regarded as a great statesman and state-builder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061_887-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20061-887">[879]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stalin strengthened and stabilised the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20043_888-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20043-888">[880]</a></sup> Service suggested that the country might have collapsed long before 1991 without Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20043_888-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20043-888">[880]</a></sup> In under three decades, Stalin transformed the Soviet Union into a major industrial world power,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991546Service20043_889-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991546Service20043-889">[881]</a></sup> one which could "claim impressive achievements" in terms of urbanisation, military strength, education and Soviet pride.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004602_890-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004602-890">[882]</a></sup> Under his rule, the average Soviet life expectancy grew due to improved living conditions, nutrition and medical care<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft1999_891-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft1999-891">[883]</a></sup> as mortality rates also declined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman20021164_892-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021164-892">[884]</a></sup> Although millions of Soviet citizens despised him, support for Stalin was nevertheless widespread throughout Soviet society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004602_890-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004602-890">[882]</a></sup> Stalin's necessity for Soviet Union's economic development has been questioned, and it has been argued that Stalin's policies from 1928 onwards may have only been a limiting factor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECheremukhinGolosovGurievTsyvinski2013DowerMarkevich2018246_893-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECheremukhinGolosovGurievTsyvinski2013DowerMarkevich2018246-893">[885]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1880" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg/220px-Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg/330px-Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg/440px-Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Expon%C3%A1ty_v_Muzeu.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Interior of the <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin_Museum,_Gori" title="Joseph Stalin Museum, Gori">Joseph Stalin Museum</a> in Gori, Georgia</div></div></div>
<p>Stalin's Soviet Union has been characterised as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Totalitarian" title="Totalitarian">totalitarian</a> state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004602Khlevniuk2015190_894-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004602Khlevniuk2015190-894">[886]</a></sup> with Stalin its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Authoritarian" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a> leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014732_895-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014732-895">[887]</a></sup> Various biographers have described him as a <a href="/wiki/Dictator" title="Dictator">dictator</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCauley20038Service200452Montefiore20079Kotkin2014xiiKhlevniuk201512_896-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCauley20038Service200452Montefiore20079Kotkin2014xiiKhlevniuk201512-896">[888]</a></sup> an <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocrat</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991194Volkogonov199131Service2004370_897-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991194Volkogonov199131Service2004370-897">[889]</a></sup> or accused him of practising <a href="/wiki/Caesarism" title="Caesarism">Caesarism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199177_898-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov199177-898">[890]</a></sup> He has also been labelled a "<a href="/wiki/Red_fascism" title="Red fascism">red fascist</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-899"><a href="#cite_note-899">[891]</a></sup> Montefiore argued that while Stalin initially ruled as part of a Communist Party <a href="/wiki/Oligarchy" title="Oligarchy">oligarchy</a>, the Soviet government transformed from this oligarchy into a personal dictatorship in 1934,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003124_900-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003124-900">[892]</a></sup> with Stalin only becoming "absolute dictator" between March and June 1937, when senior military and NKVD figures were eliminated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003215_901-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2003215-901">[893]</a></sup> According to Kotkin, Stalin "built a personal dictatorship within the Bolshevik dictatorship."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin20144_902-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin20144-902">[894]</a></sup> In both the Soviet Union and elsewhere he came to be portrayed as an "Oriental <a href="/wiki/Despotism" title="Despotism">despot</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviiMcDermott20065_903-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xviiMcDermott20065-903">[895]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Volkogonov" title="Dmitri Volkogonov">Dmitri Volkogonov</a> characterised him as "one of the most powerful figures in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_world" title="History of the world">human history</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991xviii_904-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991xviii-904">[896]</a></sup> McDermott stated that Stalin had "concentrated unprecedented political authority in his hands."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20062_905-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20062-905">[897]</a></sup> Service stated that Stalin "had come closer to personal despotism than almost any monarch in history" by the late 1930s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004370_906-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004370-906">[898]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:May_Day_in_London.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/May_Day_in_London.jpg/220px-May_Day_in_London.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/May_Day_in_London.jpg/330px-May_Day_in_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/May_Day_in_London.jpg/440px-May_Day_in_London.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:May_Day_in_London.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A contingent from the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Great_Britain_(Marxist%E2%80%93Leninist)" title="Communist Party of Great Britain (Marxist–Leninist)">Communist Party of Great Britain (Marxist–Leninist)</a> carrying a banner of Stalin at a <a href="/wiki/May_Day" title="May Day">May Day</a> march through London in 2008</div></div></div>
<p>McDermott nevertheless cautioned against "over-simplistic stereotypes"—promoted in the fiction of writers like <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Solzhenitsyn" title="Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn">Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Grossman" title="Vasily Grossman">Vasily Grossman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Anatoly_Rybakov" title="Anatoly Rybakov">Anatoly Rybakov</a>—that portrayed Stalin as an omnipotent and omnipresent tyrant who controlled every aspect of Soviet life through repression and totalitarianism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20065–6_907-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott20065–6-907">[899]</a></sup> Service similarly warned of the portrayal of Stalin as an "unimpeded despot", noting that "powerful though he was, his powers were not limitless", and his rule depended on his willingness to conserve the Soviet structure he had inherited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20048,_9_908-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20048,_9-908">[900]</a></sup> Kotkin observed that Stalin's ability to remain in power relied on him having a majority in the Politburo at all times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014596_909-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014596-909">[901]</a></sup> Khlevniuk noted that at various points, particularly when Stalin was old and frail, there were "periodic manifestations" in which the party oligarchy threatened his autocratic control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015145_796-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015145-796">[788]</a></sup> Stalin denied to foreign visitors that he was a dictator, stating that those who labelled him such did not understand the Soviet governance structure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991182_910-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991182-910">[902]</a></sup>
</p><p>A vast literature devoted to Stalin has been produced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015ix_911-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015ix-911">[903]</a></sup> During Stalin's lifetime, his approved biographies were largely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hagiographic" title="Hagiographic">hagiographic</a> in content.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20044_912-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20044-912">[904]</a></sup> Stalin ensured that these works gave very little attention to his early life, particularly because he did not wish to emphasise his Georgian origins in a state numerically dominated by Russians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService200413_913-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService200413-913">[905]</a></sup> Since his death many more biographies have been written,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20046_914-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20046-914">[906]</a></sup> although until the 1980s these relied largely on the same sources of information.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20046_914-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20046-914">[906]</a></sup> Under <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>'s Soviet administration various previously classified files on Stalin's life were made available to historians,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20046_914-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20046-914">[906]</a></sup> at which point Stalin became "one of the most urgent and vital issues on the public agenda" in the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xiii_915-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991xiii-915">[907]</a></sup> After the dissolution of the Union in 1991, the rest of the archives were opened to historians, resulting in much new information about Stalin coming to light,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20046Montefiore2007xxi_916-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20046Montefiore2007xxi-916">[908]</a></sup> and producing a flood of new research.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015ix_911-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015ix-911">[903]</a></sup>
</p><p>Leninists remain divided in their views on Stalin; some view him as Lenin's authentic successor, while others believe he betrayed Lenin's ideas by deviating from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20045_733-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20045-733">[725]</a></sup> The socio-economic nature of Stalin's Soviet Union has also been much debated, varyingly being labelled a form of <a href="/wiki/State_socialism" title="State socialism">state socialism</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_capitalism" title="State capitalism">state capitalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bureaucratic_collectivism" title="Bureaucratic collectivism">bureaucratic collectivism</a>, or a totally unique mode of production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandle1999265–266_917-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999265–266-917">[909]</a></sup> Socialist writers like Volkogonov have acknowledged that Stalin's actions damaged "the enormous appeal of socialism generated by the October Revolution".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991173_918-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991173-918">[910]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Death_toll">Death toll</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Excess_mortality_in_the_Soviet_Union_under_Joseph_Stalin" title="Excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin">Excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin</a></div>
<p>With a high number of excess deaths occurring under his rule, Stalin has been labelled "one of the most notorious figures in history."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20043_888-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20043-888">[880]</a></sup> These deaths occurred as a result of collectivisation, famine, terror campaigns, disease, war and mortality rates in the Gulag. As the majority of excess deaths under Stalin were not direct killings, the exact number of victims of Stalinism is difficult to calculate due to lack of consensus among scholars on which deaths can be attributed to the regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman20021163–1164_919-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021163–1164-919">[911]</a></sup> Stalin has also been accused of <a href="/wiki/Excess_mortality_in_the_Soviet_Union_under_Joseph_Stalin#Genocide_allegations" title="Excess mortality in the Soviet Union under Joseph Stalin">genocide</a> in the cases of forced population transfer of ethnic minorities in the Soviet Union and the famine in Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-changonrevison_920-0"><a href="#cite_note-changonrevison-920">[912]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-921"><a href="#cite_note-921">[913]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg/220px-GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg/330px-GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg/440px-GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GULag_2_Museum_Moscow_Russia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Interior of the Gulag Museum in Moscow</div></div></div>
<p>Official records reveal 799,455 documented executions in the Soviet Union between 1921 and 1953; 681,692 of these were carried out between 1937 and 1938, the years of the Great Purge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGettyRitterspornZemskov19931022_922-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGettyRitterspornZemskov19931022-922">[914]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Michael_Ellman" title="Michael Ellman">Michael Ellman</a>, the best modern estimate for the number of repression deaths during the Great Purge is 950,000–1.2 million, which includes executions, deaths in detention, or soon after their release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllman20021162–1163_923-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021162–1163-923">[915]</a></sup> In addition, while archival data shows that 1,053,829 perished in the Gulag from 1934 to 1953,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGettyRitterspornZemskov19931024_924-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGettyRitterspornZemskov19931024-924">[916]</a></sup> the current historical consensus is that of the 18 million people who passed through the Gulag system from 1930 to 1953, between 1.5 and 1.7 million died as a result of their incarceration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHealey20181049_925-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHealey20181049-925">[917]</a></sup> Historian and archival researcher <a href="/wiki/Stephen_G._Wheatcroft" title="Stephen G. Wheatcroft">Stephen G. Wheatcroft</a> and Michael Ellman attribute roughly 3 million deaths to the Stalinist regime, including executions and deaths from criminal negligence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft19961334,_1348Ellman20021172_926-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft19961334,_1348Ellman20021172-926">[918]</a></sup> Wheatcroft and historian <a href="/wiki/R._W._Davies" title="R. W. Davies">R. W. Davies</a> estimate famine deaths at 5.5–6.5 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2004401_927-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2004401-927">[919]</a></sup> while scholar Steven Rosefielde gives a number of 8.7 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERosefielde1996_928-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERosefielde1996-928">[920]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, historian <a href="/wiki/Timothy_D._Snyder" title="Timothy D. Snyder">Timothy D. Snyder</a> in 2011 summarised modern data made after the opening of the Soviet archives in the 1990s and states that Stalin's regime was responsible for 9 million deaths, with 6 million of these being deliberate killings. He further states the estimate is far lower than the estimates of 20 million or above which were made before access to the archives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESnyder2010384Snyder,_27_January_2011_929-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESnyder2010384Snyder,_27_January_2011-929">[921]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_Soviet_Union_and_its_successor_states">In the Soviet Union and its successor states</span></h3>
<p>Shortly after his death, the Soviet Union went through a period of <a href="/wiki/De-Stalinization" title="De-Stalinization">de-Stalinization</a>. Malenkov denounced the Stalin personality cult,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991314_930-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991314-930">[922]</a></sup> which was subsequently criticised in <i>Pravda</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004592_931-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004592-931">[923]</a></sup> In 1956, Khrushchev gave his "Secret Speech", titled "<a href="/wiki/On_the_Cult_of_Personality_and_Its_Consequences" title="On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences">On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences</a>", to a closed session of the <a href="/wiki/20th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Party's 20th Congress</a>. There, <a href="/wiki/Khrushchev_Thaw" title="Khrushchev Thaw">Khrushchev denounced Stalin</a> for both his mass repression and his personality cult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991314Volkogonov1991577–579Service2004594_932-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991314Volkogonov1991577–579Service2004594-932">[924]</a></sup> He repeated these denunciations at the <a href="/wiki/22nd_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">22nd Party Congress</a> in October 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004594_933-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004594-933">[925]</a></sup> In October 1961, Stalin's body was removed from the mausoleum and buried in the <a href="/wiki/Kremlin_Wall_Necropolis" title="Kremlin Wall Necropolis">Kremlin Wall Necropolis</a>, the location marked by a bust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991576Service2004594_934-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVolkogonov1991576Service2004594-934">[926]</a></sup> Stalingrad was renamed Volgograd.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004595_935-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004595-935">[927]</a></sup>
</p><p>Khrushchev's de-Stalinisation process in Soviet society ended when he was replaced as leader by <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> in 1964; the latter introduced a level of re-Stalinisation within the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991315Service2004595_936-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991315Service2004595-936">[928]</a></sup> In 1969 and again in 1979, plans were proposed for a full rehabilitation of Stalin's legacy but on both occasions were defeated by critics within the Soviet and international Marxist–Leninist movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest1991315_937-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest1991315-937">[929]</a></sup> Gorbachev saw the total denunciation of Stalin as necessary for the regeneration of Soviet society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004596_938-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004596-938">[930]</a></sup> After the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, the first President of the new Russian Federation, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a>, continued Gorbachev's denunciation of Stalin but added to it a denunciation of Lenin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004596_938-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004596-938">[930]</a></sup> His successor <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> did not seek to rehabilitate Stalin but emphasised the celebration of Soviet achievements under Stalin's leadership rather than the Stalinist repressions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004596–597_939-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004596–597-939">[931]</a></sup> In October 2017, Putin opened the <a href="/wiki/Wall_of_Grief" title="Wall of Grief">Wall of Grief</a> memorial in Moscow, noting that the "terrible past" would neither be "justified by anything" nor "erased from the national memory."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC,_5_June_2018_940-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC,_5_June_2018-940">[932]</a></sup> In a 2017 interview, Putin added that while "we should not forget the horrors of Stalinism", the excessive demonization of "Stalin is a means to attack [the] Soviet Union and Russia".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-941"><a href="#cite_note-941">[933]</a></sup> In recent years, the government and general public of Russia has been accused of rehabilitating Stalin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-942"><a href="#cite_note-942">[934]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-943"><a href="#cite_note-943">[935]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="764" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_535278_Laying_flowers_and_wreaths_to_Iosif_Stalin%27s_grave_at_Kremlin_wall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Marxist–Leninist activists from the opposition <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Communist Party of the Russian Federation">Communist Party of the Russian Federation</a> laying wreaths at Stalin's Moscow grave in 2009</div></div></div>
<p>Amid the social and economic turmoil of the post-Soviet period, many Russians viewed Stalin as having overseen an era of order, predictability, and pride.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004598_944-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004598-944">[936]</a></sup> He remains a revered figure among many Russian nationalists, who feel nostalgic about the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Soviet victory over Nazi Germany in World War II</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20047_945-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20047-945">[937]</a></sup> and he is regularly invoked approvingly within both Russia's <a href="/wiki/Far-left_politics" title="Far-left politics">far-left</a> and <a href="/wiki/Far-right_politics" title="Far-right politics">far-right</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004599_946-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004599-946">[938]</a></sup>
</p><p>Polling by the <a href="/wiki/Levada_Center" title="Levada Center">Levada Center</a> suggest Stalin's popularity has grown since 2015, with 46% of Russians expressing a favourable view of him in 2017 and 51% in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor,_15_February_2017Luhn,_16_April_2019BBC,_18_April_2019_947-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor,_15_February_2017Luhn,_16_April_2019BBC,_18_April_2019-947">[939]</a></sup> The Center, in 2019, reports that around 70% of Russians believe that Stalin played a positive role in their homeland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-948"><a href="#cite_note-948">[940]</a></sup> A 2021 survey by the Center, showed that Joseph Stalin was named by 39% of Russians as the "most outstanding figure of all times and nations" and while nobody received an absolute majority, Stalin was very clearly in first place, followed by <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a> with 30% and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a> with 23%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-949"><a href="#cite_note-949">[941]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-950"><a href="#cite_note-950">[942]</a></sup> At the same time, there was a growth in pro-Stalinist literature in Russia, much relying upon the misrepresentation or fabrication of source material.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x_951-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x-951">[943]</a></sup> In this literature, Stalin's repressions are regarded either as a necessary measure to defeat "enemies of the people" or the result of lower-level officials acting without Stalin's knowledge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x_951-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x-951">[943]</a></sup>
