</p><p>The only part of the former Soviet Union where admiration for Stalin has remained consistently widespread is <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, although Georgian attitude has been very divided.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService2004597_952-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004597-952">[944]</a></sup> A number of Georgians resent criticism of Stalin, the most famous figure from their nation's modern history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEService20047_945-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20047-945">[937]</a></sup> A 2013 survey by <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi_State_University" title="Tbilisi State University">Tbilisi State University</a> found 45% of Georgians expressing "a positive attitude" to him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC,_5_March_2013_953-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC,_5_March_2013-953">[945]</a></sup> A 2017 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research</a> survey had 57% of Georgians saying he played a positive role in history, compared to 18% of those expressing the same for <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center,_29_June_2017_954-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center,_29_June_2017-954">[946]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some positive sentiment can also be found elsewhere in the former Soviet Union. A 2012 survey commissioned by the <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Endowment_for_International_Peace" title="Carnegie Endowment for International Peace">Carnegie Endowment</a> found 38% of Armenians concurring that their country "will always have need of a leader like Stalin."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarnegie_Endowment_for_International_Peace,_1_March_2013''The_Moscow_Times'',_2_March_2013_955-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarnegie_Endowment_for_International_Peace,_1_March_2013''The_Moscow_Times'',_2_March_2013-955">[947]</a></sup> In early 2010, a new monument to Stalin was erected in <a href="/wiki/Zaporizhzhia" title="Zaporizhzhia">Zaporizhzhia</a>, Ukraine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESnyder,_26_May_2010_956-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESnyder,_26_May_2010-956">[948]</a></sup> In December 2010, unknown persons cut off its head and it was destroyed in an explosion in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERIA_Novosti,_25_February_2011_957-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERIA_Novosti,_25_February_2011-957">[949]</a></sup> In a 2016 <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_International_Institute_of_Sociology" title="Kyiv International Institute of Sociology">Kyiv International Institute of Sociology</a> poll, 38% of respondents had a negative attitude to Stalin, 26% a neutral one and 17% a positive, with 19% refusing to answer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Ukrayinska_Pravda'',_4_March_2015_958-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Ukrayinska_Pravda'',_4_March_2015-958">[950]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p>Yevstafy Zhakov, a pastor of St. Olga Strelna near St. Petersburg, caused an uproar after he hung a portrait of Stalin among sacred images, stating: "I remember him [Stalin] on appropriate occasions, the day of his birthday, his death and that of Victory. He was a true believer". Some weeks after the controversy, the Patriarchate of Moscow forced Zhakov to remove the icon of Stalin from his parish. Despite calls of "some Russians" to "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beatify" title="Beatify">beatify</a>" Stalin, the Russian Orthodox Church has stood its ground in refusing to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-959"><a href="#cite_note-959">[951]</a></sup> There have also been requests by communist officials to canonize Stalin as an official saint, although these requests were never implemented – the author referencing the church's suffering under Stalin's rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-960"><a href="#cite_note-960">[952]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Despite abolishing the office of General Secretary in 1952, Stalin continued to exercise its powers as the <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Secretariat of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Secretariat</a>'s highest-ranking member.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">After Stalin's death, Georgy Malenkov succeeded him as both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and the highest-ranking member of the <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Secretariat of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">party apparatus</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Constituent Assembly was declared dissolved by the Bolshevik-Left SR Soviet government, rendering the end the term served.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-birth_name-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-birth_name_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-birth_name_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-birth_name_4-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Stalin's original Georgian name was Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili (<span title="Georgian-language text"><span lang="ka">იოსებ ბესარიონის ძე ჯუღაშვილი</span></span>). The Russian equivalent of this is Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili (<span title="Russian-language text"><span lang="ru">Иосиф Виссарионович Джугашвили</span></span>). During his years as a revolutionary, he adopted the alias "Stalin", and after the October Revolution he made it his legal name.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">21 December [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 9] 1879 (Soviet records)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While forced to give up control of the Secretariat almost immediately after succeeding Stalin as the body's <i>de facto</i> head, Malenkov was still recognised as "<a href="/wiki/Primus_inter_pares" title="Primus inter pares">first among equals</a>" within the regime for over a year. As late as March 1954, he remained listed as first in the Soviet leadership and continued to chair meetings of the <a href="/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">Politburo</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><div><ul><li>Russian: <span lang="ru">Иосиф Виссарионович Сталин</span>, <small>romanized: </small><span title="Russian-language romanization"><i lang="ru-Latn">Iosif Vissarionovich Stalin</i></span> <small>Russian pronunciation: </small><span class="IPA" lang="ru-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[ɪˈosʲɪf vʲɪsərʲɪˈonəvʲɪt͡ɕ ˈstalʲɪn]</a></span></li><li><a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a>: <span title="Georgian-language text"><span lang="ka" style="font-style: normal;">იოსებ ბესარიონის ძე სტალინი</span></span></li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although there is inconsistency among published sources about Stalin's exact date of birth, Ioseb Jughashvili is found in the records of the Uspensky Church in Gori, Georgia as born on 18 December (<a href="/wiki/Julian_calendar" title="Julian calendar">Old Style</a>: 6 December) 1878. This birth date is maintained in his school leaving certificate, his extensive tsarist Russia police file, a police arrest record from 18 April 1902 which gave his age as 23 years, and all other surviving pre-Revolution documents. As late as 1921, Stalin himself listed his birthday as 18 December 1878 in a curriculum vitae in his own handwriting. After coming to power in 1922, Stalin gave his birth date as 21 December 1879 (<a href="/wiki/Adoption_of_the_Gregorian_calendar#Adoption_in_Eastern_Europe" title="Adoption of the Gregorian calendar">Old Style date</a> 9 December 1879). That became the day his birthday was celebrated in the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200723_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore200723-13">[6]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Citations">Citations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 25em;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014742,_note_25-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014742,_note_25_8-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKotkin2014">Kotkin 2014</a>, p. 742, note 25. Starting in about 1920, Stalin gave a birth date of 21 December [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 9] 1879 despite being born on 18 December [<a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">O.S.</a> 6] 1878.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRees2004">Rees, E.A. </li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200416Montefiore200723Kotkin201417-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConquest199111Service200416Montefiore200723Kotkin201417_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFConquest1991">Conquest 1991</a>, p. 11; <a href="#CITEREFService2004">Service 2004</a>, p. 16; <a href="#CITEREFMontefiore2007">Montefiore 2007</a>, p. 23; <a href="#CITEREFKotkin2014">Kotkin 2014</a>, p. 17.</span>

<li id="cite_note-899"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-899">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.marxists.org/subject/anarchism/voline/1934/red-fascism.html" rel="nofollow">"Red Fascism, by Voline"</a>. <i>www.marxists.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHealey20181049-925"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHealey20181049_925-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHealey2018">Healey 2018</a>, p. 1049: "New studies using declassified Gulag archives have provisionally established a consensus on mortality and 'inhumanity.' The tentative consensus says that once secret records of the Gulag administration in Moscow show a lower death toll than expected from memoir sources, generally between 1.5 and 1.7 million (out of 18 million who passed through) for the years from 1930 to 1953."</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor,_15_February_2017Luhn,_16_April_2019BBC,_18_April_2019-947"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor,_15_February_2017Luhn,_16_April_2019BBC,_18_April_2019_947-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTaylor,_15_February_2017">Taylor, 15 February 2017</a>; <a href="#CITEREFLuhn,_16_April_2019">Luhn, 16 April 2019</a>; <a href="#CITEREFBBC,_18_April_2019">BBC, 18 April 2019</a>.</span>

<li id="cite_note-948"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-948">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2019/04/16/stalins-approval-rating-among-russians-hits-record-high-poll-a65245" rel="nofollow">"Stalin's Approval Rating Among Russians Hits Record High – Poll"</a>. <i>themoscowtimes.com</i>. 16 April 2019.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=themoscowtimes.com&amp;rft.atitle=Stalin%27s+Approval+Rating+Among+Russians+Hits+Record+High+%E2%80%93+Poll&amp;rft.date=2019-04-16&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.themoscowtimes.com%2F2019%2F04%2F16%2Fstalins-approval-rating-among-russians-hits-record-high-poll-a65245&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJoseph+Stalin"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-949"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-949">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.levada.ru/2021/06/21/samye-vydayushhiesya-lichnosti-v-istorii/" rel="nofollow">"САМЫЕ ВЫДАЮЩИЕСЯ ЛИЧНОСТИ В ИСТОРИИ"</a>. <i>levada.ru</i>. 21 June 2021.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=levada.ru&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%A1%D0%90%D0%9C%D0%AB%D0%95+%D0%92%D0%AB%D0%94%D0%90%D0%AE%D0%A9%D0%98%D0%95%D0%A1%D0%AF+%D0%9B%D0%98%D0%A7%D0%9D%D0%9E%D0%A1%D0%A2%D0%98+%D0%92+%D0%98%D0%A1%D0%A2%D0%9E%D0%A0%D0%98%D0%98&amp;rft.date=2021-06-21&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.levada.ru%2F2021%2F06%2F21%2Fsamye-vydayushhiesya-lichnosti-v-istorii%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJoseph+Stalin"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-950"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-950">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFCoynash2021">Coynash, Halya (22 June 2021). <a class="external text" href="https://khpg.org//en/1608809237" rel="nofollow">"Russians name Stalin as the most 'outstanding' figure of all times"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_Human_Rights_Protection_Group" title="Kharkiv Human Rights Protection Group">Kharkiv Human Rights Protection Group</a></i>. <q>The renowned Levada Centre has carried out a survey to find out whom Russians would name as the “ten most outstanding [выдающиеся) figures of all times and nations”.  While nobody received an absolute majority, Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin was very clearly ahead, being named by 39% of the respondents.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Kharkiv+Human+Rights+Protection+Group&amp;rft.atitle=Russians+name+Stalin+as+the+most+%27outstanding%27+figure+of+all+times&amp;rft.date=2021-06-22&amp;rft.aulast=Coynash&amp;rft.aufirst=Halya&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fkhpg.org%2F%2Fen%2F1608809237&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJoseph+Stalin"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment"><code class="cs1-code">{{<a href="/wiki/Template:Cite_web" title="Template:Cite web">cite web</a>}}</code>:  CS1 maint: url-status (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_url-status" title="Category:CS1 maint: url-status">link</a>)</span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x-951"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x_951-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015x_951-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKhlevniuk2015">Khlevniuk 2015</a>, p. x.</span>

<h4><span id="Magazines.2C_newspapers_and_websites"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Magazines,_newspapers_and_websites">Magazines, newspapers and websites</span></h4>

<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_18th_Congress_of_the_All-Union_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" title="Central Committee of the 18th Congress of the All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks)">18th (1939–52)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_19th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 19th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">19th (1952–56)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_20th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">20th (1956–61)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_22nd_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">22nd (1961–66)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_23rd_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 23rd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">23rd (1966–71)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_24th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 24th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">24th (1971–76)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_25th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 25th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">25th (1976–81)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_26th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 26th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">26th (1981–86)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Committee_of_the_27th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Committee of the 27th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">27th (1986–90)</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background:#D40000;color:#FFCC00;;width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Central_Auditing_Commission_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Central Auditing Commission of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union"><span style="color:gold">Auditing Commission</span></a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Lenin</a> (1923–1924)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Alexei_Rykov" title="Alexei Rykov">Rykov</a> (1924–1930)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Molotov" title="Vyacheslav Molotov">Molotov</a> (1930–1941)</li>
<li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Stalin</a> (1941–1953)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Georgy_Malenkov" title="Georgy Malenkov">Malenkov</a> (1953–1955)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Bulganin" title="Nikolai Bulganin">Bulganin</a> (1955–1958)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Khrushchev</a> (1958–1964)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Alexei_Kosygin" title="Alexei Kosygin">Kosygin</a> (1964–1980)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Tikhonov" title="Nikolai Tikhonov">Tikhonov</a> (1980–1985)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Ryzhkov" title="Nikolai Ryzhkov">Ryzhkov</a> (1985–1991)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Valentin_Pavlov" title="Valentin Pavlov">Pavlov</a> (Jan.–Aug. 1991)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Vitaly_Doguzhiyev" title="Vitaly Doguzhiyev">Doguzhiyev</a></i> (Aug. 1991)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ivan_Silayev" title="Ivan Silayev">Silayev</a> (Aug.–Dec. 1991)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/First_Deputy_Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union">First Deputies</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

aria-labelledby="19th_Presidium_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1952–1956)" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:19th_Presidium_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" </div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Candidate members</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="9th_Politburo_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)_(1920–1921)" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:9th_Politburo_of_the_Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)" scope="row" style="width:1%">Full members</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Lev_Kamenev" title="Lev Kamenev">Lev Kamenev</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Krestinsky" title="Nikolay Krestinsky">Nikolay Krestinsky</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Joseph Stalin</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Candidate members</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Bukharin" title="Nikolai Bukharin">Nikolai Bukharin</a></li>

</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div <div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Russification_policy_in_the_territories_occupied_or_annexed_by_Russia_in_the_18–21st_centuries" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Russification" title="Template:Russification"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Russification" title="Template talk:Russification"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Russification&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Russification_policy_in_the_territories_occupied_or_annexed_by_Russia_in_the_18–21st_centuries" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a> policy in the territories occupied or annexed by Russia in the 18–21st centuries</div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">By occupied territories</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
